           <ul>
            <li style="white-space:nowrap;">84.3% <a href="/wiki/Christianity" title="Christianity">Christianity</a></li>
            <li style="white-space:nowrap;">—81.0% <a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church_in_Portugal" title="Catholic Church in Portugal">Roman Catholic</a></li>
            <li style="white-space:nowrap;">—3.3% Other <a href="/wiki/List_of_Christian_denominations" title="List of Christian denominations">Christians</a></li>
            <li style="white-space:nowrap;">6.8% <a href="/wiki/Irreligion" title="Irreligion">No religion</a></li>
            <li style="white-space:nowrap;">0.6% Other religion</li>
            <li style="white-space:nowrap;">8.3% Undeclared</li>
           </ul>
          </div></td>
        </tr>

         <td colspan="2" style="text-align:center">
          <div style="text-align:left;margin-left:auto; margin-right:auto;">
           <ol style="list-style-type: lower-alpha; margin-left: 1em;"> 
            <li value="1"><span class="citation wikicite" id="endnote_a"><b><a href="#ref_a">^</a></b></span> <a href="/wiki/Mirandese_language" title="Mirandese language">Mirandese</a>, spoken in some villages of the municipality of <a href="/wiki/Miranda_do_Douro" title="Miranda do Douro">Miranda do Douro</a>, was officially recognized in 1999 (<i>Lei n.° 7/99 de 29 de Janeiro</i>),<sup id="cite_ref-auto_1-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto-1">[1]</a></sup> awarding it an official right-of-use.<span style="font-size: 120%;"><sup id="cite_ref-auto1_2-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto1-2">[2]</a></sup></span> <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_Sign_Language" title="Portuguese Sign Language">Portuguese Sign Language</a> is also recognized.</li>
            <li value="2"><span class="citation wikicite" id="endnote_b"><b><a href="#ref_b">^</a></b></span> By country of citizenship</li>
            <li value="3"><span class="citation wikicite" id="endnote_c"><b><a href="#ref_c">^</a></b></span> <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Portugal" title="Constitution of Portugal">Portuguese Constitution adopted in 1976</a> with several subsequent minor revisions, between 1982 and 2005.</li> 
           </ol>
          </div></td>
        </tr>
       </tbody>
      </table> 
      <p><b>Portugal</b> (<span style="font-size:85%;">Portuguese:&nbsp;</span><span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/Portuguese" title="Help:IPA/Portuguese">[puɾtuˈɣaɫ]</a></span>), officially the <b>Portuguese Republic</b> (Portuguese: <i lang="pt">República Portuguesa</i> <span style="font-size:85%;"></span><span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/Portuguese" title="Help:IPA/Portuguese">[ʁɛˈpuβlikɐ puɾtuˈɣezɐ]</a></span>),<sup id="cite_ref-16" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-16">[note 4]</a></sup> is a country located on the <a href="/wiki/Iberian_Peninsula" title="Iberian Peninsula">Iberian Peninsula</a>, in <a href="/wiki/Southern_Europe" title="Southern Europe">southwestern Europe</a>. It is the westernmost <a href="/wiki/Sovereign_state" title="Sovereign state">sovereign state</a> in <a href="/wiki/Mainland_Europe" class="mw-redirect" title="Mainland Europe">mainland Europe</a>, being bordered to the west and south by the <a href="/wiki/Atlantic_Ocean" title="Atlantic Ocean">Atlantic Ocean</a> and to the north and east by <a href="/wiki/Spain" title="Spain">Spain</a>. Its territory also includes the Atlantic <a href="/wiki/Archipelago" title="Archipelago">archipelagos</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Azores" title="Azores">Azores</a> and <a href="/wiki/Madeira" title="Madeira">Madeira</a>, both <a href="/wiki/Autonomous_regions_of_Portugal" class="mw-redirect" title="Autonomous regions of Portugal">autonomous regions</a> with their own <a href="/wiki/Regional_government" class="mw-redirect" title="Regional government">regional governments</a>. The official and national language is <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_language" title="Portuguese language">Portuguese</a>. </p>
      <p>Portugal is the oldest <a href="/wiki/Nation_state" title="Nation state">nation state</a> on the Iberian Peninsula and one of the oldest in <a href="/wiki/Europe" title="Europe">Europe</a>, its territory having been continuously settled, invaded and fought over since <a href="/wiki/Prehistoric_Iberia" title="Prehistoric Iberia">prehistoric times</a>. It was inhabited by <a href="/wiki/Pre-Celtic" title="Pre-Celtic">pre-Celtic</a> and <a href="/wiki/Celts" title="Celts">Celtic</a> peoples, visited by <a href="/wiki/Phoenicians" class="mw-redirect" title="Phoenicians">Phoenicians</a>-<a href="/wiki/Carthaginians" class="mw-redirect" title="Carthaginians">Carthaginians</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Greek" title="Ancient Greek">Ancient Greeks</a> and ruled by the <a href="/wiki/Roman_Republic" title="Roman Republic">Romans</a>, who were followed by the invasions of the <a href="/wiki/Suebi" title="Suebi">Suebi</a> and <a href="/wiki/Visigoths" title="Visigoths">Visigothic</a> <a href="/wiki/Germanic_peoples" title="Germanic peoples">Germanic peoples</a>. After the <a href="/wiki/Muslim" class="mw-redirect" title="Muslim">Muslim</a> conquest of the <a href="/wiki/Iberian_Peninsula" title="Iberian Peninsula">Iberian Peninsula</a>, most of its territory was part of <a href="/wiki/Al-Andalus" title="Al-Andalus">Al-Andalus</a>. Portugal as a country was established during the early Christian <i><a href="/wiki/Reconquista" title="Reconquista">Reconquista</a></i>. Founded in 868, the <a href="/wiki/County_of_Portugal" title="County of Portugal">County of Portugal</a> gained prominence after the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_S%C3%A3o_Mamede" title="Battle of São Mamede">Battle of São Mamede</a> (1128). The <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Portugal" title="Kingdom of Portugal">Kingdom of Portugal</a> was later proclaimed following the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Ourique" title="Battle of Ourique">Battle of Ourique</a> (1139), and independence from <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Le%C3%B3n" title="Kingdom of León">León</a> was recognized by the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Zamora" title="Treaty of Zamora">Treaty of Zamora</a> (1143).<sup id="cite_ref-17" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-17">[13]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In the 15th and 16th centuries, Portugal established the <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_Empire" title="Portuguese Empire">first global maritime and commercial empire</a>, becoming one of the world's major economic, political and military <a href="/wiki/Education_superpower" class="mw-redirect" title="Education superpower">powers</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-18" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-18">[14]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-19" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-19">[15]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-20" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-20">[16]</a></sup> During this period, today referred to as the <a href="/wiki/Age_of_Discovery" title="Age of Discovery">Age of Discovery</a>, Portuguese explorers pioneered maritime exploration with the discovery of what would become <a href="/wiki/Colonial_Brazil" title="Colonial Brazil">Brazil</a> (1500). During this time Portugal monopolized the <a href="/wiki/Spice_trade" title="Spice trade">spice trade</a>, <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Tordesillas" title="Treaty of Tordesillas">divided the world into hemispheres of dominion with Castile</a>, and the empire expanded with military campaigns in <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_presence_in_Asia" title="Portuguese presence in Asia">Asia</a>. However, events such as the <a href="/wiki/1755_Lisbon_earthquake" title="1755 Lisbon earthquake">1755 Lisbon earthquake</a>, the country's occupation during the <a href="/wiki/Napoleonic_Wars" title="Napoleonic Wars">Napoleonic Wars</a>, and the independence of Brazil (1822) erased to a great extent <a href="/wiki/Economic_history_of_Portugal" title="Economic history of Portugal">Portugal's prior opulence</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-21" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-21">[17]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>After the <a href="/wiki/5_October_1910_revolution" title="5 October 1910 revolution">1910 revolution</a> deposed the monarchy, the democratic but unstable <a href="/wiki/First_Portuguese_Republic" title="First Portuguese Republic">Portuguese First Republic</a> was established, later being superseded by the <i><a href="/wiki/Estado_Novo_(Portugal)" title="Estado Novo (Portugal)">Estado Novo</a></i> authoritarian regime. Democracy was restored after the <a href="/wiki/Carnation_Revolution" title="Carnation Revolution">Carnation Revolution</a> (1974), ending the <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_Colonial_War" title="Portuguese Colonial War">Portuguese Colonial War</a>. Shortly after, independence was granted to almost all <a href="/wiki/Portuguese-speaking_African_countries" title="Portuguese-speaking African countries">its overseas territories</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Transfer_of_sovereignty_over_Macau" title="Transfer of sovereignty over Macau">handover of Macau to China</a> (1999) marked the end of what can be considered one of the longest-lived colonial empires in history. </p>
      <p>Portugal has left a profound cultural, architectural and linguistic influence <a href="/wiki/Evolution_of_the_Portuguese_Empire" title="Evolution of the Portuguese Empire">across the globe</a>, with a legacy of around 250 million <a href="/wiki/Lusophone" title="Lusophone">Portuguese speakers</a>, and many <a href="/wiki/Portuguese-based_creole_languages" title="Portuguese-based creole languages">Portuguese-based creoles</a>. It is a <a href="/wiki/Developed_country" title="Developed country">developed country</a> with an <a href="/wiki/Developed_country#IMF_advanced_economies" title="Developed country">advanced economy</a> and high <a href="/wiki/Living_standard" class="mw-redirect" title="Living standard">living standards</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-22" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-22">[18]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-23" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-23">[19]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-24" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-24">[20]</a></sup> Additionally, it is highly placed in rankings of <a href="/wiki/World_Index_of_Moral_Freedom" title="World Index of Moral Freedom">moral freedom</a> (2nd), <a href="/wiki/Global_Peace_Index" title="Global Peace Index">peacefulness</a> (3rd), <a href="/wiki/Democracy" title="Democracy">democracy</a> (7th),<sup id="cite_ref-25" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-25">[21]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Press_Freedom_Index" title="Press Freedom Index">press freedom</a> (10th), <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_Fragile_States_Index" title="List of countries by Fragile States Index">stability</a> (14th), <a href="/wiki/Social_Progress_Index" title="Social Progress Index">social progress</a> (21th), and <a href="/wiki/Legatum_Prosperity_Index" title="Legatum Prosperity Index">prosperity</a> (27th). A member of the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations" title="United Nations">United Nations</a>, the <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">European Union</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Schengen_Area" title="Schengen Area">Schengen Area</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Council_of_Europe" title="Council of Europe">Council of Europe</a> (CoE), Portugal was also one of the founding members of <a href="/wiki/NATO" title="NATO">NATO</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Eurozone" title="Eurozone">eurozone</a>, the <a href="/wiki/OECD" title="OECD">OECD</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Community_of_Portuguese_Language_Countries" title="Community of Portuguese Language Countries">Community of Portuguese Language Countries</a>. </p> 
      <div id="toc" class="toc" role="navigation" aria-labelledby="mw-toc-heading">

      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Etymology">Etymology</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Portugal&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1" title="Edit section: Etymology">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2> 
      <p>The word Portugal derives from the <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Rome" title="Ancient Rome">Roman</a>-<a href="/wiki/Celts" title="Celts">Celtic</a> place name <b><a href="/wiki/Portus_Cale" title="Portus Cale">Portus Cale</a></b>;<sup id="cite_ref-26" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-26">[22]</a></sup> a city where present-day <a href="/wiki/Vila_Nova_de_Gaia" title="Vila Nova de Gaia">Vila Nova de Gaia</a> now stands, at the mouth of the <a href="/wiki/River_Douro" class="mw-redirect" title="River Douro">River Douro</a> in the north of what is now Portugal. The name of the city is from the Latin word for <a href="/wiki/Port" title="Port">port</a> or harbour, <i>portus</i>, but the second element of <i>Portus Cale</i> is less clear. The mainstream explanation for the name is that it is an <a href="/wiki/Ethnonym" title="Ethnonym">ethnonym</a> derived from the <a href="/wiki/Castro_culture" title="Castro culture">Castro people</a>, also known as the <a href="/wiki/Callaeci" class="mw-redirect" title="Callaeci">Callaeci</a>, Gallaeci or Gallaecia, who occupied the north-west of the Iberian Peninsula.<sup id="cite_ref-academia.edu_27-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-academia.edu-27">[23]</a></sup> The names <i>Cale</i> and <i>Callaici</i> are the origin of today's <i><a href="/wiki/Vila_Nova_de_Gaia" title="Vila Nova de Gaia">Gaia</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Galicia_(Spain)" title="Galicia (Spain)">Galicia</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-ReferenceA_28-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ReferenceA-28">[24]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-auto3_29-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto3-29">[25]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Another theory proposes that <i>Cale</i> or <i>Calle</i> is a derivation of the Celtic word for port, like the <a href="/wiki/Irish_language" title="Irish language">Irish</a> <i>caladh</i> or <a href="/wiki/Scottish_Gaelic" title="Scottish Gaelic">Scottish Gaelic</a> <i>cala</i>. These explanations, would require the pre-Roman language of the area to have been a branch of Q-Celtic, which is not generally accepted because the region's pre-Roman language was Gallaecian Celtic, usually considered P-Celtic. However, scholars like Jean Markale and Tranoy propose that the Celtic branches all share the same origin, and placenames such as Cale, Gal, Gaia, Calais, Galatia, Galicia, Gaelic, Gael, Gaul, Wales, Cornwall, Wallonia and others all stem from one linguistic root.<sup id="cite_ref-ReferenceA_28-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ReferenceA-28">[24]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-30" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-30">[26]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-31" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-31">[27]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Another theory has it that Cala was the name of a Celtic goddess (drawing a comparison with the <a href="/wiki/Gaelic_languages" class="mw-redirect" title="Gaelic languages">Gaelic</a> <i><a href="/wiki/Cailleach" title="Cailleach">Cailleach</a></i>, a supernatural hag). Some French scholars believe the name may have come from "Portus Gallus",<sup id="cite_ref-32" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-32">[28]</a></sup> the port of the Gauls or Celts. </p>
      <p>Around 200 BC, the Romans took the <a href="/wiki/Iberian_Peninsula" title="Iberian Peninsula">Iberian Peninsula</a> from the <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Carthage" title="Ancient Carthage">Carthaginians</a> during the <a href="/wiki/Second_Punic_War" title="Second Punic War">Second Punic War</a>. In the process they conquered Cale, renaming it Portus Cale ("Port of Cale") and incorporating it in the province of <a href="/wiki/Gaelicia" class="mw-redirect" title="Gaelicia">Gaellicia</a> with its capital in <a href="/wiki/Bracara_Augusta" class="mw-redirect" title="Bracara Augusta">Bracara Augusta</a> (modern day <a href="/wiki/Braga" title="Braga">Braga</a>, Portugal). During the <a href="/wiki/Middle_Ages" title="Middle Ages">Middle Ages</a>, the region around Portus Cale became known by the <a href="/wiki/Suebi" title="Suebi">Suebi</a> and <a href="/wiki/Visigoths" title="Visigoths">Visigoths</a> as <i><b>Portucale</b></i>. The name <i>Portucale</i> evolved into <i><b>Portugale</b></i> during the 7th and 8th centuries, and by the 9th century, that term was used extensively to refer to the region between the rivers <a href="/wiki/Douro" title="Douro">Douro</a> and <a href="/wiki/Minho_River" class="mw-redirect" title="Minho River">Minho</a>. By the 11th and 12th centuries, <i>Portugale</i>, <i>Portugallia</i>, <i>Portvgallo</i> or <i>Portvgalliae</i> was already referred to as <b>Portugal</b>. </p>
      <p>The 14th century <a href="/wiki/Middle_French" title="Middle French">Middle French</a> name for the country, <i>Portingal</i>, which added an intrusive /n/ sound through the process of <a href="/wiki/Excrescence_(phonology)" class="mw-redirect" title="Excrescence (phonology)">excrescence</a>, spread to <a href="/wiki/Middle_English" title="Middle English">Middle English</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-OED_33-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-OED-33">[29]</a></sup> Middle English variant spellings included <i>Portingall</i>, <i>Portingale</i>,<sup id="cite_ref-35" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-35">[note 5]</a></sup> <i>Portyngale</i> and <i>Portingaill</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-OED_33-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-OED-33">[29]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-36" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-36">[31]</a></sup> The spelling <i>Portyngale</i> is found in Chaucer's Epilogue to <a href="/wiki/The_Nun%27s_Priest%27s_Tale" title="The Nun's Priest's Tale">the Nun's Priest's Tale</a>. These variants survive in the <i><a href="/wiki/Torrent_of_Portyngale" title="Torrent of Portyngale">Torrent of Portyngale</a></i>, a Middle English romance composed around 1400, and "<a href="/wiki/Old_Robin_of_Portingale" title="Old Robin of Portingale">Old Robin of Portingale</a>", an English Child ballad. <i>Portingal</i> and variants were also used in <a href="/wiki/Scots_language" title="Scots language">Scots</a><sup id="cite_ref-OED_33-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-OED-33">[29]</a></sup> and survive in the <a href="/wiki/Cornish_language" title="Cornish language">Cornish</a> name for the country, <i><a href="https://kw.wikipedia.org/wiki/Portyngal" class="extiw" title="kw:Portyngal">Portyngal</a></i>. </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="History">History</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Portugal&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2" title="Edit section: History">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2> 
      <table class="box-More_citations_needed plainlinks metadata ambox ambox-content ambox-Refimprove" role="presentation">
       <tbody>
        <tr>
         <td class="mbox-image">
          <div style="width:52px">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Question_book-new.svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/99/Question_book-new.svg/50px-Question_book-new.svg.png" decoding="async" width="50" height="39" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/99/Question_book-new.svg/75px-Question_book-new.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/99/Question_book-new.svg/100px-Question_book-new.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="512" data-file-height="399"></a>
          </div></td>
         <td class="mbox-text">
          <div class="mbox-text-span">
           This section <b>needs additional citations for <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability" title="Wikipedia:Verifiability">verification</a></b>.<span class="hide-when-compact"> Please help <a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Portugal&amp;action=edit">improve this article</a> by <a href="/wiki/Help:Referencing_for_beginners" title="Help:Referencing for beginners">adding citations to reliable sources</a>. Unsourced material may be challenged and removed.<br><small><span class="plainlinks"><i>Find sources:</i>&nbsp;<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="//www.google.com/search?as_eq=wikipedia&amp;q=%22Portugal%22">"Portugal"</a>&nbsp;–&nbsp;<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="//www.google.com/search?tbm=nws&amp;q=%22Portugal%22+-wikipedia">news</a>&nbsp;<b>·</b> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="//www.google.com/search?&amp;q=%22Portugal%22+site:news.google.com/newspapers&amp;source=newspapers">newspapers</a>&nbsp;<b>·</b> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="//www.google.com/search?tbs=bks:1&amp;q=%22Portugal%22+-wikipedia">books</a>&nbsp;<b>·</b> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="//scholar.google.com/scholar?q=%22Portugal%22">scholar</a>&nbsp;<b>·</b> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.jstor.org/action/doBasicSearch?Query=%22Portugal%22&amp;acc=on&amp;wc=on">JSTOR</a></span></small></span> <small class="date-container"><i>(<span class="date">October 2018</span>)</i></small><small class="hide-when-compact"><i> (<a href="/wiki/Help:Maintenance_template_removal" title="Help:Maintenance template removal">Learn how and when to remove this template message</a>)</i></small>
          </div></td>
        </tr>
       </tbody>
      </table> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Prehistory">Prehistory</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Portugal&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3" title="Edit section: Prehistory">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Escoural_Cave" title="Escoural Cave">Escoural Cave</a> and <a href="/wiki/History_of_Portugal" title="History of Portugal">History of Portugal</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Rock_Art_Foz_Coa_01.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/18/Rock_Art_Foz_Coa_01.jpg/220px-Rock_Art_Foz_Coa_01.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/18/Rock_Art_Foz_Coa_01.jpg/330px-Rock_Art_Foz_Coa_01.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/18/Rock_Art_Foz_Coa_01.jpg/440px-Rock_Art_Foz_Coa_01.jpg 2x" data-file-width="909" data-file-height="682"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Rock_Art_Foz_Coa_01.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Prehistoric_Rock_Art_Sites_in_the_C%C3%B4a_Valley" title="Prehistoric Rock Art Sites in the Côa Valley">Prehistoric Rock Art Sites in the Côa Valley</a>.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The early history of Portugal is shared with the rest of the <a href="/wiki/Iberian_Peninsula" title="Iberian Peninsula">Iberian Peninsula</a> located in Southwestern Europe. <a href="/wiki/The_name_of_Portugal" class="mw-redirect" title="The name of Portugal">The name of Portugal</a> derives from the joined Romano-Celtic name <a href="/wiki/Portus_Cale" title="Portus Cale">Portus Cale</a>. The region was <a href="/wiki/Pre-Roman_peoples_of_the_Iberian_Peninsula" class="mw-redirect" title="Pre-Roman peoples of the Iberian Peninsula">settled</a> by Pre-<a href="/wiki/Celts" title="Celts">Celts</a> and Celts, giving origin to peoples like the <a href="/wiki/Gallaeci" title="Gallaeci">Gallaeci</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lusitanians" title="Lusitanians">Lusitanians</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-37" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-37">[32]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Celtici" title="Celtici">Celtici</a> and <a href="/wiki/Cynetes" title="Cynetes">Cynetes</a> (also known as <a href="/wiki/Conii" class="mw-redirect" title="Conii">Conii</a>),<sup id="cite_ref-38" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-38">[33]</a></sup> visited by <a href="/wiki/Phoenicians" class="mw-redirect" title="Phoenicians">Phoenicians</a>-<a href="/wiki/Carthaginians" class="mw-redirect" title="Carthaginians">Carthaginians</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Greek" title="Ancient Greek">Ancient Greeks</a>, was incorporated in the <a href="/wiki/Roman_Republic" title="Roman Republic">Roman Republic</a> dominions as <a href="/wiki/Lusitania" title="Lusitania">Lusitania</a> and part of <a href="/wiki/Gallaecia" title="Gallaecia">Gallaecia</a>, after 45 BC until 298 AD. </p>
      <p>The region of present-day Portugal was inhabited by <a href="/wiki/Neanderthal" title="Neanderthal">Neanderthals</a> and then by <i><a href="/wiki/Homo_sapiens" class="mw-redirect" title="Homo sapiens">Homo sapiens</a></i>, who roamed the border-less region of the northern Iberian peninsula.<sup id="cite_ref-Birmp1_39-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Birmp1-39">[34]</a></sup> These were subsistence societies and although they did not establish prosperous settlements, they did form organized societies. Neolithic Portugal experimented with domestication of herding animals, the raising of some cereal crops and fluvial or marine fishing.<sup id="cite_ref-Birmp1_39-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Birmp1-39">[34]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Centro_de_Alcalar_2017_-_Monumento_9_-_Entrada_(cropped).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/56/Centro_de_Alcalar_2017_-_Monumento_9_-_Entrada_%28cropped%29.jpg/220px-Centro_de_Alcalar_2017_-_Monumento_9_-_Entrada_%28cropped%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="161" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/56/Centro_de_Alcalar_2017_-_Monumento_9_-_Entrada_%28cropped%29.jpg/330px-Centro_de_Alcalar_2017_-_Monumento_9_-_Entrada_%28cropped%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/56/Centro_de_Alcalar_2017_-_Monumento_9_-_Entrada_%28cropped%29.jpg/440px-Centro_de_Alcalar_2017_-_Monumento_9_-_Entrada_%28cropped%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1819" data-file-height="1334"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Centro_de_Alcalar_2017_-_Monumento_9_-_Entrada_(cropped).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Megalithic_Monuments_of_Alcalar" title="Megalithic Monuments of Alcalar">Megalithic Monuments of Alcalar</a>, built in the 3rd millennium BCE.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>It is believed by some scholars that early in the first millennium BC, several waves of <a href="/wiki/Celts" title="Celts">Celts</a> invaded Portugal from Central Europe and inter-married with the local populations, forming <a href="/wiki/Pre-Roman_peoples_of_the_Iberian_Peninsula" class="mw-redirect" title="Pre-Roman peoples of the Iberian Peninsula">different tribes</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-40" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-40">[35]</a></sup>Another theory suggests that Celts inhabited Western Iberia / Portugal well before any large Celtic migrations from <a href="/wiki/Central_Europe" title="Central Europe">Central Europe</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-41" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-41">[36]</a></sup> In addition, a number of linguists expert in ancient Celtic have presented compelling evidence that the <a href="/wiki/Tartessian_language" title="Tartessian language">Tartessian language</a>, once spoken in parts of SW Spain and SW Portugal, is at least proto-Celtic in structure.<sup id="cite_ref-42" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-42">[37]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Modern archaeology and research shows a Portuguese root to the <a href="/wiki/Celts" title="Celts">Celts</a> in Portugal and elsewhere.<sup id="cite_ref-43" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-43">[38]</a></sup> During that period and until the Roman invasions, the Castro culture (a variation of the <a href="/wiki/Urnfield_culture" title="Urnfield culture">Urnfield culture</a> also known as <i>Urnenfelderkultur</i>) was prolific in Portugal and modern Galicia.<sup id="cite_ref-44" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-44">[39]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-45" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-45">[40]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-auto3_29-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto3-29">[25]</a></sup> This culture, together with the surviving elements of the Atlantic megalithic culture<sup id="cite_ref-46" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-46">[41]</a></sup> and the contributions that come from the more Western Mediterranean cultures, ended up in what has been called the Cultura Castreja or <a href="/wiki/Castro_Culture" class="mw-redirect" title="Castro Culture">Castro Culture</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-47" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-47">[42]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-48" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-48">[43]</a></sup> This designation refers to the characteristic Celtic populations called 'dùn', 'dùin' or 'don' in <a href="/wiki/Goidelic_languages" title="Goidelic languages">Gaelic</a> and that the Romans called castrae in their chronicles.<sup id="cite_ref-49" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-49">[44]</a></sup> </p> 
      <style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r978413945/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">.mw-parser-output .tmulti .thumbinner{display:flex;flex-direction:column}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow{display:flex;flex-direction:row;clear:left;flex-wrap:wrap;width:100%;box-sizing:border-box}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle{margin:1px;float:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .theader{clear:both;font-weight:bold;text-align:center;align-self:center;background-color:transparent;width:100%}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .thumbcaption{background-color:transparent}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-left{text-align:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-right{text-align:right}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-center{text-align:center}@media all and (max-width:720px){.mw-parser-output .tmulti .thumbinner{width:100%!important;box-sizing:border-box;max-width:none!important;align-items:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow{justify-content:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle{float:none!important;max-width:100%!important;box-sizing:border-box;text-align:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle .thumbcaption{text-align:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow>.thumbcaption{text-align:center}}</style>
      <div class="thumb tmulti tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:204px;max-width:204px">
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px">
          <div class="thumbimage">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Citania_briteiros_casa_2.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/29/Citania_briteiros_casa_2.jpg/200px-Citania_briteiros_casa_2.jpg" decoding="async" width="200" height="150" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/29/Citania_briteiros_casa_2.jpg/300px-Citania_briteiros_casa_2.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/29/Citania_briteiros_casa_2.jpg/400px-Citania_briteiros_casa_2.jpg 2x" data-file-width="640" data-file-height="480"></a>
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px">
          <div class="thumbimage">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Ch%C3%A3o_cividade_terroso.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/42/Ch%C3%A3o_cividade_terroso.JPG/200px-Ch%C3%A3o_cividade_terroso.JPG" decoding="async" width="200" height="150" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/42/Ch%C3%A3o_cividade_terroso.JPG/300px-Ch%C3%A3o_cividade_terroso.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/42/Ch%C3%A3o_cividade_terroso.JPG/400px-Ch%C3%A3o_cividade_terroso.JPG 2x" data-file-width="2000" data-file-height="1500"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           Examples of <a href="/wiki/Castro_culture" title="Castro culture">Celtic Castro culture</a> in <a href="/wiki/Northern_Portugal" class="mw-redirect" title="Northern Portugal">Northern Portugal</a> (9th – 1st c. BCE): <a href="/wiki/Cit%C3%A2nia_de_Briteiros" title="Citânia de Briteiros">Citânia de Briteiros</a> (top) and <a href="/wiki/Cividade_de_Terroso" title="Cividade de Terroso">Cividade de Terroso</a> (bottom).
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Based on the Roman chronicles about the <a href="/wiki/Callaeci" class="mw-redirect" title="Callaeci">Callaeci</a> peoples, along with the <a href="/wiki/Lebor_Gab%C3%A1la_%C3%89renn" title="Lebor Gabála Érenn">Lebor Gabála Érenn</a><sup id="cite_ref-50" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-50">[45]</a></sup> narrations and the interpretation of the abundant archaeological remains throughout the northern half of Portugal and Galicia, it is possible to infer that there was a matriarchal society, with a military and religious aristocracy probably of the feudal type. The figures of maximum authority were the chieftain (chefe tribal), of military type and with authority in his Castro or clan, and the druid, mainly referring to medical and religious functions that could be common to several castros. The Celtic cosmogony remained homogeneous due to the ability of the <a href="/wiki/Druids" class="mw-redirect" title="Druids">druids</a> to meet in councils with the druids of other areas, which ensured the transmission of knowledge and the most significant events. The first documentary references to Castro society are provided by chroniclers of Roman military campaigns such as <a href="/wiki/Strabo" title="Strabo">Strabo</a>, <a href="/wiki/Herodotus" title="Herodotus">Herodotus</a> and <a href="/wiki/Pliny_the_Elder" title="Pliny the Elder">Pliny the Elder</a> among others, about the social organization, and describing the inhabitants of these territories, the <a href="/wiki/Gallaecia" title="Gallaecia">Gallaeci of Northern Portugal</a> as: "A group of barbarians who spend the day fighting and the night eating, drinking and dancing under the moon." </p>
      <p>There were other similar tribes, and chief among them were the <a href="/wiki/Lusitanians" title="Lusitanians">Lusitanians</a>; the core area of these people lay in inland central Portugal, while numerous other related tribes existed such as the <a href="/wiki/Celtici" title="Celtici">Celtici of Alentejo</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Cynetes" title="Cynetes">Cynetes or Conii of the Algarve</a>. Among the tribes or sub-divisions were the <a href="/wiki/Bracari" title="Bracari">Bracari</a>, <a href="/wiki/Coelerni" title="Coelerni">Coelerni</a>, <a href="/wiki/Equaesi" title="Equaesi">Equaesi</a>, <a href="/wiki/Grovii" title="Grovii">Grovii</a>, <a href="/wiki/Interamici" title="Interamici">Interamici</a>, <a href="/wiki/Leuni" title="Leuni">Leuni</a>, <a href="/wiki/Luanqui" title="Luanqui">Luanqui</a>, <a href="/wiki/Limici" title="Limici">Limici</a>, <a href="/wiki/Narbasi" title="Narbasi">Narbasi</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nemetati" title="Nemetati">Nemetati</a>, <a href="/wiki/Paesuri" title="Paesuri">Paesuri</a>, <a href="/wiki/Quaquerni" title="Quaquerni">Quaquerni</a>, <a href="/wiki/Seurbi" title="Seurbi">Seurbi</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tamagani" title="Tamagani">Tamagani</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tapoli" title="Tapoli">Tapoli</a>, <a href="/wiki/Turduli" title="Turduli">Turduli</a>, <a href="/wiki/Turduli_Veteres" title="Turduli Veteres">Turduli Veteres</a>, <a href="/wiki/Turdulorum_Oppida" class="mw-redirect" title="Turdulorum Oppida">Turdulorum Oppida</a>, <a href="/wiki/Turodi" title="Turodi">Turodi</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Zoelae" title="Zoelae">Zoelae</a>. A few small, semi-permanent, commercial coastal settlements (such as <a href="/wiki/Tavira_Municipality" class="mw-redirect" title="Tavira Municipality">Tavira</a>) were also founded in the <a href="/wiki/Algarve" title="Algarve">Algarve</a> region by <a href="/wiki/Phoenicians" class="mw-redirect" title="Phoenicians">Phoenicians</a>–<a href="/wiki/Carthaginians" class="mw-redirect" title="Carthaginians">Carthaginians</a>. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Roman_Lusitania_and_Gallaecia">Roman Lusitania and Gallaecia</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Portugal&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4" title="Edit section: Roman Lusitania and Gallaecia">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Lusitania" title="Lusitania">Lusitania</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gallaecia" title="Gallaecia">Gallaecia</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Hispania" title="Hispania">Hispania</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Evora-RomanTemple_edit.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/be/Evora-RomanTemple_edit.jpg/220px-Evora-RomanTemple_edit.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="163" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/be/Evora-RomanTemple_edit.jpg/330px-Evora-RomanTemple_edit.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/be/Evora-RomanTemple_edit.jpg/440px-Evora-RomanTemple_edit.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3676" data-file-height="2729"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Evora-RomanTemple_edit.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Roman_Temple_of_%C3%89vora" title="Roman Temple of Évora">Roman Temple of Évora</a>, in the <a href="/wiki/Alentejo" title="Alentejo">Alentejo</a>, is one of the best preserved <a href="/wiki/Roman_civilization" class="mw-redirect" title="Roman civilization">Roman</a>-built structures in the country.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Romans first invaded the Iberian Peninsula in 219 BC. The Carthaginians, Rome's adversary in the <a href="/wiki/Punic_Wars" title="Punic Wars">Punic Wars</a>, were expelled from their coastal colonies. During the last days of <a href="/wiki/Julius_Caesar" title="Julius Caesar">Julius Caesar</a>, almost the entire peninsula was annexed to the <a href="/wiki/Roman_Republic" title="Roman Republic">Roman Republic</a>. </p>
      <p>The Roman conquest of what is now part of Portugal took almost two hundred years and took many lives of young soldiers and the lives of those who were sentenced to a certain death in the slave mines when not sold as slaves to other parts of the empire. It suffered a severe setback in 155 BC, when a <a href="/wiki/Lusitanian_War" title="Lusitanian War">rebellion</a> began in the north. The <a href="/wiki/Lusitanians" title="Lusitanians">Lusitanians</a> and other native tribes, under the leadership of <a href="/wiki/Viriathus" title="Viriathus">Viriathus</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-51" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-51">[46]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-52" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-52">[47]</a></sup> wrested control of all of western Iberia. </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Torre_de_Centum_Cellas.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c2/Torre_de_Centum_Cellas.jpg/200px-Torre_de_Centum_Cellas.jpg" decoding="async" width="200" height="267" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c2/Torre_de_Centum_Cellas.jpg/300px-Torre_de_Centum_Cellas.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c2/Torre_de_Centum_Cellas.jpg/400px-Torre_de_Centum_Cellas.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2736" data-file-height="3648"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Torre_de_Centum_Cellas.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Centum_Cellas" title="Centum Cellas">Centum Cellas</a>, in the <a href="/wiki/Beira_(Portugal)" title="Beira (Portugal)">Beira region</a>, is a Roman <i><a href="/wiki/Villa_rustica" title="Villa rustica">villa rustica</a></i> from the 1st century CE.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Rome sent numerous legions and its best generals to Lusitania to quell the rebellion, but to no avail – the Lusitanians kept conquering territory. The Roman leaders decided to change their strategy. They bribed Viriathus's allies to kill him. In 139 BC, Viriathus was assassinated and <a href="/wiki/Tautalus" title="Tautalus">Tautalus</a> became leader of the Lusitanians. </p>
      <p>Rome installed a colonial regime. The complete Romanization of Lusitania only took place in the <a href="/wiki/Visigothic" class="mw-redirect" title="Visigothic">Visigothic</a> era. </p>
      <p>In 27 BC, Lusitania gained the status of <a href="/wiki/Roman_province" title="Roman province">Roman province</a>. Later, a northern province of Lusitania was formed, known as <a href="/wiki/Gallaecia" title="Gallaecia">Gallaecia</a>, with capital in Bracara Augusta, today's <a href="/wiki/Braga" title="Braga">Braga</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-53" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-53">[48]</a></sup> There are still many ruins of castros (<a href="/wiki/Hill_forts" class="mw-redirect" title="Hill forts">hill forts</a>) throughout modern Portugal and remains of the <a href="/wiki/Castro_culture" title="Castro culture">Castro culture</a>. Some urban remains are quite large, like <a href="/wiki/Con%C3%ADmbriga" title="Conímbriga">Conímbriga</a> and <a href="/wiki/Mir%C3%B3briga" title="Miróbriga">Mirobriga</a>. The former, beyond being one of the largest <a href="/wiki/Roman_Empire" title="Roman Empire">Roman</a> settlements in Portugal, is also classified as a <a href="/wiki/Monuments_of_Portugal" class="mw-redirect" title="Monuments of Portugal">National Monument</a>. Conímbriga lies 16 kilometres (10 miles) from <a href="/wiki/Coimbra" title="Coimbra">Coimbra</a>, which in turn was the ancient <i><a href="/wiki/Aeminium" title="Aeminium">Aeminium</a></i>. The site also has a museum that displays objects found by archaeologists during their excavations. </p>
      <p>Several works of engineering, such as baths, temples, bridges, roads, circuses, theatres and laymen's homes are preserved throughout the country. Coins, some coined in Lusitanian land, as well as numerous pieces of ceramics, were also found. Contemporary historians include <a href="/wiki/Paulus_Orosius" class="mw-redirect" title="Paulus Orosius">Paulus Orosius</a> (c. 375–418)<sup id="cite_ref-54" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-54">[49]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Hydatius" title="Hydatius">Hydatius</a> (c. 400–469), bishop of <a href="/wiki/Aquae_Flaviae" title="Aquae Flaviae">Aquae Flaviae</a>, who reported on the final years of the Roman rule and arrival of the <a href="/wiki/Germanic_peoples" title="Germanic peoples">Germanic tribes</a>. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Germanic_kingdoms:_Suebi_and_Visigoths">Germanic kingdoms: Suebi and Visigoths</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Portugal&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5" title="Edit section: Germanic kingdoms: Suebi and Visigoths">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Reino_suevo.svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3e/Reino_suevo.svg/200px-Reino_suevo.svg.png" decoding="async" width="200" height="230" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3e/Reino_suevo.svg/300px-Reino_suevo.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3e/Reino_suevo.svg/400px-Reino_suevo.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="475" data-file-height="546"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Reino_suevo.svg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Map of the <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_the_Suebi" title="Kingdom of the Suebi">Kingdom of the Suebi</a> in the 5th and 6th centuries
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Iberia_560.svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0f/Iberia_560.svg/220px-Iberia_560.svg.png" decoding="async" width="220" height="181" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0f/Iberia_560.svg/330px-Iberia_560.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0f/Iberia_560.svg/440px-Iberia_560.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="924" data-file-height="762"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Iberia_560.svg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Visigothic_kingdom" class="mw-redirect" title="Visigothic kingdom">Visigothic kingdom</a> in Iberia c.560
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>In the early 5th century, <a href="/wiki/Germanic_peoples" title="Germanic peoples">Germanic tribes</a>, namely the <a href="/wiki/Suebi" title="Suebi">Suebi</a><sup id="cite_ref-auto4_55-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto4-55">[50]</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/Vandals" title="Vandals">Vandals</a> (<a href="/wiki/Silingi" title="Silingi">Silingi</a> and <a href="/wiki/Hasdingi" title="Hasdingi">Hasdingi</a>) together with their allies, the <a href="/wiki/Sarmatian" class="mw-redirect" title="Sarmatian">Sarmatians</a> and <a href="/wiki/Alans" title="Alans">Alans</a> invaded the <a href="/wiki/Iberian_Peninsula" title="Iberian Peninsula">Iberian Peninsula</a> where they would form their kingdom. The <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_the_Suebi" title="Kingdom of the Suebi">Kingdom of the Suebi</a><sup id="cite_ref-auto5_56-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto5-56">[51]</a></sup> was the Germanic post-Roman kingdom, established in the former Roman provinces of <a href="/wiki/Gallaecia" title="Gallaecia">Gallaecia</a>-<a href="/wiki/Lusitania" title="Lusitania">Lusitania</a>. 5th-century vestiges of <a href="/wiki/Alans" title="Alans">Alan</a> settlements were found in <a href="/wiki/Alenquer_Municipality,_Portugal" class="mw-redirect" title="Alenquer Municipality, Portugal">Alenquer</a> (from old Germanic <i>Alan kerk</i>, <i>temple of the Alans</i>), <a href="/wiki/Coimbra" title="Coimbra">Coimbra</a> and Lisbon.<sup id="cite_ref-57" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-57">[52]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>About 410 and during the 6th century it became a formally declared <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_the_Suebi" title="Kingdom of the Suebi">Kingdom of the Suebi</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-auto5_56-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto5-56">[51]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-auto4_55-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto4-55">[50]</a></sup> where king <a href="/wiki/Hermeric" title="Hermeric">Hermeric</a> made a peace treaty with the Gallaecians before passing his domains to <a href="/wiki/Rechila" title="Rechila">Rechila</a>, his son. In 448 Rechila died, leaving the state in expansion to <a href="/wiki/Rechiar" title="Rechiar">Rechiar</a>. After the defeat against the Visigoths, the Suebian kingdom was divided, with Frantan and Aguiulfo ruling simultaneously. Both reigned from 456 to 457, the year in which Maldras (457–459) reunified the kingdom. He was assassinated after a failed Roman-Visigothic conspiracy. Although the conspiracy did not achieve its true purposes, the Suebian Kingdom was again divided between two kings: <a href="/wiki/Frumar" title="Frumar">Frumar</a> (Frumario 459–463) and <a href="/wiki/Remismund" title="Remismund">Remismund</a> (Remismundo, son of <a href="/wiki/Maldras" title="Maldras">Maldras</a>) (459–469) who would re-reunify his father's kingdom in 463. He would be forced to adopt <a href="/wiki/Arianism" title="Arianism">Arianism</a> in 465 due to the Visigoth influence. By the year 500, the <a href="/wiki/Visigothic_Kingdom" title="Visigothic Kingdom">Visigothic Kingdom</a> had been installed in Iberia, it was based in <a href="/wiki/Toledo,_Spain" title="Toledo, Spain">Toledo</a> and advancing westwards. They became a threat to the Suebian rule. After the death of Remismund in 469 a dark period set in, where virtually all written texts and accounts disappear. This period lasted until 550. The only thing known about this period is that <a href="/wiki/Theodemund" title="Theodemund">Theodemund</a> (Teodemundo) most probably ruled the Suebians. The dark period ended with the reign of Karriarico (550–559) who reinstalled <a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church" title="Catholic Church">Catholic Christianity</a> in 550. He was succeeded by <a href="/wiki/Theodemir_(Suebian_king)" title="Theodemir (Suebian king)">Theodemar</a> (559–570) during whose reign the 1st Council of Braga (561) was held. </p> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Ariamirogaliza.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/66/Ariamirogaliza.jpg/220px-Ariamirogaliza.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="176" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/66/Ariamirogaliza.jpg/330px-Ariamirogaliza.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/6/66/Ariamirogaliza.jpg 2x" data-file-width="394" data-file-height="316"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Ariamirogaliza.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Illustrated depiction of the <a href="/wiki/First_Council_of_Braga" title="First Council of Braga">First Council of Braga</a> of 561 CE
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The councils represented an advance in the organization of the territory (paroeciam suevorum (Suebian parish) and the <a href="/wiki/Christianization" title="Christianization">Christianization</a> of the pagan population (<i><a href="/wiki/De_correctione_rusticorum" title="De correctione rusticorum">De correctione rusticorum</a></i>) under the auspices of <a href="/wiki/Saint_Martin_of_Braga" class="mw-redirect" title="Saint Martin of Braga">Saint Martin of Braga</a> (São Martinho de Braga).<sup id="cite_ref-books.google.co.uk_58-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-books.google.co.uk-58">[53]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>After the death of Teodomiro, <a href="/wiki/Miro_(Suebian_king)" title="Miro (Suebian king)">Miro</a> (570–583) was his successor. During his reign, the 2nd Council of Braga (572) was held. The Visigothic civil war began in 577. Miro intervened. Later in 583 he also organized an unsuccessful expedition to reconquer Seville. During the return from this failed operation Miro died. </p>
      <p>In the Suebian Kingdom many internal struggles continued to take place. <a href="/wiki/Eborico" class="mw-redirect" title="Eborico">Eborico</a> (Eurico, 583–584) was dethroned by <a href="/wiki/Andeca" class="mw-redirect" title="Andeca">Andeca</a> (Audeca 584–585), who failed to prevent the Visigothic invasion led by Leovigildo. The Visigothic invasion, completed in 585, turned the once rich and fertile kingdom of the Suebi into the sixth province of the Gothic kingdom.<sup id="cite_ref-59" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-59">[54]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Leovigild" class="mw-redirect" title="Leovigild">Leovigild</a> was crowned King of Gallaecia, Hispania and <a href="/wiki/Gallia_Narbonensis" title="Gallia Narbonensis">Gallia Narbonensis</a>. </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Cvp-00791-109v.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/Cvp-00791-109v.jpg/170px-Cvp-00791-109v.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="223" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/Cvp-00791-109v.jpg/255px-Cvp-00791-109v.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/Cvp-00791-109v.jpg/340px-Cvp-00791-109v.jpg 2x" data-file-width="390" data-file-height="512"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Cvp-00791-109v.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_the_Suebi" title="Kingdom of the Suebi">Suebi King</a> <a href="/wiki/Miro_(Suebian_king)" title="Miro (Suebian king)">Miro</a> and St. <a href="/wiki/Martin_of_Braga" title="Martin of Braga">Martin of Braga</a>; c. 1145
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>For the next 300 years and by the year 700, the entire Iberian Peninsula was ruled by the <a href="/wiki/Visigoths" title="Visigoths">Visigoths</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-60" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-60">[55]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-61" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-61">[56]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-62" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-62">[57]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-63" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-63">[58]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-64" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-64">[59]</a></sup> Under the Visigoths, Gallaecia was a well-defined space governed by a doge of its own. Doges at this time were related to the monarchy acted as princes in all matters. Both 'governors' <a href="/wiki/Wamba_(king)" title="Wamba (king)">Wamba</a> and <a href="/wiki/Wittiza" title="Wittiza">Wittiza</a> (Vitiza) acted as doge (they would later become kings in Toledo). These two became known as the 'vitizians', who headquartered in the northwest and called on the Arab invaders from the South to be their allies in the struggle for power in 711. King <a href="/wiki/Roderic" title="Roderic">Roderic</a> (Rodrigo) was killed while opposing this invasion, thus becoming the last Visigothic king of Iberia. From the various Germanic groups who settled in Western Iberia, the <a href="/wiki/Suebi" title="Suebi">Suebi</a> left the strongest lasting cultural legacy in what is today Portugal, Galicia and western fringes of Asturias.<sup id="cite_ref-65" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-65">[60]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-66" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-66">[61]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-67" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-67">[62]</a></sup> According to Dan Stanislawski, the Portuguese way of living in regions North of the Tagus is mostly inherited from the Suebi, in which small farms prevail, distinct from the large properties of Southern Portugal. Bracara Augusta, the modern city of <a href="/wiki/Braga" title="Braga">Braga</a> and former capital of <a href="/wiki/Gallaecia" title="Gallaecia">Gallaecia</a>, became the capital of the Suebi.<sup id="cite_ref-books.google.co.uk_58-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-books.google.co.uk-58">[53]</a></sup> Apart from cultural and some linguistic traces, the Suebians left the highest Germanic genetic contribution of the Iberian Peninsula in Portugal and Galicia.<sup id="cite_ref-68" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-68">[63]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Paulus_Orosius" class="mw-redirect" title="Paulus Orosius">Orosius</a>, at that time resident in Hispania, shows a rather pacific initial settlement, the newcomers working their lands<sup id="cite_ref-69" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-69">[64]</a></sup> or serving as bodyguards of the locals.<sup id="cite_ref-70" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-70">[65]</a></sup> Another Germanic group that accompanied the Suebi and settled in Gallaecia were the <a href="/wiki/Buri_(Germanic_tribe)" class="mw-redirect" title="Buri (Germanic tribe)">Buri</a>. They settled in the region between the rivers <i><a href="/wiki/C%C3%A1vado_River" title="Cávado River">Cávado</a></i> and <i>Homem</i>, in the area known as <a href="/wiki/Terras_de_Bouro" title="Terras de Bouro">Terras de Bouro</a> (Lands of the Buri).<sup id="cite_ref-71" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-71">[66]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Islamic_period_and_the_Reconquista">Islamic period and the Reconquista</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Portugal&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6" title="Edit section: Islamic period and the Reconquista">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:262px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Al_Andalus_-_2.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/01/Al_Andalus_-_2.png/260px-Al_Andalus_-_2.png" decoding="async" width="260" height="193" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/01/Al_Andalus_-_2.png/390px-Al_Andalus_-_2.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/01/Al_Andalus_-_2.png/520px-Al_Andalus_-_2.png 2x" data-file-width="670" data-file-height="497"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Al_Andalus_-_2.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The Caliphate of Cordoba in the early 10th century
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Today's continental Portugal, along with most of modern Spain, was part of <a href="/wiki/Al-Andalus" title="Al-Andalus">al-Andalus</a> between 726 and 1249, following the <a href="/wiki/Umayyad_Caliphate" title="Umayyad Caliphate">Umayyad Caliphate</a> conquest of the <a href="/wiki/Iberian_Peninsula" title="Iberian Peninsula">Iberian Peninsula</a>. This rule lasted from some decades in the North to five centuries in the South. </p>
      <p>After defeating the <a href="/wiki/Visigoths" title="Visigoths">Visigoths</a> in only a few months, the Umayyad Caliphate started expanding rapidly in the peninsula. Beginning in 726, the land that is now Portugal became part of the vast Umayyad Caliphate's empire of <a href="/wiki/Damascus" title="Damascus">Damascus</a>, which stretched from the <a href="/wiki/Indus" class="mw-redirect" title="Indus">Indus</a> river in the Indian sub-continent up to the South of France, until its collapse in 750. That year the west of the empire gained its independence under <a href="/wiki/Abd-ar-Rahman_I" class="mw-redirect" title="Abd-ar-Rahman I">Abd-ar-Rahman I</a> with the establishment of the <a href="/wiki/Emirate_of_C%C3%B3rdoba" title="Emirate of Córdoba">Emirate of Córdoba</a>. After almost two centuries, the Emirate became the <a href="/wiki/Caliphate_of_C%C3%B3rdoba" title="Caliphate of Córdoba">Caliphate of Córdoba</a> in 929, until its dissolution a century later in 1031 into no less than 23 small kingdoms, called <a href="/wiki/Taifa" title="Taifa">Taifa</a> kingdoms. </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Portugal_DSC04496_-_MERTOLA_(34025572830).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/42/Portugal_DSC04496_-_MERTOLA_%2834025572830%29.jpg/220px-Portugal_DSC04496_-_MERTOLA_%2834025572830%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/42/Portugal_DSC04496_-_MERTOLA_%2834025572830%29.jpg/330px-Portugal_DSC04496_-_MERTOLA_%2834025572830%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/42/Portugal_DSC04496_-_MERTOLA_%2834025572830%29.jpg/440px-Portugal_DSC04496_-_MERTOLA_%2834025572830%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2000" data-file-height="1333"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Portugal_DSC04496_-_MERTOLA_(34025572830).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Statue of <a href="/wiki/Abu-l-Qasim_Ahmad_ibn_al-Husayn_ibn_Qasi" title="Abu-l-Qasim Ahmad ibn al-Husayn ibn Qasi">Ibn Qasi</a> outside the <a href="/wiki/Castle_of_M%C3%A9rtola" class="mw-redirect" title="Castle of Mértola">Castle of Mértola</a>, in the <a href="/wiki/Alentejo" title="Alentejo">Alentejo</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The governors of the taifas each proclaimed themselves <a href="/wiki/Emir" title="Emir">Emir</a> of their provinces and established diplomatic relations with the Christian kingdoms of the north. Most of present-day Portugal fell into the hands of the <a href="/wiki/Taifa_of_Badajoz" title="Taifa of Badajoz">Taifa of Badajoz</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Aftasid_Dynasty" class="mw-redirect" title="Aftasid Dynasty">Aftasid Dynasty</a>, and after a short spell of an ephemeral <a href="/wiki/Taifa_of_Lisbon" title="Taifa of Lisbon">Taifa of Lisbon</a> in 1022, fell under the dominion of the <a href="/wiki/Taifa_of_Seville" title="Taifa of Seville">Taifa of Seville</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Abbadids" class="mw-redirect" title="Abbadids">Abbadids</a> poets. The Taifa period ended with the conquest of the <a href="/wiki/Almoravids" class="mw-redirect" title="Almoravids">Almoravids</a> who came from <a href="/wiki/Morocco" title="Morocco">Morocco</a> in 1086 winning a decisive victory at the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Sagrajas" title="Battle of Sagrajas">Battle of Sagrajas</a>, followed a century later in 1147, after the second period of Taifa, by the <a href="/wiki/Almohads" class="mw-redirect" title="Almohads">Almohads</a>, also from <a href="/wiki/Marrakesh" title="Marrakesh">Marrakesh</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-72" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-72">[67]</a></sup> Al-Andaluz was divided into different districts called <i>Kura</i>. Gharb Al-Andalus at its largest was constituted of ten kuras,<sup id="cite_ref-A._R._Disney,_p.55_73-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-A._R._Disney,_p.55-73">[68]</a></sup> each with a distinct capital and governor. The main cities of the period in Portugal were in the southern half of the country: <a href="/wiki/Beja_(Portugal)" class="mw-redirect" title="Beja (Portugal)">Beja</a>, <a href="/wiki/Silves_Municipality,_Portugal" class="mw-redirect" title="Silves Municipality, Portugal">Silves</a>, <a href="/wiki/Alc%C3%A1cer_do_Sal" title="Alcácer do Sal">Alcácer do Sal</a>, <a href="/wiki/Santar%C3%A9m,_Portugal" title="Santarém, Portugal">Santarém</a> and <a href="/wiki/Lisbon" title="Lisbon">Lisbon</a>. The Muslim population of the region consisted mainly of native Iberian converts to <a href="/wiki/Islam" title="Islam">Islam</a> (the so-called <i><a href="/wiki/Muwallad" title="Muwallad">Muwallad</a></i> or <i>Muladi</i>) and berbers. The Arabs were principally noblemen from <a href="/wiki/Syria" title="Syria">Syria</a> and <a href="/wiki/Oman" title="Oman">Oman</a>; and though few in numbers, they constituted the elite of the population. The <a href="/wiki/Berbers" title="Berbers">Berbers</a> were originally from the <a href="/wiki/Rif" title="Rif">Rif</a> and <a href="/wiki/Atlas_mountains" class="mw-redirect" title="Atlas mountains">Atlas mountains</a> region of North Africa and were nomads. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="County_of_Portugal">County of Portugal</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Portugal&amp;action=edit&amp;section=7" title="Edit section: County of Portugal">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/County_of_Portugal" title="County of Portugal">County of Portugal</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Porto_April_2019-18.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a9/Porto_April_2019-18.jpg/180px-Porto_April_2019-18.jpg" decoding="async" width="180" height="288" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a9/Porto_April_2019-18.jpg/270px-Porto_April_2019-18.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a9/Porto_April_2019-18.jpg/360px-Porto_April_2019-18.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4342" data-file-height="6951"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Porto_April_2019-18.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>A statue of Count <a href="/wiki/V%C3%ADmara_Peres" title="Vímara Peres">Vímara Peres</a>, first <a href="/wiki/County_of_Portugal" title="County of Portugal">Count of Portugal</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>An Asturian Visigothic noble named <a href="/wiki/Pelagius_of_Asturias" title="Pelagius of Asturias">Pelagius of Asturias</a> in 718 was elected leader<sup id="cite_ref-74" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-74">[69]</a></sup> by many of the ousted <a href="/wiki/Visigoth" class="mw-redirect" title="Visigoth">Visigoth</a> nobles. Pelagius called for the remnant of the Christian Visigothic armies to rebel against the Moors and regroup in the unconquered northern Asturian highlands, better known today as the <a href="/wiki/Cantabrian_Mountains" title="Cantabrian Mountains">Cantabrian Mountains</a>, in what is today the small mountain region in North-western <a href="/wiki/Spain" title="Spain">Spain</a>, adjacent to the <a href="/wiki/Bay_of_Biscay" title="Bay of Biscay">Bay of Biscay</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-V._Livermore,_1969_pp._32-33_75-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-V._Livermore,_1969_pp._32-33-75">[70]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Pelagius' plan was to use the Cantabrian mountains as a place of refuge and protection from the invading Moors. He then aimed to regroup the Iberian Peninsula's Christian armies and use the Cantabrian mountains as a springboard from which to regain their lands. In the process, after defeating the Moors in the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Covadonga" title="Battle of Covadonga">Battle of Covadonga</a> in 722, Pelagius was proclaimed king, thus founding the Christian <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Asturias" title="Kingdom of Asturias">Kingdom of Asturias</a> and starting the war of Christian reconquest known in <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_language" title="Portuguese language">Portuguese</a> as the <i><a href="/wiki/Reconquista" title="Reconquista">Reconquista Cristã</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-V._Livermore,_1969_pp._32-33_75-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-V._Livermore,_1969_pp._32-33-75">[70]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>At the end of the 9th century, the region of Portugal, between the rivers Minho and Douro, was reconquered from the Moors by the nobleman and knight <a href="/wiki/V%C3%ADmara_Peres" title="Vímara Peres">Vímara Peres</a> on the orders of King <a href="/wiki/Alfonso_III_of_Asturias" title="Alfonso III of Asturias">Alfonso III of Asturias</a>. Finding that the region had previously had two major cities – <a href="/wiki/Portus_Cale" title="Portus Cale">Portus Cale</a> in the coast and <a href="/wiki/Braga" title="Braga">Braga</a> in the interior, with many towns that were now deserted – he decided to repopulate and rebuild them with Portuguese and Galician refugees and other Christians.<sup id="cite_ref-QuidNovi_76-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-QuidNovi-76">[71]</a></sup> Apart from the Arabs from the South, the coastal regions in the North were also attacked by <a href="/wiki/Normans" title="Normans">Norman</a> and <a href="/wiki/Viking" class="mw-redirect" title="Viking">Viking</a><sup id="cite_ref-77" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-77">[72]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-78" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-78">[73]</a></sup> raiders mainly from 844. The last great invasion, through the <a href="/wiki/Minho_(river)" title="Minho (river)">Minho (river)</a>, ended with the defeat of <a href="/wiki/Olaf_II_Haraldsson" class="mw-redirect" title="Olaf II Haraldsson">Olaf II Haraldsson</a> in 1014 against the Galician nobility who also stopped further advances into the County of Portugal. </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Henri_de_Bourgogne_re%C3%A7oit_l%27investiture_du_comt%C3%A9_de_Portugal,_1094_(Claude_Jacquand,_dit_Claudius;_1841).png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d8/Henri_de_Bourgogne_re%C3%A7oit_l%27investiture_du_comt%C3%A9_de_Portugal%2C_1094_%28Claude_Jacquand%2C_dit_Claudius%3B_1841%29.png/220px-Henri_de_Bourgogne_re%C3%A7oit_l%27investiture_du_comt%C3%A9_de_Portugal%2C_1094_%28Claude_Jacquand%2C_dit_Claudius%3B_1841%29.png" decoding="async" width="220" height="202" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d8/Henri_de_Bourgogne_re%C3%A7oit_l%27investiture_du_comt%C3%A9_de_Portugal%2C_1094_%28Claude_Jacquand%2C_dit_Claudius%3B_1841%29.png/330px-Henri_de_Bourgogne_re%C3%A7oit_l%27investiture_du_comt%C3%A9_de_Portugal%2C_1094_%28Claude_Jacquand%2C_dit_Claudius%3B_1841%29.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d8/Henri_de_Bourgogne_re%C3%A7oit_l%27investiture_du_comt%C3%A9_de_Portugal%2C_1094_%28Claude_Jacquand%2C_dit_Claudius%3B_1841%29.png/440px-Henri_de_Bourgogne_re%C3%A7oit_l%27investiture_du_comt%C3%A9_de_Portugal%2C_1094_%28Claude_Jacquand%2C_dit_Claudius%3B_1841%29.png 2x" data-file-width="1234" data-file-height="1135"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Henri_de_Bourgogne_re%C3%A7oit_l%27investiture_du_comt%C3%A9_de_Portugal,_1094_(Claude_Jacquand,_dit_Claudius;_1841).png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Alfonso_VI_of_Le%C3%B3n" class="mw-redirect" title="Alfonso VI of León">Alfonso VI of León</a> investing <a href="/wiki/Henry,_Count_of_Portugal" title="Henry, Count of Portugal">Henry, Count of Portugal</a>, in 1093
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Count Vímara Peres<sup id="cite_ref-79" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-79">[74]</a></sup> organized the region he had reconquered, and elevated it to the status of <a href="/wiki/County" title="County">County</a>, naming it the <a href="/wiki/County_of_Portugal" title="County of Portugal">County of Portugal</a> after the region's major port city – <i>Portus Cale</i> or modern <a href="/wiki/Porto" title="Porto">Porto</a>. One of the first cities Vimara Peres founded at this time is Vimaranes, known today as <a href="/wiki/Guimar%C3%A3es" title="Guimarães">Guimarães</a> – the "birthplace of the Portuguese nation" or the "cradle city" (Cidade Berço in Portuguese).<sup id="cite_ref-QuidNovi_76-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-QuidNovi-76">[71]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>After annexing the County of Portugal into one of the several counties that made up the <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Asturias" title="Kingdom of Asturias">Kingdom of Asturias</a>, King <a href="/wiki/Alfonso_III_of_Asturias" title="Alfonso III of Asturias">Alfonso III of Asturias</a> knighted Vímara Peres, in 868, as the First Count of Portus Cale (Portugal). The region became known as <i>Portucale</i>, <i>Portugale</i>, and simultaneously <i>Portugália</i> – the <a href="/wiki/County_of_Portugal" title="County of Portugal">County of Portugal</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-QuidNovi_76-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-QuidNovi-76">[71]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Later the Kingdom of Asturias was divided into a number of Christian Kingdoms in Northern Iberia due to dynastic divisions of inheritance among the king's offspring. With the forced abdication of <a href="/wiki/Alfonso_III_of_Asturias" title="Alfonso III of Asturias">Alfonso III "the Great" of Asturias</a> by his sons in 910, the Kingdom of Asturias split into three separate kingdoms. The three kingdoms were eventually reunited in 924 under the crown of <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Le%C3%B3n" title="Kingdom of León">León</a>. </p>
      <p>In 1093, <a href="/wiki/Alfonso_VI_of_Le%C3%B3n" class="mw-redirect" title="Alfonso VI of León">Alfonso VI of León</a> bestowed the county to <a href="/wiki/Henry,_Count_of_Portugal" title="Henry, Count of Portugal">Henry of Burgundy</a> and married him to his illegitimate daughter, <a href="/wiki/Teresa_of_Le%C3%B3n,_Countess_of_Portugal" class="mw-redirect" title="Teresa of León, Countess of Portugal">Teresa of León</a>, for his role in reconquering the land from Moors. Henry based his newly formed county in Bracara Augusta (modern <a href="/wiki/Braga" title="Braga">Braga</a>), capital city of the ancient Roman province, and also previous capital of several kingdoms over the first millennia. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Afonsine_era">Afonsine era</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Portugal&amp;action=edit&amp;section=8" title="Edit section: Afonsine era">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Portugal_in_the_Middle_Ages" title="Portugal in the Middle Ages">Portugal in the Middle Ages</a> and <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_House_of_Burgundy" title="Portuguese House of Burgundy">Portuguese House of Burgundy</a>
      </div> 
      <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r978413945/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">
      <div class="thumb tmulti tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:204px;max-width:204px">
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px">
          <div class="thumbimage">
           <a href="/wiki/File:BatalhaOurique.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9c/BatalhaOurique.jpg/200px-BatalhaOurique.jpg" decoding="async" width="200" height="118" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9c/BatalhaOurique.jpg/300px-BatalhaOurique.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9c/BatalhaOurique.jpg/400px-BatalhaOurique.jpg 2x" data-file-width="460" data-file-height="271"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           The <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Ourique" title="Battle of Ourique">Battle of Ourique</a>, 1139
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px">
          <div class="thumbimage">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Siege_of_Lisbon_by_Roque_Gameiro.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1e/Siege_of_Lisbon_by_Roque_Gameiro.jpg/200px-Siege_of_Lisbon_by_Roque_Gameiro.jpg" decoding="async" width="200" height="131" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1e/Siege_of_Lisbon_by_Roque_Gameiro.jpg/300px-Siege_of_Lisbon_by_Roque_Gameiro.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1e/Siege_of_Lisbon_by_Roque_Gameiro.jpg/400px-Siege_of_Lisbon_by_Roque_Gameiro.jpg 2x" data-file-width="972" data-file-height="639"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           The <a href="/wiki/Siege_of_Lisbon" title="Siege of Lisbon">Siege of Lisbon</a>, 1147
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>On 24 June 1128, the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_S%C3%A3o_Mamede" title="Battle of São Mamede">Battle of São Mamede</a> occurred near <a href="/wiki/Guimar%C3%A3es" title="Guimarães">Guimarães</a>. <a href="/wiki/Afonso_I_of_Portugal" title="Afonso I of Portugal">Afonso Henriques</a>, Count of Portugal, defeated his mother <a href="/wiki/Teresa,_Countess_of_Portugal" class="mw-redirect" title="Teresa, Countess of Portugal">Countess Teresa</a> and her lover <a href="/wiki/Fern%C3%A3o_Peres_de_Trava" class="mw-redirect" title="Fernão Peres de Trava">Fernão Peres de Trava</a>, thereby establishing himself as sole leader. Afonso then turned his arms against the Moors in the south. </p>
      <p>Afonso's campaigns were successful and, on 25 July 1139, he obtained an overwhelming victory in the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Ourique" title="Battle of Ourique">Battle of Ourique</a>, and straight after was unanimously proclaimed <a href="/wiki/King_of_Portugal" class="mw-redirect" title="King of Portugal">King of Portugal</a> by his soldiers. This is traditionally taken as the occasion when the County of Portugal, as a fief of the Kingdom of León, was transformed into the independent <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Portugal" title="Kingdom of Portugal">Kingdom of Portugal</a>. </p>
      <p>Afonso then established the first of the <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_Cortes" title="Portuguese Cortes">Portuguese Cortes</a> at <a href="/wiki/Lamego" title="Lamego">Lamego</a>, where he was crowned by the Archbishop of Braga, though the validity of the Cortes of Lamego has been disputed and called a myth created during the <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_Restoration_War" title="Portuguese Restoration War">Portuguese Restoration War</a>. Afonso was recognized in 1143 by King <a href="/wiki/Alfonso_VII_of_Le%C3%B3n" class="mw-redirect" title="Alfonso VII of León">Alfonso VII of León</a>, and in 1179 by <a href="/wiki/Pope_Alexander_III" title="Pope Alexander III">Pope Alexander III</a>. </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:D._Afonso_Henriques_-_The_Portuguese_Genealogy_(Genealogia_dos_Reis_de_Portugal).png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ee/D._Afonso_Henriques_-_The_Portuguese_Genealogy_%28Genealogia_dos_Reis_de_Portugal%29.png/180px-D._Afonso_Henriques_-_The_Portuguese_Genealogy_%28Genealogia_dos_Reis_de_Portugal%29.png" decoding="async" width="180" height="288" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ee/D._Afonso_Henriques_-_The_Portuguese_Genealogy_%28Genealogia_dos_Reis_de_Portugal%29.png/270px-D._Afonso_Henriques_-_The_Portuguese_Genealogy_%28Genealogia_dos_Reis_de_Portugal%29.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ee/D._Afonso_Henriques_-_The_Portuguese_Genealogy_%28Genealogia_dos_Reis_de_Portugal%29.png/360px-D._Afonso_Henriques_-_The_Portuguese_Genealogy_%28Genealogia_dos_Reis_de_Portugal%29.png 2x" data-file-width="1132" data-file-height="1812"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:D._Afonso_Henriques_-_The_Portuguese_Genealogy_(Genealogia_dos_Reis_de_Portugal).png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Afonso_Henriques" class="mw-redirect" title="Afonso Henriques">Afonso Henriques</a> was the last <a href="/wiki/Count_of_Portugal" class="mw-redirect" title="Count of Portugal">Count of Portugal</a> and the first <a href="/wiki/List_of_Portuguese_monarchs" title="List of Portuguese monarchs">King of Portugal</a> after winning the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Ourique" title="Battle of Ourique">Battle of Ourique</a> in 1139. (<i>Depicted in a 1530s <a href="/wiki/Illuminated_manuscript" title="Illuminated manuscript">illuminated manuscript</a></i>)
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>During the <a href="/wiki/Reconquista" title="Reconquista">Reconquista</a> period, Christians reconquered the Iberian Peninsula from <a href="/wiki/Moors" title="Moors">Moorish</a> domination. Afonso Henriques and his successors, aided by military <a href="/wiki/Christian_monasticism" title="Christian monasticism">monastic orders</a>, pushed southward to drive out the Moors.
