At this time, Portugal covered about half of its present area. In 1249, the Reconquista ended with the capture of the <a href="/wiki/Algarve" title="Algarve">Algarve</a> and complete expulsion of the last Moorish settlements on the southern coast, giving Portugal its present-day borders, with minor exceptions. </p>
      <p>In one of these situations of conflict with the <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Castile" title="Kingdom of Castile">kingdom of Castile</a>, <a href="/wiki/Dinis_I_of_Portugal" class="mw-redirect" title="Dinis I of Portugal">Dinis I of Portugal</a> signed with the king <a href="/wiki/Fernando_IV_of_Castile" class="mw-redirect" title="Fernando IV of Castile">Fernando IV of Castile</a> (who was represented, when a minor, by his mother the queen <a href="/wiki/Maria_de_Molina" class="mw-redirect" title="Maria de Molina">Maria de Molina</a>) the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Alca%C3%B1ices_(1297)" class="mw-redirect" title="Treaty of Alcañices (1297)">Treaty of Alcañices (1297)</a>, which stipulated that Portugal abolished agreed treaties against the kingdom of Castile for supporting the infant <a href="/wiki/Juan_de_Castilla" title="Juan de Castilla">Juan de Castilla</a>. This treaty established among other things the border demarcation between the kingdom of Portugal and the kingdom of Leon, where the disputed town of <a href="/wiki/Olivenza" title="Olivenza">Olivenza</a> was included. </p>
      <p>The reigns of <a href="/wiki/Denis_I_of_Portugal" class="mw-redirect" title="Denis I of Portugal">Dinis I</a> (Denis I), <a href="/wiki/Afonso_IV_of_Portugal" title="Afonso IV of Portugal">Afonso IV</a> (Alphons IV), and <a href="/wiki/Peter_I_of_Portugal" title="Peter I of Portugal">Pedro I</a> (Peter I) for the most part saw peace with the Christian kingdoms of Iberia. </p>
      <p>In 1348 and 1349 Portugal, like the rest of Europe, was devastated by the <a href="/wiki/Black_Death" title="Black Death">Black Death</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-80" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-80">[75]</a></sup> In 1373, Portugal made an <a href="/wiki/Anglo-Portuguese_Alliance" title="Anglo-Portuguese Alliance">alliance with England</a>, which is the longest-standing alliance in the world. Over time, this went far beyond geo-political and military cooperation (protecting both nations' interests in Africa, the Americas and Asia against French, Spanish and Dutch rivals) and maintained strong trade and cultural ties between the two old European allies. In the <a href="/wiki/Oporto" class="mw-redirect" title="Oporto">Oporto</a> region, in particular, there is visible English influence to this day. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Joanine_era_and_Age_of_Discoveries">Joanine era and Age of Discoveries</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Portugal&amp;action=edit&amp;section=9" title="Edit section: Joanine era and Age of Discoveries">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_inventions" title="Portuguese inventions">Portuguese inventions</a>, <a href="/wiki/Evolution_of_the_Portuguese_Empire" title="Evolution of the Portuguese Empire">Evolution of the Portuguese Empire</a>, <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_discovery_of_the_sea_route_to_India" title="Portuguese discovery of the sea route to India">Portuguese discovery of the sea route to India</a>, <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_Empire" title="Portuguese Empire">Portuguese Empire</a>, <a href="/wiki/Spice_trade" title="Spice trade">Spice trade</a>, <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_India_Armadas" title="Portuguese India Armadas">Portuguese India Armadas</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_presence_in_Asia" title="Portuguese presence in Asia">Portuguese presence in Asia</a>
      </div> 
      <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r978413945/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">
      <div class="thumb tmulti tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:204px;max-width:204px">
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px">
          <div class="thumbimage">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Batalha_de_Aljubarrota_02.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b3/Batalha_de_Aljubarrota_02.jpg/200px-Batalha_de_Aljubarrota_02.jpg" decoding="async" width="200" height="117" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b3/Batalha_de_Aljubarrota_02.jpg/300px-Batalha_de_Aljubarrota_02.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b3/Batalha_de_Aljubarrota_02.jpg/400px-Batalha_de_Aljubarrota_02.jpg 2x" data-file-width="5574" data-file-height="3250"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           <a href="/wiki/John_I_of_Portugal" title="John I of Portugal">John I of Portugal</a>'s victory at the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Aljubarrota" title="Battle of Aljubarrota">Battle of Aljubarrota</a> secured the <a href="/wiki/House_of_Aviz" title="House of Aviz">House of Aviz</a>'s claim to the throne.
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px">
          <div class="thumbimage">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Batalha_009_(4617766169).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a3/Batalha_009_%284617766169%29.jpg/200px-Batalha_009_%284617766169%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="200" height="134" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a3/Batalha_009_%284617766169%29.jpg/300px-Batalha_009_%284617766169%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a3/Batalha_009_%284617766169%29.jpg/400px-Batalha_009_%284617766169%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1000" data-file-height="671"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           <a href="/wiki/Batalha_Monastery" title="Batalha Monastery">Batalha Monastery</a> was erected by King John I to commemorate his victory in the <a href="/wiki/1383%E2%80%9385_Portuguese_interregnum" class="mw-redirect" title="1383–85 Portuguese interregnum">1383–1385 Crisis</a> against Castile.
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>In 1383, <a href="/wiki/John_I_of_Castile" title="John I of Castile">John I of Castile</a>, husband of <a href="/wiki/Beatrice_of_Portugal" title="Beatrice of Portugal">Beatrice of Portugal</a> and son-in-law of <a href="/wiki/Ferdinand_I_of_Portugal" title="Ferdinand I of Portugal">Ferdinand I of Portugal</a>, claimed the throne of Portugal. A faction of petty noblemen and commoners, led by <a href="/wiki/John_I_of_Portugal" title="John I of Portugal">John of Aviz</a> (later King John I of Portugal) and commanded by General <a href="/wiki/Nuno_%C3%81lvares_Pereira" title="Nuno Álvares Pereira">Nuno Álvares Pereira</a> defeated the Castilians in the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Aljubarrota" title="Battle of Aljubarrota">Battle of Aljubarrota</a>. With this battle, the <a href="/wiki/House_of_Aviz" title="House of Aviz">House of Aviz</a> became the ruling house of Portugal. </p>
      <p>Portugal spearheaded European exploration of the world and the <a href="/wiki/Age_of_Discovery" title="Age of Discovery">Age of Discovery</a>. Prince <a href="/wiki/Henry_the_Navigator" class="mw-redirect" title="Henry the Navigator">Henry the Navigator</a>, son of King <a href="/wiki/John_I_of_Portugal" title="John I of Portugal">John I of Portugal</a>, became the main sponsor and patron of this endeavour. During this period, Portugal explored the <a href="/wiki/Atlantic_Ocean" title="Atlantic Ocean">Atlantic Ocean</a>, discovering the Atlantic archipelagos the <a href="/wiki/Azores" title="Azores">Azores</a>, <a href="/wiki/Madeira" title="Madeira">Madeira</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_Cape_Verde" title="Portuguese Cape Verde">Cape Verde</a>; explored the African coast; colonized selected areas of Africa; discovered an eastern <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_India_Armadas" title="Portuguese India Armadas">route to India</a> via the <a href="/wiki/Cape_of_Good_Hope" title="Cape of Good Hope">Cape of Good Hope</a>; <a href="/wiki/Colonial_Brazil#Discovery_and_early_exploitation" title="Colonial Brazil">discovered Brazil</a>, explored the <a href="/wiki/Indian_Ocean" title="Indian Ocean">Indian Ocean</a>, established trading routes throughout most of southern Asia; and sent the first direct European maritime trade and diplomatic missions to <a href="/wiki/Jorge_%C3%81lvares" title="Jorge Álvares">China</a> and <a href="/wiki/Nanban_trade" title="Nanban trade">Japan</a>. </p>
      <p>In 1415, Portugal acquired the first of its overseas colonies by conquering <a href="/wiki/Ceuta" title="Ceuta">Ceuta</a>, the first prosperous Islamic trade centre in North Africa. There followed the first discoveries in the Atlantic: <a href="/wiki/Madeira" title="Madeira">Madeira</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Azores" title="Azores">Azores</a>, which led to the first <a href="/wiki/Colonialism" title="Colonialism">colonization</a> movements. </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Henry_the_Navigator1.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/02/Henry_the_Navigator1.jpg/170px-Henry_the_Navigator1.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="217" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/02/Henry_the_Navigator1.jpg/255px-Henry_the_Navigator1.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/02/Henry_the_Navigator1.jpg/340px-Henry_the_Navigator1.jpg 2x" data-file-width="783" data-file-height="1000"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Henry_the_Navigator1.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Henry_the_Navigator" class="mw-redirect" title="Henry the Navigator">Henry the Navigator</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Throughout the 15th century, <a href="/wiki/European_exploration_of_Africa#Portuguese" title="European exploration of Africa">Portuguese explorers</a> sailed the coast of Africa, establishing trading posts for <a href="/wiki/Economic_history_of_Portugal#Expansion_of_the_Portuguese_empire_(15th_and_16th_centuries)" title="Economic history of Portugal">several common types of tradable commodities at the time</a>, ranging from <a href="/wiki/Gold" title="Gold">gold</a> to <a href="/wiki/Slavery" title="Slavery">slaves</a>, as they looked for a route to India and its <a href="/wiki/Spice" title="Spice">spices</a>, which were coveted in Europe. </p>
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Tordesillas" title="Treaty of Tordesillas">Treaty of Tordesillas</a>, intended to resolve the dispute that had been created following the return of <a href="/wiki/Christopher_Columbus" title="Christopher Columbus">Christopher Columbus</a>, was made by <a href="/wiki/Pope_Alexander_VI" title="Pope Alexander VI">Pope Alexander VI</a>, the mediator between Portugal and Spain. It was signed on 7 June 1494, and divided the newly discovered lands outside Europe between the two countries along a meridian 370 leagues west of the <a href="/wiki/Cape_Verde" title="Cape Verde">Cape Verde</a> islands (off the west coast of Africa). </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Ignoto_portoghese,_ritratto_di_un_cavaliere_dell%27ordine_di_cristo,_1525-50_ca._02.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/Ignoto_portoghese%2C_ritratto_di_un_cavaliere_dell%27ordine_di_cristo%2C_1525-50_ca._02.jpg/170px-Ignoto_portoghese%2C_ritratto_di_un_cavaliere_dell%27ordine_di_cristo%2C_1525-50_ca._02.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="231" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/Ignoto_portoghese%2C_ritratto_di_un_cavaliere_dell%27ordine_di_cristo%2C_1525-50_ca._02.jpg/255px-Ignoto_portoghese%2C_ritratto_di_un_cavaliere_dell%27ordine_di_cristo%2C_1525-50_ca._02.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/Ignoto_portoghese%2C_ritratto_di_un_cavaliere_dell%27ordine_di_cristo%2C_1525-50_ca._02.jpg/340px-Ignoto_portoghese%2C_ritratto_di_un_cavaliere_dell%27ordine_di_cristo%2C_1525-50_ca._02.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1920" data-file-height="2609"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Ignoto_portoghese,_ritratto_di_un_cavaliere_dell%27ordine_di_cristo,_1525-50_ca._02.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Vasco_da_Gama" title="Vasco da Gama">Vasco da Gama</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>In 1498, <a href="/wiki/Vasco_da_Gama" title="Vasco da Gama">Vasco da Gama</a> accomplished what <a href="/wiki/Christopher_Columbus" title="Christopher Columbus">Columbus</a> set out for and became the first European to reach <a href="/wiki/India" title="India">India</a> by sea, bringing <a href="/wiki/Economic_history_of_Portugal" title="Economic history of Portugal">economic prosperity to Portugal</a> and its population of 1.7&nbsp;million residents, and helping to start the <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_Renaissance" title="Portuguese Renaissance">Portuguese Renaissance</a>. In 1500, the Portuguese explorer <a href="/wiki/Gaspar_Corte-Real" title="Gaspar Corte-Real">Gaspar Corte-Real</a> reached what is now <a href="/wiki/Canada" title="Canada">Canada</a> and founded the town of <a href="/wiki/Portugal_Cove-St._Philip%27s" class="mw-redirect" title="Portugal Cove-St. Philip's">Portugal Cove-St. Philip's</a>, <a href="/wiki/Newfoundland_and_Labrador" title="Newfoundland and Labrador">Newfoundland and Labrador</a>, long before the French and English in the 17th century, and being just one of many <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_colonization_of_the_Americas" title="Portuguese colonization of the Americas">Portuguese colonizations of the Americas</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-81" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-81">[76]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-82" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-82">[77]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-83" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-83">[78]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In 1500, <a href="/wiki/Pedro_%C3%81lvares_Cabral" title="Pedro Álvares Cabral">Pedro Álvares Cabral</a> discovered <a href="/wiki/Brazil" title="Brazil">Brazil</a> and claimed it for Portugal.<sup id="cite_ref-84" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-84">[79]</a></sup> Ten years later, <a href="/wiki/Afonso_de_Albuquerque" title="Afonso de Albuquerque">Afonso de Albuquerque</a> conquered <a href="/wiki/Goa" title="Goa">Goa</a> in India, <a href="/wiki/Muscat,_Oman" class="mw-redirect" title="Muscat, Oman">Muscat</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ormuz" class="mw-redirect" title="Ormuz">Ormuz</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Persian_Strait" class="mw-redirect" title="Persian Strait">Persian Strait</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Malacca" title="Malacca">Malacca</a>, now a <a href="/wiki/States_of_Malaysia" class="mw-redirect" title="States of Malaysia">state</a> in Malaysia. Thus, the Portuguese empire held dominion over commerce in the <a href="/wiki/Indian_Ocean" title="Indian Ocean">Indian Ocean</a> and South Atlantic. Portuguese sailors set out to reach Eastern Asia by sailing eastward from Europe, landing in such places as Taiwan, Japan, the island of <a href="/wiki/Timor" title="Timor">Timor</a>, and in the <a href="/wiki/Moluccas" class="mw-redirect" title="Moluccas">Moluccas</a>. </p>
      <p>Although for a long period it was believed the <a href="/wiki/Dutch_people" title="Dutch people">Dutch</a> were the first Europeans to arrive in Australia, there is also some evidence that the <a href="/wiki/Theory_of_the_Portuguese_discovery_of_Australia" title="Theory of the Portuguese discovery of Australia">Portuguese may have discovered Australia</a> in 1521.<sup id="cite_ref-85" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-85">[80]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-86" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-86">[81]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-87" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-87">[82]</a></sup> From 1519 to 1522, <a href="/wiki/Ferdinand_Magellan" title="Ferdinand Magellan">Ferdinand Magellan</a> (Fernão de Magalhães) organized a Spanish expedition to the <a href="/wiki/East_Indies" title="East Indies">East Indies</a> which resulted in the first <a href="/wiki/Circumnavigation" title="Circumnavigation">circumnavigation</a> of the globe. Magellan never made it back to Europe as he was murdered by natives in the <a href="/wiki/Philippines" title="Philippines">Philippines</a> in 1521. </p>
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Zaragoza" title="Treaty of Zaragoza">Treaty of Zaragoza</a>, signed on 22 April 1529 between Portugal and Spain, specified the anti-meridian to the line of demarcation specified in the Treaty of Tordesillas. </p>
      <p>All these factors made Portugal one of the world's major economic, military, and political powers from the 15th century until the late 16th century. </p> 
      <h3><span id="Iberian_Union.2C_Restoration_and_early_Brigantine_era"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Iberian_Union,_Restoration_and_early_Brigantine_era">Iberian Union, Restoration and early Brigantine era</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Portugal&amp;action=edit&amp;section=10" title="Edit section: Iberian Union, Restoration and early Brigantine era">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Iberian_Union" title="Iberian Union">Iberian Union</a>, <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_Restoration_War" title="Portuguese Restoration War">Portuguese Restoration War</a>, and <a href="/wiki/House_of_Braganza" title="House of Braganza">House of Braganza</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:292px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:All_areas_of_the_world_that_were_once_part_of_the_Portuguese_Empire.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/33/All_areas_of_the_world_that_were_once_part_of_the_Portuguese_Empire.png/290px-All_areas_of_the_world_that_were_once_part_of_the_Portuguese_Empire.png" decoding="async" width="290" height="127" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/33/All_areas_of_the_world_that_were_once_part_of_the_Portuguese_Empire.png/435px-All_areas_of_the_world_that_were_once_part_of_the_Portuguese_Empire.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/33/All_areas_of_the_world_that_were_once_part_of_the_Portuguese_Empire.png/580px-All_areas_of_the_world_that_were_once_part_of_the_Portuguese_Empire.png 2x" data-file-width="1425" data-file-height="625"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:All_areas_of_the_world_that_were_once_part_of_the_Portuguese_Empire.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Areas across the world that were, at one point in their history, part of the <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_Empire" title="Portuguese Empire">Portuguese Empire</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Portugal voluntarily entered a dynastic union between 1580 and 1640. This occurred because the last two kings of the <a href="/wiki/House_of_Aviz" title="House of Aviz">House of Aviz</a>&nbsp;– King <a href="/wiki/Sebastian_of_Portugal" title="Sebastian of Portugal">Sebastian</a>, who died in the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Alc%C3%A1cer_Quibir" title="Battle of Alcácer Quibir">battle of Alcácer Quibir</a> in <a href="/wiki/Morocco" title="Morocco">Morocco</a>, and his great-uncle and successor, King-<a href="/wiki/Cardinal_(Catholic_Church)" title="Cardinal (Catholic Church)">Cardinal</a> <a href="/wiki/Henry_I_of_Portugal" class="mw-redirect" title="Henry I of Portugal">Henry of Portugal</a>&nbsp;– both died without heirs, resulting in the <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_succession_crisis_of_1580" title="Portuguese succession crisis of 1580">Portuguese succession crisis of 1580</a>. </p>
      <p>Subsequently, <a href="/wiki/Philip_II_of_Spain" title="Philip II of Spain">Philip II of Spain</a> claimed the throne and was accepted as Philip I of Portugal. Portugal did not lose its formal independence, briefly forming a <a href="/wiki/Iberian_Union" title="Iberian Union">union</a> of kingdoms. At this time Spain was a <a href="/wiki/Geographic_region" class="mw-redirect" title="Geographic region">geographic territory</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-88" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-88">[83]</a></sup> The joining of the two crowns deprived Portugal of an independent foreign policy and led to its involvement in the <a href="/wiki/Eighty_Years%27_War" title="Eighty Years' War">Eighty Years' War</a> between Spain and the <a href="/wiki/Netherlands" title="Netherlands">Netherlands</a>. </p>
      <p>War led to a deterioration of the relations with <a href="/wiki/Anglo-Portuguese_Alliance" title="Anglo-Portuguese Alliance">Portugal's oldest ally, England</a>, and the loss of <a href="/wiki/Ormus" title="Ormus">Hormuz</a>, a strategic trading post located between <a href="/wiki/Iran" title="Iran">Iran</a> and <a href="/wiki/Oman" title="Oman">Oman</a>. From 1595 to 1663 the <a href="/wiki/Dutch-Portuguese_War" class="mw-redirect" title="Dutch-Portuguese War">Dutch-Portuguese War</a> primarily involved the Dutch companies invading many Portuguese <a href="/wiki/Colonies" class="mw-redirect" title="Colonies">colonies</a> and commercial interests in Brazil, Africa, India and the Far East, resulting in the loss of the Portuguese Indian sea trade monopoly. In 1640, <a href="/wiki/John_IV_of_Portugal" title="John IV of Portugal">John IV of Portugal</a> spearheaded an uprising backed by disgruntled nobles and was proclaimed king. The <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_Restoration_War" title="Portuguese Restoration War">Portuguese Restoration War</a> ended the sixty-year period of the <a href="/wiki/Iberian_Union" title="Iberian Union">Iberian Union</a> under the <a href="/wiki/House_of_Habsburg" title="House of Habsburg">House of Habsburg</a>. This was the beginning of the <a href="/wiki/House_of_Braganza" title="House of Braganza">House of Braganza</a>, which reigned in Portugal until 1910. </p> 
      <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r978413945/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">
      <div class="thumb tmulti tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:204px;max-width:204px">
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px">
          <div class="thumbimage">
           <a href="/wiki/File:John_V_of_Portugal_Pompeo_Batoni.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/12/John_V_of_Portugal_Pompeo_Batoni.jpg/200px-John_V_of_Portugal_Pompeo_Batoni.jpg" decoding="async" width="200" height="255" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/12/John_V_of_Portugal_Pompeo_Batoni.jpg/300px-John_V_of_Portugal_Pompeo_Batoni.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/12/John_V_of_Portugal_Pompeo_Batoni.jpg/400px-John_V_of_Portugal_Pompeo_Batoni.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1465" data-file-height="1867"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           King <a href="/wiki/John_V_of_Portugal" title="John V of Portugal">John V</a> patronized numerous artistic works, earning him the epithet of the <i>Portuguese Sun King</i>.
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px">
          <div class="thumbimage">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Europa_-_Portugal_-_Lisboa_-_Mafra_-_Palacio.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c1/Europa_-_Portugal_-_Lisboa_-_Mafra_-_Palacio.jpg/200px-Europa_-_Portugal_-_Lisboa_-_Mafra_-_Palacio.jpg" decoding="async" width="200" height="133" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c1/Europa_-_Portugal_-_Lisboa_-_Mafra_-_Palacio.jpg/300px-Europa_-_Portugal_-_Lisboa_-_Mafra_-_Palacio.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c1/Europa_-_Portugal_-_Lisboa_-_Mafra_-_Palacio.jpg/400px-Europa_-_Portugal_-_Lisboa_-_Mafra_-_Palacio.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4470" data-file-height="2980"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           <a href="/wiki/Mafra_Palace" class="mw-redirect" title="Mafra Palace">Royal Palatial Complex of Mafra</a>, a <a href="/wiki/UNESCO_World_Heritage_site" class="mw-redirect" title="UNESCO World Heritage site">UNESCO World Heritage site</a>.
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>King John IV's eldest son came to reign as <a href="/wiki/Afonso_VI_of_Portugal" title="Afonso VI of Portugal">Afonso VI</a>, however his physical and mental disabilities left him overpowered by <a href="/wiki/Lu%C3%ADs_de_Vasconcelos_e_Sousa,_3rd_Count_of_Castelo_Melhor" title="Luís de Vasconcelos e Sousa, 3rd Count of Castelo Melhor">Luís de Vasconcelos e Sousa, 3rd Count of Castelo Melhor</a>. In a palace coup organized by the King's wife, <a href="/wiki/Maria_Francisca_of_Savoy" title="Maria Francisca of Savoy">Maria Francisca of Savoy</a>, and his brother, <a href="/wiki/Peter_II_of_Portugal" title="Peter II of Portugal">Pedro, Duke of Beja</a>, King Afonso VI was declared mentally incompetent and exiled first to the Azores and then to the <a href="/wiki/Sintra_National_Palace" title="Sintra National Palace">Royal Palace of Sintra</a>, outside Lisbon. After Afonso's death, Pedro came to the throne as King Pedro II. Pedro's reign saw the consolidation of national independence, imperial expansion, and investment in domestic production. </p>
      <p>Pedro II's son, <a href="/wiki/John_V_of_Portugal" title="John V of Portugal">John V</a>, saw a reign characterized by the influx of gold into the coffers of the royal treasury, supplied largely by the <a href="/wiki/Royal_fifth" title="Royal fifth">royal fifth</a> (a tax on precious metals) that was received from the <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_empire" class="mw-redirect" title="Portuguese empire">Portuguese colonies</a> of <a href="/wiki/State_of_Brazil" title="State of Brazil">Brazil</a> and <a href="/wiki/State_of_Maranh%C3%A3o_(colonial)" title="State of Maranhão (colonial)">Maranhão</a>. </p>
      <p>Disregarding traditional Portuguese institutions of governance, John V acted as an absolute monarch, nearly depleting the country's tax revenues on ambitious architectural works, most notably <a href="/wiki/Mafra_National_Palace" class="mw-redirect" title="Mafra National Palace">Mafra Palace</a>, and on commissions and additions for his sizeable art and literary collections. </p>
      <p>Owing to his craving for international diplomatic recognition, John also spent large sums on the embassies he sent to the courts of Europe, the most famous being those he sent to <a href="/wiki/Paris" title="Paris">Paris</a> in 1715 and <a href="/wiki/Rome" title="Rome">Rome</a> in 1716. </p>
      <p>Official estimates&nbsp;– and most estimates made so far&nbsp;– place the number of Portuguese migrants to <a href="/wiki/Colonial_Brazil" title="Colonial Brazil">Colonial Brazil</a> during the gold rush of the 18th century at 600,000.<sup id="cite_ref-ibge_89-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ibge-89">[84]</a></sup> This represented one of the largest movements of European populations to their colonies in the Americas during colonial times. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Pombaline_era_and_Enlightenment">Pombaline era and Enlightenment</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Portugal&amp;action=edit&amp;section=11" title="Edit section: Pombaline era and Enlightenment">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/History_of_Portugal_(1640%E2%80%931777)" title="History of Portugal (1640–1777)">History of Portugal (1640–1777)</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Sebasti%C3%A3oJoseph.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ed/Sebasti%C3%A3oJoseph.png/200px-Sebasti%C3%A3oJoseph.png" decoding="async" width="200" height="287" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ed/Sebasti%C3%A3oJoseph.png/300px-Sebasti%C3%A3oJoseph.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ed/Sebasti%C3%A3oJoseph.png/400px-Sebasti%C3%A3oJoseph.png 2x" data-file-width="616" data-file-height="885"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Sebasti%C3%A3oJoseph.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The <a href="/wiki/Sebasti%C3%A3o_Jos%C3%A9_de_Carvalho_e_Melo,_1st_Marquis_of_Pombal" title="Sebastião José de Carvalho e Melo, 1st Marquis of Pombal">1st Marquis of Pombal</a> effectively ruled Portugal during the reign of King <a href="/wiki/Joseph_I_of_Portugal" title="Joseph I of Portugal">José I</a>.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>In 1738, <i><a href="/wiki/Fidalgo" title="Fidalgo">fidalgo</a></i> <a href="/wiki/Sebasti%C3%A3o_Jos%C3%A9_de_Carvalho_e_Melo,_1st_Marquis_of_Pombal" title="Sebastião José de Carvalho e Melo, 1st Marquis of Pombal">Sebastião José de Carvalho e Melo</a> (later ennobled as the 1st <a href="/wiki/Marquis_of_Pombal_(title)" title="Marquis of Pombal (title)">Marquis of Pombal</a>) began a diplomatic career as the Portuguese Ambassador in London and later in Vienna. The <a href="/wiki/Queen_consort" title="Queen consort">Queen consort</a> of Portugal, <a href="/wiki/Maria_Anna_of_Austria" title="Maria Anna of Austria">Archduchess Maria Anna of Austria</a>, was fond of Carvalho e Melo; and after his first wife died, she arranged the widowed Carvalho e Melo's second marriage to the daughter of the Austrian Field Marshal <a href="/wiki/Leopold_Josef,_Count_von_Daun" class="mw-redirect" title="Leopold Josef, Count von Daun">Leopold Josef, Count von Daun</a>. King <a href="/wiki/John_V_of_Portugal" title="John V of Portugal">John V</a>, however, was not pleased and recalled Carvalho e Melo to Portugal in 1749. John V died the following year and his son, <a href="/wiki/Joseph_I_of_Portugal" title="Joseph I of Portugal">Joseph I</a>, was crowned. In contrast to his father, Joseph I was fond of Carvalho e Melo, and with the <a href="/wiki/Queen_Mother" class="mw-redirect" title="Queen Mother">Queen Mother</a>'s approval, he appointed Carvalho e Melo as <a href="/wiki/Political_minister" class="mw-redirect" title="Political minister">Minister</a> of Foreign Affairs. </p>
      <p>As the King's confidence in Carvalho e Melo increased, the King entrusted him with more control of the state. By 1755, Sebastião José de Carvalho e Melo was made Prime Minister. Impressed by British economic success that he had witnessed from his time as an Ambassador, he successfully implemented similar <a href="/wiki/Economic_system" title="Economic system">economic</a> policies in Portugal. He <a href="/wiki/Slavery_in_Portugal#Banning" title="Slavery in Portugal">abolished slavery</a> in mainland Portugal and in the Portuguese colonies in India, reorganized the army and the navy, restructured the <a href="/wiki/University_of_Coimbra" title="University of Coimbra">University of Coimbra</a>, and ended legal discrimination against different <a href="/wiki/Christianity" title="Christianity">Christian</a> sects in Portugal by abolishing the distinction between <a href="/wiki/Old_Christian" title="Old Christian">Old</a> and <a href="/wiki/New_Christian" title="New Christian">New Christians</a>. </p>
      <p>Carvalho e Melo's greatest reforms were economic and financial, with the creation of several companies and guilds to regulate every commercial activity. He created one of the first <a href="/wiki/Appellation" title="Appellation">appellation systems</a> in the world by demarcating the region for production of <a href="/wiki/Port_wine" title="Port wine">Port</a> to ensure the wine's quality; and this was the first attempt to control wine quality and production in Europe. He ruled with a strong hand by imposing strict law upon all classes of Portuguese society from the high nobility to the poorest working class, along with a widespread review of the country's tax system. These reforms gained him enemies in the upper classes, especially among the high nobility, who despised him as a social upstart. </p> 
      <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r978413945/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">
      <div class="thumb tmulti tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:242px;max-width:242px">
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:119px;max-width:119px">
          <div class="thumbimage" style="height:82px;overflow:hidden">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Ruinas_da_Pra%C3%A7a_da_Patriarcal_ap%C3%B3s_o_Terramoto_de_1755_-_Jacques_Philippe_Le_Bas,_1757.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bd/Ruinas_da_Pra%C3%A7a_da_Patriarcal_ap%C3%B3s_o_Terramoto_de_1755_-_Jacques_Philippe_Le_Bas%2C_1757.png/117px-Ruinas_da_Pra%C3%A7a_da_Patriarcal_ap%C3%B3s_o_Terramoto_de_1755_-_Jacques_Philippe_Le_Bas%2C_1757.png" decoding="async" width="117" height="82" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bd/Ruinas_da_Pra%C3%A7a_da_Patriarcal_ap%C3%B3s_o_Terramoto_de_1755_-_Jacques_Philippe_Le_Bas%2C_1757.png/176px-Ruinas_da_Pra%C3%A7a_da_Patriarcal_ap%C3%B3s_o_Terramoto_de_1755_-_Jacques_Philippe_Le_Bas%2C_1757.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bd/Ruinas_da_Pra%C3%A7a_da_Patriarcal_ap%C3%B3s_o_Terramoto_de_1755_-_Jacques_Philippe_Le_Bas%2C_1757.png/234px-Ruinas_da_Pra%C3%A7a_da_Patriarcal_ap%C3%B3s_o_Terramoto_de_1755_-_Jacques_Philippe_Le_Bas%2C_1757.png 2x" data-file-width="1024" data-file-height="715"></a>
          </div>
         </div>
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:119px;max-width:119px">
          <div class="thumbimage" style="height:82px;overflow:hidden">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Ruinas_da_Igreja_de_S._Nicolau_ap%C3%B3s_o_Terramoto_de_1755_-_Jacques_Philippe_Le_Bas,_1757.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/49/Ruinas_da_Igreja_de_S._Nicolau_ap%C3%B3s_o_Terramoto_de_1755_-_Jacques_Philippe_Le_Bas%2C_1757.png/117px-Ruinas_da_Igreja_de_S._Nicolau_ap%C3%B3s_o_Terramoto_de_1755_-_Jacques_Philippe_Le_Bas%2C_1757.png" decoding="async" width="117" height="83" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/49/Ruinas_da_Igreja_de_S._Nicolau_ap%C3%B3s_o_Terramoto_de_1755_-_Jacques_Philippe_Le_Bas%2C_1757.png/176px-Ruinas_da_Igreja_de_S._Nicolau_ap%C3%B3s_o_Terramoto_de_1755_-_Jacques_Philippe_Le_Bas%2C_1757.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/49/Ruinas_da_Igreja_de_S._Nicolau_ap%C3%B3s_o_Terramoto_de_1755_-_Jacques_Philippe_Le_Bas%2C_1757.png/234px-Ruinas_da_Igreja_de_S._Nicolau_ap%C3%B3s_o_Terramoto_de_1755_-_Jacques_Philippe_Le_Bas%2C_1757.png 2x" data-file-width="1012" data-file-height="716"></a>
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:119px;max-width:119px">
          <div class="thumbimage" style="height:82px;overflow:hidden">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Ruinas_da_Igreja_de_S._Paulo_ap%C3%B3s_o_Terramoto_de_1755_-_Jacques_Philippe_Le_Bas,_1757.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6b/Ruinas_da_Igreja_de_S._Paulo_ap%C3%B3s_o_Terramoto_de_1755_-_Jacques_Philippe_Le_Bas%2C_1757.png/117px-Ruinas_da_Igreja_de_S._Paulo_ap%C3%B3s_o_Terramoto_de_1755_-_Jacques_Philippe_Le_Bas%2C_1757.png" decoding="async" width="117" height="83" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6b/Ruinas_da_Igreja_de_S._Paulo_ap%C3%B3s_o_Terramoto_de_1755_-_Jacques_Philippe_Le_Bas%2C_1757.png/176px-Ruinas_da_Igreja_de_S._Paulo_ap%C3%B3s_o_Terramoto_de_1755_-_Jacques_Philippe_Le_Bas%2C_1757.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6b/Ruinas_da_Igreja_de_S._Paulo_ap%C3%B3s_o_Terramoto_de_1755_-_Jacques_Philippe_Le_Bas%2C_1757.png/234px-Ruinas_da_Igreja_de_S._Paulo_ap%C3%B3s_o_Terramoto_de_1755_-_Jacques_Philippe_Le_Bas%2C_1757.png 2x" data-file-width="1029" data-file-height="731"></a>
          </div>
         </div>
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:119px;max-width:119px">
          <div class="thumbimage" style="height:82px;overflow:hidden">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Ruinas_da_S%C3%A9_de_Lisboa_ap%C3%B3s_o_Terramoto_de_1755_-_Jacques_Philippe_Le_Bas,_1757.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/70/Ruinas_da_S%C3%A9_de_Lisboa_ap%C3%B3s_o_Terramoto_de_1755_-_Jacques_Philippe_Le_Bas%2C_1757.png/117px-Ruinas_da_S%C3%A9_de_Lisboa_ap%C3%B3s_o_Terramoto_de_1755_-_Jacques_Philippe_Le_Bas%2C_1757.png" decoding="async" width="117" height="83" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/70/Ruinas_da_S%C3%A9_de_Lisboa_ap%C3%B3s_o_Terramoto_de_1755_-_Jacques_Philippe_Le_Bas%2C_1757.png/176px-Ruinas_da_S%C3%A9_de_Lisboa_ap%C3%B3s_o_Terramoto_de_1755_-_Jacques_Philippe_Le_Bas%2C_1757.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/70/Ruinas_da_S%C3%A9_de_Lisboa_ap%C3%B3s_o_Terramoto_de_1755_-_Jacques_Philippe_Le_Bas%2C_1757.png/234px-Ruinas_da_S%C3%A9_de_Lisboa_ap%C3%B3s_o_Terramoto_de_1755_-_Jacques_Philippe_Le_Bas%2C_1757.png 2x" data-file-width="1016" data-file-height="725"></a>
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="trow" style="display:flex">
         <div class="thumbcaption">
          The <a href="/wiki/1755_Lisbon_earthquake" title="1755 Lisbon earthquake">1755 Lisbon earthquake</a> devastated Portugal with an estimated magnitude between 8.5 and 9.0.
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Disaster fell upon Portugal in the morning of 1 November 1755, when <a href="/wiki/Lisbon" title="Lisbon">Lisbon</a> was struck by <a href="/wiki/1755_Lisbon_earthquake" title="1755 Lisbon earthquake">a violent earthquake</a> with an estimated <a href="/wiki/Moment_magnitude_scale" title="Moment magnitude scale">moment magnitude</a> of 8.5–9. The city was razed to the ground by the earthquake and the subsequent tsunami and ensuing fires.<sup id="cite_ref-90" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-90">[85]</a></sup> Carvalho e Melo survived by a stroke of luck and then immediately embarked on rebuilding the city, with his famous quote: "What now? We bury the dead and take care of the living." </p>
      <p>Despite the calamity and huge <a href="/wiki/Death_toll" title="Death toll">death toll</a>, Lisbon suffered no epidemics and within less than one year was already being rebuilt. The new city centre of Lisbon was designed to resist subsequent earthquakes. Architectural models were built for tests, and the effects of an earthquake were simulated by having troops march around the models. The buildings and large squares of the <a href="/wiki/Lisbon_Baixa" title="Lisbon Baixa">Pombaline Downtown</a> still remain as one of Lisbon's tourist attractions. Carvalho e Melo also made an important contribution to the study of <a href="/wiki/Seismology" title="Seismology">seismology</a> by designing a detailed inquiry on the effects of the earthquake, the <a href="/wiki/Parochial_Memories_of_1758" title="Parochial Memories of 1758">Parochial Memories of 1758</a>, that was sent to every parish in the country; this wealth of information allows modern scientists to reconstruct the event with some degree of scientific precision. </p>
      <p>Following the earthquake, <a href="/wiki/Joseph_I_of_Portugal" title="Joseph I of Portugal">Joseph I</a> gave his Prime Minister even more power, and Carvalho de Melo became a powerful, <a href="/wiki/Enlightened_absolutism" title="Enlightened absolutism">progressive dictator</a>. As his power grew, his enemies increased in number, and bitter disputes with the upper nobility became frequent. In 1758 Joseph I was wounded in an attempted assassination. The <a href="/wiki/Marquis_of_T%C3%A1vora" title="Marquis of Távora">Távora family</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Dukes_of_Aveiro" class="mw-redirect" title="Dukes of Aveiro">Duke of Aveiro</a> were implicated and <a href="/wiki/T%C3%A1vora_affair" title="Távora affair">summarily executed after a quick trial</a>. The following year, the <a href="/wiki/Society_of_Jesus" title="Society of Jesus">Jesuits</a> were <a href="/wiki/Suppression_of_the_Society_of_Jesus" title="Suppression of the Society of Jesus">suppressed and expelled from the country</a> and their assets confiscated by the crown. Carvalho e Melo spared none involved, even women and children (notably, 8-year-old <a href="/wiki/Leonor_de_Almeida_Portugal,_Marquise_of_Alorna" title="Leonor de Almeida Portugal, Marquise of Alorna">Leonor de Almeida Portugal</a>, imprisoned in a convent for nineteen years). This was the final stroke that crushed all opposition by publicly demonstrating even the aristocracy was powerless before the King's loyal minister. Joseph I ennobled Carvalho e Melo as Count of <a href="/wiki/Oeiras,_Portugal" title="Oeiras, Portugal">Oeiras</a> in 1759. </p>
      <p>In 1762, <a href="/wiki/Spanish%E2%80%93Portuguese_War,_1761%E2%80%931763" class="mw-redirect" title="Spanish–Portuguese War, 1761–1763">Spain invaded Portuguese territory</a> as part of the <a href="/wiki/Seven_Years%27_War" title="Seven Years' War">Seven Years' War</a>, but by 1763 the <i>status quo</i> between Spain and Portugal before the war had been restored. </p>
      <p>Following the Távora affair, the new Count of Oeiras knew no opposition. Further titled "Marquês de Pombal" in 1770, he effectively ruled Portugal until Joseph I's death in 1777. </p>
      <p>The new ruler, Queen <a href="/wiki/Maria_I_of_Portugal" title="Maria I of Portugal">Maria I of Portugal</a>, disliked the Marquês de Pombal because of the power he amassed, and never forgave him for the ruthlessness with which he dispatched the Távora family, and upon her accession to the throne, she withdrew all his political offices. The Marquês de Pombal was banished to his estate at <a href="/wiki/Pombal,_Portugal" title="Pombal, Portugal">Pombal</a>, where he died in 1782. </p>
      <p>However, historians also argue that Pombal's "enlightenment," while far-reaching, was primarily a mechanism for enhancing autocracy at the expense of individual liberty and especially an apparatus for crushing opposition, suppressing criticism, and furthering colonial economic exploitation as well as intensifying book censorship and consolidating personal control and profit.<sup id="cite_ref-91" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-91">[86]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Napoleonic_era">Napoleonic era</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Portugal&amp;action=edit&amp;section=12" title="Edit section: Napoleonic era">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/History_of_Portugal_(1777%E2%80%931834)" title="History of Portugal (1777–1834)">History of Portugal (1777–1834)</a> and <a href="/wiki/United_Kingdom_of_Portugal,_Brazil_and_the_Algarves" title="United Kingdom of Portugal, Brazil and the Algarves">United Kingdom of Portugal, Brazil and the Algarves</a>
      </div> 
      <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r978413945/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">
      <div class="thumb tmulti tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:204px;max-width:204px">
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px">
          <div class="thumbimage">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Embarque_da_Fam%C3%ADlia_Real_para_o_Brasil_-_Nicolas-Louis-Albert_Delerive,_attrib._(Museu_Nacional_dos_Coches).png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/99/Embarque_da_Fam%C3%ADlia_Real_para_o_Brasil_-_Nicolas-Louis-Albert_Delerive%2C_attrib._%28Museu_Nacional_dos_Coches%29.png/200px-Embarque_da_Fam%C3%ADlia_Real_para_o_Brasil_-_Nicolas-Louis-Albert_Delerive%2C_attrib._%28Museu_Nacional_dos_Coches%29.png" decoding="async" width="200" height="141" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/99/Embarque_da_Fam%C3%ADlia_Real_para_o_Brasil_-_Nicolas-Louis-Albert_Delerive%2C_attrib._%28Museu_Nacional_dos_Coches%29.png/300px-Embarque_da_Fam%C3%ADlia_Real_para_o_Brasil_-_Nicolas-Louis-Albert_Delerive%2C_attrib._%28Museu_Nacional_dos_Coches%29.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/99/Embarque_da_Fam%C3%ADlia_Real_para_o_Brasil_-_Nicolas-Louis-Albert_Delerive%2C_attrib._%28Museu_Nacional_dos_Coches%29.png/400px-Embarque_da_Fam%C3%ADlia_Real_para_o_Brasil_-_Nicolas-Louis-Albert_Delerive%2C_attrib._%28Museu_Nacional_dos_Coches%29.png 2x" data-file-width="5347" data-file-height="3782"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           The <a href="/wiki/Transfer_of_the_Portuguese_Court_to_Brazil" class="mw-redirect" title="Transfer of the Portuguese Court to Brazil">Departure of the Portuguese Royal Court to Brazil</a> in 1808
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px">
          <div class="thumbimage">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Alegoria_%C3%A0s_virtudes_do_Pr%C3%ADncipe_Regente_D._Jo%C3%A3o_-_Domingos_Sequeira,_1810.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/66/Alegoria_%C3%A0s_virtudes_do_Pr%C3%ADncipe_Regente_D._Jo%C3%A3o_-_Domingos_Sequeira%2C_1810.png/200px-Alegoria_%C3%A0s_virtudes_do_Pr%C3%ADncipe_Regente_D._Jo%C3%A3o_-_Domingos_Sequeira%2C_1810.png" decoding="async" width="200" height="147" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/66/Alegoria_%C3%A0s_virtudes_do_Pr%C3%ADncipe_Regente_D._Jo%C3%A3o_-_Domingos_Sequeira%2C_1810.png/300px-Alegoria_%C3%A0s_virtudes_do_Pr%C3%ADncipe_Regente_D._Jo%C3%A3o_-_Domingos_Sequeira%2C_1810.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/66/Alegoria_%C3%A0s_virtudes_do_Pr%C3%ADncipe_Regente_D._Jo%C3%A3o_-_Domingos_Sequeira%2C_1810.png/400px-Alegoria_%C3%A0s_virtudes_do_Pr%C3%ADncipe_Regente_D._Jo%C3%A3o_-_Domingos_Sequeira%2C_1810.png 2x" data-file-width="3543" data-file-height="2608"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           <i>Allegory of the Virtues of <a href="/wiki/John_VI_of_Portugal" title="John VI of Portugal">Prince Regent John</a></i>; <a href="/wiki/Domingos_Sequeira" title="Domingos Sequeira">D. Sequeira</a>, 1810
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>With the occupation by Napoleon, Portugal began a slow but inexorable decline that lasted until the 20th century. This decline was hastened by the <a href="/wiki/Independence_of_Brazil" title="Independence of Brazil">independence of Brazil</a>, the country's largest colonial possession. </p>
      <p>In the autumn of 1807, <a href="/wiki/Napoleon" title="Napoleon">Napoleon</a> moved French troops through Spain to invade Portugal. From 1807 to 1811, British-Portuguese forces would successfully fight against the French invasion of Portugal in the <a href="/wiki/Peninsular_War" title="Peninsular War">Peninsular War</a>, during which the royal family and the Portuguese <a href="/wiki/Nobility" title="Nobility">nobility</a>, including Maria I, relocated to the <a href="/wiki/Colonial_Brazil" title="Colonial Brazil">Portuguese territory of Brazil</a>, at that time a colony of the <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_Empire" title="Portuguese Empire">Portuguese Empire</a>, in South America. This episode is known as the <a href="/wiki/Transfer_of_the_Portuguese_Court_to_Brazil" class="mw-redirect" title="Transfer of the Portuguese Court to Brazil">Transfer of the Portuguese Court to Brazil</a>. </p>
      <p>In 1807, as Napoleon's army closed in on Lisbon, <a href="/wiki/Jo%C3%A3o_VI_of_Portugal" class="mw-redirect" title="João VI of Portugal">João VI of Portugal</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Prince_Regent" class="mw-redirect" title="Prince Regent">Prince Regent</a>, transferred his court to Brazil and established <a href="/wiki/Rio_de_Janeiro" title="Rio de Janeiro">Rio de Janeiro</a> as the capital of the Portuguese Empire. In 1815, Brazil was declared a Kingdom and the Kingdom of Portugal was united with it, forming a pluricontinental state, the <a href="/wiki/United_Kingdom_of_Portugal,_Brazil_and_the_Algarves" title="United Kingdom of Portugal, Brazil and the Algarves">United Kingdom of Portugal, Brazil and the Algarves</a>. </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Portuguese_Constitution_of_1826.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e4/Portuguese_Constitution_of_1826.jpg/200px-Portuguese_Constitution_of_1826.jpg" decoding="async" width="200" height="252" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e4/Portuguese_Constitution_of_1826.jpg/300px-Portuguese_Constitution_of_1826.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e4/Portuguese_Constitution_of_1826.jpg/400px-Portuguese_Constitution_of_1826.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1243" data-file-height="1564"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Portuguese_Constitution_of_1826.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The frontispiece of the 1826 Portuguese Constitution featuring King-Emperor <a href="/wiki/Pedro_I_of_Brazil" title="Pedro I of Brazil">Pedro IV</a> and his daughter Queen <a href="/wiki/Maria_II_of_Portugal" title="Maria II of Portugal">Maria II</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>As a result of the change in its status and the arrival of the Portuguese royal family, Brazilian administrative, civic, <a href="/wiki/Economic_history_of_Brazil#The_economy_at_independence,_1822" title="Economic history of Brazil">economical</a>, military, <a href="/wiki/Education_in_Brazil#History" title="Education in Brazil">educational</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Brazilian_science_and_technology#History" class="mw-redirect" title="Brazilian science and technology">scientific</a> apparatus were expanded and highly modernized. Portuguese and their allied British troops fought against the <a href="/wiki/French_Invasion_of_Portugal" class="mw-redirect" title="French Invasion of Portugal">French Invasion of Portugal</a> and by 1815 the situation in Europe had cooled down sufficiently that João VI would have been able to return safely to Lisbon. However, the King of Portugal remained in Brazil until the <a href="/wiki/Liberal_Revolution_of_1820" title="Liberal Revolution of 1820">Liberal Revolution of 1820</a>, which started in <a href="/wiki/Porto" title="Porto">Porto</a>, demanded his return to Lisbon in 1821. </p>
      <p>Thus he returned to Portugal but left his son <a href="/wiki/Pedro_I_of_Brazil" title="Pedro I of Brazil">Pedro</a> in charge of Brazil. When the Portuguese Government attempted the following year to return the Kingdom of Brazil to subordinate status, his son Pedro, with the overwhelming support of the Brazilian elites, declared <a href="/wiki/War_of_Independence_of_Brazil" title="War of Independence of Brazil">Brazil's independence</a> from Portugal. <a href="/wiki/Cisplatina" title="Cisplatina">Cisplatina</a> (today's sovereign state of Uruguay), in the south, was one of the last additions to the territory of Brazil under Portuguese rule. </p>
      <p>Brazilian independence was recognized in 1825, whereby Emperor Pedro I granted to his father the titular honour of <i>Emperor of Brazil</i>. John VI's death in 1826 caused serious questions in his succession. Though Pedro was his heir, and reigned briefly as Pedro IV, his status as a Brazilian monarch was seen as an impediment to holding the Portuguese throne by both nations. Pedro abdicated in favour of his daughter, <a href="/wiki/Maria_II_of_Portugal" title="Maria II of Portugal">Maria II</a> (Mary II). However, Pedro's brother, <a href="/wiki/Miguel_I_of_Portugal" title="Miguel I of Portugal">Infante Miguel</a>, claimed the throne in protest. After a proposal for Miguel and Maria to marry failed, Miguel seized power as King Miguel I, in 1828. In order to defend his daughter's rights to the throne, Pedro launched the <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_Civil_War" class="mw-redirect" title="Portuguese Civil War">Liberal Wars</a> to reinstall his daughter and establish a constitutional monarchy in Portugal. The war ended in 1834, with Miguel's defeat, the promulgation of a constitution, and the reinstatement of Queen Maria II. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Constitutional_monarchy">Constitutional monarchy</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Portugal&amp;action=edit&amp;section=13" title="Edit section: Constitutional monarchy">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/History_of_Portugal_(1834%E2%80%931910)" title="History of Portugal (1834–1910)">History of Portugal (1834–1910)</a>
      </div> 
      <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r978413945/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">
      <div class="thumb tmulti tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:204px;max-width:204px">
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px">
          <div class="thumbimage">
           <a href="/wiki/File:O_Regic%C3%ADdio_por_Haenen_(2).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/73/O_Regic%C3%ADdio_por_Haenen_%282%29.jpg/200px-O_Regic%C3%ADdio_por_Haenen_%282%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="200" height="118" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/73/O_Regic%C3%ADdio_por_Haenen_%282%29.jpg/300px-O_Regic%C3%ADdio_por_Haenen_%282%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/73/O_Regic%C3%ADdio_por_Haenen_%282%29.jpg/400px-O_Regic%C3%ADdio_por_Haenen_%282%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="669" data-file-height="395"></a>
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px">
          <div class="thumbimage">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Aclama%C3%A7%C3%A3o_de_Dom_Manuel_II.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ef/Aclama%C3%A7%C3%A3o_de_Dom_Manuel_II.jpg/200px-Aclama%C3%A7%C3%A3o_de_Dom_Manuel_II.jpg" decoding="async" width="200" height="123" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ef/Aclama%C3%A7%C3%A3o_de_Dom_Manuel_II.jpg/300px-Aclama%C3%A7%C3%A3o_de_Dom_Manuel_II.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ef/Aclama%C3%A7%C3%A3o_de_Dom_Manuel_II.jpg/400px-Aclama%C3%A7%C3%A3o_de_Dom_Manuel_II.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1045" data-file-height="644"></a>
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px">
          <div class="thumbimage">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Proclama%C3%A7%C3%A3o_Rep%C3%BAblica_Portuguesa.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a9/Proclama%C3%A7%C3%A3o_Rep%C3%BAblica_Portuguesa.jpg/200px-Proclama%C3%A7%C3%A3o_Rep%C3%BAblica_Portuguesa.jpg" decoding="async" width="200" height="139" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a9/Proclama%C3%A7%C3%A3o_Rep%C3%BAblica_Portuguesa.jpg/300px-Proclama%C3%A7%C3%A3o_Rep%C3%BAblica_Portuguesa.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a9/Proclama%C3%A7%C3%A3o_Rep%C3%BAblica_Portuguesa.jpg/400px-Proclama%C3%A7%C3%A3o_Rep%C3%BAblica_Portuguesa.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2048" data-file-height="1422"></a>
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="trow" style="display:flex">
         <div class="thumbcaption">
          Top to bottom: The <a href="/wiki/Lisbon_Regicide" title="Lisbon Regicide">Lisbon Regicide</a> (1908), <a href="/wiki/Manuel_II_of_Portugal" title="Manuel II of Portugal">Manuel II</a>'s acclamation as King (1908) and the <a href="/wiki/5_October_1910_revolution" title="5 October 1910 revolution">Proclamation of the Republic</a> (1910)
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Queen Maria II (Mary II) and King <a href="/wiki/Ferdinand_II_of_Portugal" title="Ferdinand II of Portugal">Ferdinand II</a>'s son, King <a href="/wiki/Pedro_V" class="mw-redirect" title="Pedro V">Pedro V</a> (Peter V) modernized the country during his short reign (1853–1861). Under his reign, roads, telegraphs, and railways were constructed and improvements in public health advanced. His popularity increased when, during the <a href="/wiki/Cholera" title="Cholera">cholera</a> outbreak of 1853–1856, he visited hospitals handing out gifts and comforting the sick. Pedro's reign was short, as he died of cholera in 1861, after a series of deaths in the royal family, including his two brothers <a href="/wiki/Infante_Fernando_of_Portugal" title="Infante Fernando of Portugal">Infante Fernando</a> and <a href="/wiki/Infante_Jo%C3%A3o,_Duke_of_Beja" title="Infante João, Duke of Beja">Infante João, Duke of Beja</a>, and his wife, <a href="/wiki/Stephanie_of_Hohenzollern-Sigmaringen" title="Stephanie of Hohenzollern-Sigmaringen">Stephanie of Hohenzollern-Sigmaringen</a>. Pedro not having children, his brother, <a href="/wiki/Lu%C3%ADs_I_of_Portugal" title="Luís I of Portugal">Luís I of Portugal</a> (Louis I) ascended the throne and continued his modernization. </p>
      <p>At the height of European colonialism in the 19th century, Portugal had already lost its territory in South America and all but a few bases in Asia. <a href="/wiki/Luanda" title="Luanda">Luanda</a>, <a href="/wiki/Benguela" title="Benguela">Benguela</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bissau" title="Bissau">Bissau</a>, <a href="/wiki/Maputo" title="Maputo">Lourenço Marques</a>, <a href="/wiki/Porto_Amboim" title="Porto Amboim">Porto Amboim</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Island_of_Mozambique" title="Island of Mozambique">Island of Mozambique</a> were among the oldest Portuguese-founded port cities in its African territories. During this phase, Portuguese colonialism focused on expanding its outposts in Africa into nation-sized territories to compete with other European powers there. </p>
      <p>With the <a href="/wiki/Berlin_Conference_(1884)" class="mw-redirect" title="Berlin Conference (1884)">Conference of Berlin</a> of 1884, Portuguese territories in Africa had their borders formally established on request of Portugal in order to protect the centuries-long Portuguese interests in the continent from rivalries enticed by the <a href="/wiki/Scramble_for_Africa" title="Scramble for Africa">Scramble for Africa</a>. Portuguese towns and cities in Africa like <a href="/wiki/Nova_Lisboa" class="mw-redirect" title="Nova Lisboa">Nova Lisboa</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lubango" title="Lubango">Sá da Bandeira</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kuito" class="mw-redirect" title="Kuito">Silva Porto</a>, <a href="/wiki/Malanje" title="Malanje">Malanje</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tete" class="mw-redirect" title="Tete">Tete</a>, <a href="/wiki/Vila_Junqueiro" class="mw-redirect" title="Vila Junqueiro">Vila Junqueiro</a>, <a href="/wiki/Vila_Pery" class="mw-redirect" title="Vila Pery">Vila Pery</a> and <a href="/wiki/Vila_Cabral" class="mw-redirect" title="Vila Cabral">Vila Cabral</a> were founded or redeveloped inland during this period and beyond. New coastal towns like <a href="/wiki/Beira,_Mozambique" title="Beira, Mozambique">Beira</a>, <a href="/wiki/Namibe" class="mw-redirect" title="Namibe">Moçâmedes</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lobito" title="Lobito">Lobito</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jo%C3%A3o_Belo" class="mw-redirect" title="João Belo">João Belo</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nacala" title="Nacala">Nacala</a> and <a href="/wiki/Porto_Am%C3%A9lia" class="mw-redirect" title="Porto Amélia">Porto Amélia</a> were also founded. Even before the turn of the 20th century, railway tracks as the <a href="/wiki/Benguela_railway" title="Benguela railway">Benguela railway</a> in Angola, and the <a href="/wiki/Beira_railway" class="mw-redirect" title="Beira railway">Beira railway</a> in Mozambique, started to be built to link coastal areas and selected inland regions. </p>
      <p>Other episodes during this period of the Portuguese presence in Africa include the <a href="/wiki/1890_British_Ultimatum" title="1890 British Ultimatum">1890 British Ultimatum</a>. This forced the Portuguese military to retreat from the land between the Portuguese colonies of <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_Mozambique" title="Portuguese Mozambique">Mozambique</a> and <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_Angola" title="Portuguese Angola">Angola</a> (most of present-day <a href="/wiki/Zimbabwe" title="Zimbabwe">Zimbabwe</a> and <a href="/wiki/Zambia" title="Zambia">Zambia</a>), which had been claimed by Portugal and included in its "<a href="/wiki/Pink_Map" title="Pink Map">Pink Map</a>", which clashed with British aspirations to create a <a href="/wiki/Cape_to_Cairo_Railway" class="mw-redirect" title="Cape to Cairo Railway">Cape to Cairo Railway</a>. </p>
      <p>The Portuguese territories in Africa were <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_Cape_Verde" title="Portuguese Cape Verde">Cape Verde</a>, <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_S%C3%A3o_Tom%C3%A9_and_Pr%C3%ADncipe" title="Portuguese São Tomé and Príncipe">São Tomé and Príncipe</a>, <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_Guinea" title="Portuguese Guinea">Portuguese Guinea</a>, <a href="/wiki/Angola_(Portugal)" class="mw-redirect" title="Angola (Portugal)">Angola</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Mozambique_(Portugal)" class="mw-redirect" title="Mozambique (Portugal)">Mozambique</a>. The tiny fortress of <a href="/wiki/S%C3%A3o_Jo%C3%A3o_Baptista_de_Ajud%C3%A1" class="mw-redirect" title="São João Baptista de Ajudá">São João Baptista de Ajudá</a> on the coast of <a href="/wiki/Dahomey" title="Dahomey">Dahomey</a>, was also under Portuguese rule. In addition, Portugal still ruled the Asian territories of <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_India" title="Portuguese India">Portuguese India</a>, <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_Timor" title="Portuguese Timor">Portuguese Timor</a> and <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_Macau" title="Portuguese Macau">Portuguese Macau</a>. </p>
      <p>On February 1, 1908, King Dom <a href="/wiki/Carlos_I_of_Portugal" title="Carlos I of Portugal">Carlos I of Portugal</a> and his <a href="/wiki/Heir_apparent" title="Heir apparent">heir apparent</a> and his eldest son, <a href="/wiki/Luis_Filipe,_Prince_Royal_of_Portugal" class="mw-redirect" title="Luis Filipe, Prince Royal of Portugal">Prince Royal Dom Luís Filipe</a>, <a href="/wiki/Duke_of_Braganza" title="Duke of Braganza">Duke of Braganza</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lisbon_Regicide" title="Lisbon Regicide">were assassinated in Lisbon</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Terreiro_do_Pa%C3%A7o" class="mw-redirect" title="Terreiro do Paço">Terreiro do Paço</a> by two Portuguese republican activist revolutionaries, <a href="/wiki/Alfredo_Lu%C3%ADs_da_Costa" title="Alfredo Luís da Costa">Alfredo Luís da Costa</a> and <a href="/wiki/Manuel_Bu%C3%AD%C3%A7a" title="Manuel Buíça">Manuel Buíça</a>. Under his rule, Portugal had been declared <a href="/wiki/Bankrupt" class="mw-redirect" title="Bankrupt">bankrupt</a>&nbsp;twice – first on June 14, 1892, and then again on May 10, 1902&nbsp;– causing social turmoil, economic disturbances, angry protests, revolts and criticism of the monarchy. His second and youngest son, <a href="/wiki/Manuel_II_of_Portugal" title="Manuel II of Portugal">Manuel II of Portugal</a>, became the new king, but was eventually overthrown by the <a href="/wiki/5_October_1910_revolution" title="5 October 1910 revolution">5 October 1910 Portuguese republican revolution</a>, which abolished the monarchy and installed a <a href="/wiki/Republic" title="Republic">republican</a> government in Portugal, causing him and his royal family to flee into <a href="/wiki/Exile" title="Exile">exile</a> in <a href="/wiki/London" title="London">London</a>, <a href="/wiki/England" title="England">England</a>. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="First_Republic_and_Estado_Novo">First Republic and Estado Novo</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Portugal&amp;action=edit&amp;section=14" title="Edit section: First Republic and Estado Novo">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:262px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Bernardino_Machado,_Te%C3%B3filo_Braga,_Ant%C3%B3nio_Jos%C3%A9_de_Almeida_e_Afonso_Costa,_ap%C3%B3s_uma_sess%C3%A3o_solene_do_Parlamento_em_homenagem_aos_mortos_da_revolu%C3%A7%C3%A3o_republicana,_1911.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8d/Bernardino_Machado%2C_Te%C3%B3filo_Braga%2C_Ant%C3%B3nio_Jos%C3%A9_de_Almeida_e_Afonso_Costa%2C_ap%C3%B3s_uma_sess%C3%A3o_solene_do_Parlamento_em_homenagem_aos_mortos_da_revolu%C3%A7%C3%A3o_republicana%2C_1911.png/260px-thumbnail.png" decoding="async" width="260" height="183" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8d/Bernardino_Machado%2C_Te%C3%B3filo_Braga%2C_Ant%C3%B3nio_Jos%C3%A9_de_Almeida_e_Afonso_Costa%2C_ap%C3%B3s_uma_sess%C3%A3o_solene_do_Parlamento_em_homenagem_aos_mortos_da_revolu%C3%A7%C3%A3o_republicana%2C_1911.png/390px-thumbnail.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8d/Bernardino_Machado%2C_Te%C3%B3filo_Braga%2C_Ant%C3%B3nio_Jos%C3%A9_de_Almeida_e_Afonso_Costa%2C_ap%C3%B3s_uma_sess%C3%A3o_solene_do_Parlamento_em_homenagem_aos_mortos_da_revolu%C3%A7%C3%A3o_republicana%2C_1911.png/520px-thumbnail.png 2x" data-file-width="2048" data-file-height="1445"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Bernardino_Machado,_Te%C3%B3filo_Braga,_Ant%C3%B3nio_Jos%C3%A9_de_Almeida_e_Afonso_Costa,_ap%C3%B3s_uma_sess%C3%A3o_solene_do_Parlamento_em_homenagem_aos_mortos_da_revolu%C3%A7%C3%A3o_republicana,_1911.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Left to right: President <a href="/wiki/Bernardino_Machado" title="Bernardino Machado">Bernardino Machado</a>, President <a href="/wiki/Te%C3%B3filo_Braga" title="Teófilo Braga">Teófilo Braga</a>, President <a href="/wiki/Ant%C3%B3nio_Jos%C3%A9_de_Almeida" title="António José de Almeida">António José de Almeida</a>, and Prime Minister <a href="/wiki/Afonso_Costa" title="Afonso Costa">Afonso Costa</a>; 1911
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/First_Portuguese_Republic" title="First Portuguese Republic">First Portuguese Republic</a> and <a href="/wiki/Estado_Novo_(Portugal)" title="Estado Novo (Portugal)">Estado Novo (Portugal)</a>
      </div> 
      <p>The new republic had many problems. Portugal had 45 different governments in just 15 years. During <a href="/wiki/World_War_I" title="World War I">World War 1</a> (1914–1918), Portugal helped the <a href="/wiki/Allies_of_World_War_I" title="Allies of World War I">Allies</a> fight the <a href="/wiki/Central_Powers" title="Central Powers">Central Powers</a>. But the war hurt its weak economy. Political instability and economic weaknesses were fertile ground for chaos and unrest during the <a href="/wiki/First_Portuguese_Republic" title="First Portuguese Republic">First Portuguese Republic</a>. These conditions would lead to the failed <a href="/wiki/Monarchy_of_the_North" title="Monarchy of the North">Monarchy of the North</a>, <a href="/wiki/28_May_1926_coup_d%27%C3%A9tat" title="28 May 1926 coup d'état">28 May 1926 coup d'état</a>, and the creation of the National Dictatorship (<i><a href="/wiki/Ditadura_Nacional" title="Ditadura Nacional">Ditadura Nacional</a></i>). This in turn led to the establishment of the right-wing dictatorship of the <a href="/wiki/Estado_Novo_(Portugal)" title="Estado Novo (Portugal)">Estado Novo</a> under <a href="/wiki/Ant%C3%B3nio_de_Oliveira_Salazar" title="António de Oliveira Salazar">António de Oliveira Salazar</a> in 1933. </p>
      <p>Portugal remained neutral in <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">World War II</a>. From the 1940s to the 1960s, Portugal was a founding member of <a href="/wiki/NATO" title="NATO">NATO</a>, <a href="/wiki/OECD" title="OECD">OECD</a> and the <a href="/wiki/European_Free_Trade_Association" title="European Free Trade Association">European Free Trade Association</a> (EFTA). Gradually, new economic development projects and relocation of mainland Portuguese citizens into the overseas provinces in Africa were initiated, with <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_Angola" title="Portuguese Angola">Angola</a> and <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_Mozambique" title="Portuguese Mozambique">Mozambique</a>, as the largest and richest overseas territories, being the main targets of those initiatives. These actions were used to affirm Portugal's status as a <a href="/wiki/List_of_transcontinental_countries" title="List of transcontinental countries">transcontinental</a> nation and not as a colonial empire. </p>
      <p>After India attained independence in 1947, pro-Indian residents of <a href="/wiki/Dadra_and_Nagar_Haveli" title="Dadra and Nagar Haveli">Dadra and Nagar Haveli</a>, with the support of the Indian government and the help of pro-independence organizations, separated the territories of Dadra and Nagar Haveli from Portuguese rule in 1954.<sup id="cite_ref-lele_92-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-lele-92">[87]</a></sup> In 1961, <a href="/wiki/Fort_of_S%C3%A3o_Jo%C3%A3o_Baptista_de_Ajud%C3%A1" title="Fort of São João Baptista de Ajudá">Fort of São João Baptista de Ajudá</a>'s annexation by the <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_Dahomey" title="Republic of Dahomey">Republic of Dahomey</a> was the start of a process that led to the final dissolution of the centuries-old Portuguese Empire. </p> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Antonio_Salazar-1.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/34/Antonio_Salazar-1.jpg/200px-Antonio_Salazar-1.jpg" decoding="async" width="200" height="268" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/34/Antonio_Salazar-1.jpg/300px-Antonio_Salazar-1.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/34/Antonio_Salazar-1.jpg/400px-Antonio_Salazar-1.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1195" data-file-height="1600"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Antonio_Salazar-1.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Ant%C3%B3nio_de_Oliveira_Salazar" title="António de Oliveira Salazar">António de Oliveira Salazar</a> ruled Portugal from 1932 to 1968, within the <a href="/wiki/Estado_Novo_(Portugal)" title="Estado Novo (Portugal)">Estado Novo</a> regime.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>According to the census of 1921 São João Baptista de Ajudá had 5 inhabitants and, at the moment of the ultimatum by the Dahomey Government, it had only 2 inhabitants representing Portuguese Sovereignty. </p>
      <p>Another forcible retreat from overseas territories occurred in December 1961 when Portugal refused to relinquish the territories of <a href="/wiki/Goa" title="Goa">Goa</a>, <a href="/wiki/Daman_and_Diu" title="Daman and Diu">Daman and Diu</a> in <a href="/wiki/India" title="India">India</a>. As a result, the Portuguese army and navy were involved in armed conflict in its colony of <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_India" title="Portuguese India">Portuguese India</a> against the <a href="/wiki/Indian_Armed_Forces" title="Indian Armed Forces">Indian Armed Forces</a>. </p>
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Annexation_of_Goa" title="Annexation of Goa">operations resulted in the defeat</a> and surrender of the limited Portuguese defensive garrison, which was forced to surrender to a much larger military force. The outcome was the loss of the remaining Portuguese territories in the <a href="/wiki/Indian_subcontinent" title="Indian subcontinent">Indian subcontinent</a>. The Portuguese regime refused to recognize Indian sovereignty over the annexed territories, which continued to be represented in Portugal's National Assembly until the military coup of 1974. </p>
      <p>Also in the early 1960s, independence movements in the Portuguese overseas provinces of <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_Angola" title="Portuguese Angola">Angola</a>, <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_Mozambique" title="Portuguese Mozambique">Mozambique</a> and <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_Guinea" title="Portuguese Guinea">Guinea</a> in Africa, resulted in the <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_Colonial_War" title="Portuguese Colonial War">Portuguese Colonial War</a> (1961–1974). </p>
      <p>Throughout the colonial war period Portugal had to deal with increasing dissent, arms embargoes and other punitive sanctions imposed by most of the international community. However, the authoritarian and conservative <a href="/wiki/Estado_Novo_(Portugal)" title="Estado Novo (Portugal)">Estado Novo</a> regime, first installed and governed by <a href="/wiki/Ant%C3%B3nio_de_Oliveira_Salazar" title="António de Oliveira Salazar">António de Oliveira Salazar</a> and from 1968 onwards led by <a href="/wiki/Marcelo_Caetano" title="Marcelo Caetano">Marcelo Caetano</a>, tried to preserve a vast centuries-long intercontinental empire with a total area of 2,168,071&nbsp;km<sup>2</sup>.<sup id="cite_ref-93" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-93">[88]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Carnation_Revolution_and_European_integration">Carnation Revolution and European integration</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Portugal&amp;action=edit&amp;section=15" title="Edit section: Carnation Revolution and European integration">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Carnation_Revolution" title="Carnation Revolution">Carnation Revolution</a> and <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_transition_to_democracy" title="Portuguese transition to democracy">Portuguese transition to democracy</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Portuguese_colonial_war_blank_map.svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d6/Portuguese_colonial_war_blank_map.svg/200px-Portuguese_colonial_war_blank_map.svg.png" decoding="async" width="200" height="223" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d6/Portuguese_colonial_war_blank_map.svg/300px-Portuguese_colonial_war_blank_map.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d6/Portuguese_colonial_war_blank_map.svg/400px-Portuguese_colonial_war_blank_map.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="635" data-file-height="709"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Portuguese_colonial_war_blank_map.svg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Portuguese_Africa_(disambiguation)" class="mw-redirect mw-disambig" title="Portuguese Africa (disambiguation)">Portuguese Africa</a> before independence in 1975
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The Portuguese government and army resisted the <a href="/wiki/Decolonization" title="Decolonization">decolonization</a> of its overseas territories until April 1974, when a bloodless left-wing military <a href="/wiki/Coup" class="mw-redirect" title="Coup">coup</a> in Lisbon, known as the <a href="/wiki/Carnation_Revolution" title="Carnation Revolution">Carnation Revolution</a>, led the way for the independence of the overseas territories in Africa and Asia, as well as for the restoration of democracy after two years of a transitional period known as PREC (<i><a href="/wiki/Processo_Revolucion%C3%A1rio_Em_Curso" title="Processo Revolucionário Em Curso">Processo Revolucionário Em Curso</a></i>). This period was characterized by social turmoil and power disputes between left- and right-wing political forces. By the summer of 1975, the tension between these was so high, that the country was on the verge of civil war. The forces connected to the extreme left-wing launched a further <i>coup d'état</i> on 25 November but the Group of Nine, a moderate military faction, immediately initiated a counter-coup. The main episode of this confrontation was the successful assault on the barracks of the left-wing dominated <a href="/wiki/2nd_Lancers_Regiment_(Portugal)" title="2nd Lancers Regiment (Portugal)">Military Police Regiment</a> by the moderate forces of the Commando Regiment, resulting in three soldiers <a href="/wiki/Killed_in_action" title="Killed in action">killed in action</a>. The Group of Nine emerged victorious, thus preventing the establishment of a <a href="/wiki/Communism" title="Communism">communist</a> state in Portugal and ending the period of political instability in the country. The retreat from the overseas territories and the acceptance of its independence terms by Portuguese head representatives for overseas negotiations, which would create independent states in 1975, prompted a mass exodus of Portuguese citizens from Portugal's African territories (mostly from Portuguese <a href="/wiki/Overseas_Province_of_Angola" class="mw-redirect" title="Overseas Province of Angola">Angola</a> and <a href="/wiki/Overseas_Province_of_Mozambique" class="mw-redirect" title="Overseas Province of Mozambique">Mozambique</a>).<sup id="cite_ref-94" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-94">[89]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-95" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-95">[90]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Over one million <a href="/wiki/White_African#Portuguese_in_Africa" class="mw-redirect" title="White African">Portuguese refugees</a> fled the former Portuguese provinces as white settlers were usually not considered part of the new identities of the former Portuguese colonies in Africa and Asia. <a href="/wiki/M%C3%A1rio_Soares" title="Mário Soares">Mário Soares</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ant%C3%B3nio_de_Almeida_Santos" title="António de Almeida Santos">António de Almeida Santos</a> were charged with organizing the independence of Portugal's overseas territories.
