By 1975, all the Portuguese African territories were independent and Portugal held <a href="/wiki/1975_Portuguese_Constituent_Assembly_election" title="1975 Portuguese Constituent Assembly election">its first democratic elections</a> in 50 years. </p>
      <p>Portugal continued to be governed by a <a href="/wiki/Junta_de_Salva%C3%A7%C3%A3o_Nacional" class="mw-redirect" title="Junta de Salvação Nacional">Junta de Salvação Nacional</a> until the <a href="/wiki/1976_Portuguese_legislative_election" title="1976 Portuguese legislative election">Portuguese legislative election of 1976</a>. It was won by the <a href="/wiki/Socialist_Party_(Portugal)" title="Socialist Party (Portugal)">Portuguese Socialist Party</a> (PS) and Mário Soares, its leader, became Prime Minister of the 1st Constitutional Government on 23 July. Mário Soares would be Prime Minister from 1976 to 1978 and again from 1983 to 1985. In this capacity Soares tried to resume the economic growth and development record that had been achieved before the Carnation Revolution, during the last decade of the previous regime. He initiated the process of accession to the <a href="/wiki/European_Economic_Community" title="European Economic Community">European Economic Community</a> (EEC) by starting accession negotiations as early as 1977. </p> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Portugese_minister_Soares_(voorzitter_Socialistische_Partij)_op_Schiphol_aangeko,_Bestanddeelnr_927-7110.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/aa/Portugese_minister_Soares_%28voorzitter_Socialistische_Partij%29_op_Schiphol_aangeko%2C_Bestanddeelnr_927-7110.jpg/200px-Portugese_minister_Soares_%28voorzitter_Socialistische_Partij%29_op_Schiphol_aangeko%2C_Bestanddeelnr_927-7110.jpg" decoding="async" width="200" height="131" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/aa/Portugese_minister_Soares_%28voorzitter_Socialistische_Partij%29_op_Schiphol_aangeko%2C_Bestanddeelnr_927-7110.jpg/300px-Portugese_minister_Soares_%28voorzitter_Socialistische_Partij%29_op_Schiphol_aangeko%2C_Bestanddeelnr_927-7110.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/aa/Portugese_minister_Soares_%28voorzitter_Socialistische_Partij%29_op_Schiphol_aangeko%2C_Bestanddeelnr_927-7110.jpg/400px-Portugese_minister_Soares_%28voorzitter_Socialistische_Partij%29_op_Schiphol_aangeko%2C_Bestanddeelnr_927-7110.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3683" data-file-height="2419"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Portugese_minister_Soares_(voorzitter_Socialistische_Partij)_op_Schiphol_aangeko,_Bestanddeelnr_927-7110.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/M%C3%A1rio_Soares" title="Mário Soares">Mário Soares</a> became Portugal's first democratically elected Prime-Minister in 1976.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>After the transition to democracy, Portugal bounced between <a href="/wiki/Socialism" title="Socialism">socialism</a> and adherence to the <a href="/wiki/Neoliberal" class="mw-redirect" title="Neoliberal">neoliberal</a> model. <a href="/wiki/Land_reform" title="Land reform">Land reform</a> and <a href="/wiki/Nationalization" title="Nationalization">nationalizations</a> were enforced; the <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_Constitution" class="mw-redirect" title="Portuguese Constitution">Portuguese Constitution</a> (approved in 1976) was rewritten in order to accommodate socialist and communist principles. Until the constitutional revisions of 1982 and 1989, the constitution was a document with numerous references to socialism, the rights of workers, and the desirability of a <a href="/wiki/Socialist_economy" class="mw-redirect" title="Socialist economy">socialist economy</a>. Portugal's economic situation after the revolution obliged the government to pursue <a href="/wiki/International_Monetary_Fund" title="International Monetary Fund">International Monetary Fund</a> (IMF)-monitored stabilization programs in 1977–78 and 1983–85. </p>
      <p>In 1986, Portugal, along with Spain, joined the <a href="/wiki/European_Economic_Community" title="European Economic Community">European Economic Community</a> (EEC) that later became the European Union (EU). In the following years Portugal's economy progressed considerably as a result of EEC/EU <a href="/wiki/Structural_and_cohesion_funds" class="mw-redirect" title="Structural and cohesion funds">structural and cohesion funds</a> and Portuguese companies' easier access to foreign markets. </p>
      <p>Portugal's last overseas and Asian colonial territory, <a href="/wiki/Macau" title="Macau">Macau</a>, was peacefully handed over to the <a href="/wiki/China" title="China">People's Republic of China (PRC)</a> on December 20, 1999, under the 1987 joint declaration that set the terms for Macau's handover from Portugal to the PRC. In 2002, the independence of <a href="/wiki/East_Timor" title="East Timor">East Timor</a> (Asia) was formally recognized by Portugal, after an incomplete decolonization process that was started in 1975 because of the Carnation Revolution, but interrupted by an <a href="/wiki/Indonesia" title="Indonesia">Indonesian</a> armed invasion and <a href="/wiki/Indonesian_occupation_of_East_Timor" title="Indonesian occupation of East Timor">occupation</a>. </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:312px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Tratado_de_Lisboa_13_12_2007_(081).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/Tratado_de_Lisboa_13_12_2007_%28081%29.jpg/310px-Tratado_de_Lisboa_13_12_2007_%28081%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="310" height="184" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/Tratado_de_Lisboa_13_12_2007_%28081%29.jpg/465px-Tratado_de_Lisboa_13_12_2007_%28081%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/7/7c/Tratado_de_Lisboa_13_12_2007_%28081%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="521" data-file-height="310"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Tratado_de_Lisboa_13_12_2007_(081).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Lisbon" title="Treaty of Lisbon">Treaty of Lisbon</a> was signed in 2007, when Portugal held the presidency for the <a href="/wiki/European_Council" title="European Council">European Council</a>.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>On 26 March 1995, Portugal started to implement <a href="/wiki/Schengen_Area" title="Schengen Area">Schengen Area</a> rules, eliminating border controls with other Schengen members while simultaneously strengthening border controls with non-member states. In 1996 the country was a co-founder of the <a href="/wiki/Community_of_Portuguese_Language_Countries" title="Community of Portuguese Language Countries">Community of Portuguese Language Countries</a> (CPLP) headquartered in Lisbon. In 1996, <a href="/wiki/Jorge_Sampaio" title="Jorge Sampaio">Jorge Sampaio</a> became president. He won <a href="/wiki/2001_Portuguese_presidential_election" title="2001 Portuguese presidential election">re-election</a> in January 2001. <a href="/wiki/Expo_%2798" title="Expo '98">Expo '98</a> took place in Portugal and in 1999 it was one of the founding countries of the <a href="/wiki/Euro" title="Euro">euro</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Eurozone" title="Eurozone">eurozone</a>. On July 5, 2004, <a href="/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_Manuel_Barroso" title="José Manuel Barroso">José Manuel Barroso</a>, then <a href="/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Portugal" title="Prime Minister of Portugal">Prime Minister of Portugal</a>, was nominated <a href="/wiki/President_of_the_European_Commission" title="President of the European Commission">President of the European Commission</a>, the most powerful office in the European Union. On 1 December 2009, the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Lisbon" title="Treaty of Lisbon">Treaty of Lisbon</a> entered into force, after it had been signed by the European Union member states on 13 December 2007 in the <a href="/wiki/Jer%C3%B3nimos_Monastery" title="Jerónimos Monastery">Jerónimos Monastery</a>, in Lisbon, enhancing the efficiency and democratic legitimacy of the Union and improving the coherence of its action. The <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_Ireland" title="Republic of Ireland">Republic of Ireland</a> was the only EU state to hold a democratic referendum on the Lisbon Treaty. It was initially rejected by voters in 2008. </p>
      <p>Economic disruption and an unsustainable growth in <a href="/wiki/Government_debt" title="Government debt">government debt</a> during the <a href="/wiki/Financial_crisis_of_2007%E2%80%932008" title="Financial crisis of 2007–2008">financial crisis of 2007–2008</a> led the country to negotiate in 2011 with the IMF and the European Union, through the <a href="/wiki/European_Financial_Stability_Mechanism" class="mw-redirect" title="European Financial Stability Mechanism">European Financial Stability Mechanism</a> (EFSM) and the <a href="/wiki/European_Financial_Stability_Facility" title="European Financial Stability Facility">European Financial Stability Facility</a> (EFSF), a loan to help the country stabilize its finances. </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Geography">Geography</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Portugal&amp;action=edit&amp;section=16" title="Edit section: Geography">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Geography_of_Portugal" title="Geography of Portugal">Geography of Portugal</a>
      </div> 
      <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r978413945/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">
      <div class="thumb tmulti tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:204px;max-width:204px">
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px">
          <div class="thumbimage">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Portugal_topographic_map-pt.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cd/Portugal_topographic_map-pt.png/200px-Portugal_topographic_map-pt.png" decoding="async" width="200" height="353" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cd/Portugal_topographic_map-pt.png/300px-Portugal_topographic_map-pt.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cd/Portugal_topographic_map-pt.png/400px-Portugal_topographic_map-pt.png 2x" data-file-width="1738" data-file-height="3070"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           Topography and administration.
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The territory of Portugal includes an area on the <a href="/wiki/Iberian_Peninsula" title="Iberian Peninsula">Iberian Peninsula</a> (referred to as <i>the continent</i> by most Portuguese) and two archipelagos in the Atlantic Ocean: the archipelagos of <a href="/wiki/Madeira" title="Madeira">Madeira</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Azores" title="Azores">Azores</a>. It lies between latitudes <a href="/wiki/30th_parallel_north" title="30th parallel north">30°</a> and <a href="/wiki/42nd_parallel_north" title="42nd parallel north">42° N</a>, and longitudes <a href="/wiki/32nd_meridian_west" title="32nd meridian west">32°</a> and <a href="/wiki/6th_meridian_west" title="6th meridian west">6° W</a>. </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Continental_Portugal" title="Continental Portugal">Mainland Portugal</a> is split by its main river, the <a href="/wiki/Tagus" title="Tagus">Tagus</a>, that flows from Spain and disgorges in the <a href="/wiki/Tagus_Estuary_Natural_Reserve" title="Tagus Estuary Natural Reserve">Tagus Estuary</a>, in Lisbon, before escaping into the Atlantic. The northern landscape is mountainous towards the interior with several plateaus indented by river valleys, whereas the south, including the <a href="/wiki/Algarve" title="Algarve">Algarve</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Alentejo" title="Alentejo">Alentejo</a> regions, is characterized by rolling plains.<sup id="cite_ref-96" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-96">[91]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Portugal's highest peak is the similarly named <a href="/wiki/Mount_Pico" title="Mount Pico">Mount Pico</a> on the island of <a href="/wiki/Pico_Island" title="Pico Island">Pico</a> in the Azores. This ancient volcano, which measures 2,351&nbsp;m (7,713&nbsp;ft) is an iconic symbol of the Azores, while the <a href="/wiki/Serra_da_Estrela" title="Serra da Estrela">Serra da Estrela</a> on the mainland (the summit being 1,991&nbsp;m (6,532&nbsp;ft) above sea level) is an important seasonal attraction for skiers and winter sports enthusiasts. </p>
      <p>The archipelagos of Madeira and the Azores are scattered within the Atlantic Ocean: the Azores straddling the <a href="/wiki/Mid-Atlantic_Ridge" title="Mid-Atlantic Ridge">Mid-Atlantic Ridge</a> on a tectonic triple junction, and Madeira along a range formed by <a href="/wiki/Plate_tectonics" title="Plate tectonics">in-plate</a> <a href="/wiki/Hotspot_(geology)" title="Hotspot (geology)">hotspot</a> geology. Geologically, these islands were formed by volcanic and seismic events. The last terrestrial volcanic eruption occurred in 1957–58 (<a href="/wiki/Capelinhos" title="Capelinhos">Capelinhos</a>) and minor earthquakes occur sporadically, usually of low intensity. </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Exclusive_economic_zone_of_Portugal" title="Exclusive economic zone of Portugal">Portugal's exclusive economic zone</a>, a sea zone over which the Portuguese have special rights over the exploration and use of marine resources, has 1,727,408&nbsp;km<sup>2</sup>. This is the 3rd largest <a href="/wiki/Exclusive_economic_zone" title="Exclusive economic zone">exclusive economic zone</a> of the European Union and the 20th largest in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-97" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-97">[92]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Climate">Climate</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Portugal&amp;action=edit&amp;section=17" title="Edit section: Climate">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Climate_of_Portugal" class="mw-redirect" title="Climate of Portugal">Climate of Portugal</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Portugal_K%C3%B6ppen.svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e8/Portugal_K%C3%B6ppen.svg/200px-Portugal_K%C3%B6ppen.svg.png" decoding="async" width="200" height="445" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e8/Portugal_K%C3%B6ppen.svg/300px-Portugal_K%C3%B6ppen.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e8/Portugal_K%C3%B6ppen.svg/400px-Portugal_K%C3%B6ppen.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="765" data-file-height="1701"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Portugal_K%C3%B6ppen.svg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Köppen climate classification map of continental Portugal
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Portugal is mainly characterized by a <a href="/wiki/Mediterranean_climate" title="Mediterranean climate">Mediterranean climate</a> (<i>Csa</i> in the South, central interior, and the <a href="/wiki/Douro" title="Douro">Douro</a> river valley; <i>Csb</i> in the North, Central west and <a href="/wiki/Southwest_Alentejo_and_Vicentine_Coast_Natural_Park" title="Southwest Alentejo and Vicentine Coast Natural Park">Vicentine Coast)</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-98" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-98">[93]</a></sup> but has other climatic characteristics such as a <a href="/wiki/Oceanic_climate" title="Oceanic climate">temperate maritime climate</a> (Cfb) in the mountains located in Northwestern sector (mainland) and also in some high altitude zones of the Azorean islands, a <a href="/wiki/Semi-arid_climate" title="Semi-arid climate">semi-arid climate</a> in certain parts of the <a href="/wiki/Beja_District" title="Beja District">Beja District</a> far south (<i>BSk</i>) and in <a href="/wiki/Porto_Santo_Island" title="Porto Santo Island">Porto Santo Island</a> (BSh), a <a href="/wiki/BWh" class="mw-redirect" title="BWh">warm desert climate</a> (BWh) in the <a href="/wiki/Savage_Islands" title="Savage Islands">Selvagens Islands</a> and a <a href="/wiki/Humid_subtropical_climate" title="Humid subtropical climate">humid subtropical climate</a> in the western <a href="/wiki/Azores" title="Azores">Azores</a> (Cfa), according to the <a href="/wiki/K%C3%B6ppen_climate_classification" title="Köppen climate classification">Köppen-Geiger Climate Classification</a>. It is one of the warmest countries in Europe: the annual average temperature in <a href="/wiki/Mainland_Portugal" class="mw-redirect" title="Mainland Portugal">mainland Portugal</a> varies from 10–12&nbsp;°C (50.0–53.6&nbsp;°F) in the mountainous interior north to 16–18&nbsp;°C (60.8–64.4&nbsp;°F) in the south and on the <a href="/wiki/Guadiana" title="Guadiana">Guadiana</a> <a href="/wiki/River_basin" class="mw-redirect" title="River basin">river basin</a>. There are however, variations from the highlands to the lowlands: Spanish biologist Salvador Rivas Martinez presents several different bioclimatic zones for Portugal.<sup id="cite_ref-99" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-99">[94]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Algarve" title="Algarve">Algarve</a>, separated from the <a href="/wiki/Alentejo" title="Alentejo">Alentejo</a> region by mountains reaching up to 900 metres (3,000&nbsp;ft) in <a href="/wiki/F%C3%B3ia_(mountain)" title="Fóia (mountain)">Alto da Fóia</a>, has a climate similar to that of the southern coastal areas of Spain or Southwest Australia. </p>
      <p>Annual average rainfall in the mainland varies from just over 3,200&nbsp;mm (126.0&nbsp;in) on the <a href="/wiki/Peneda-Ger%C3%AAs_National_Park" title="Peneda-Gerês National Park">Peneda-Gerês National Park</a> to less than 500&nbsp;mm (19.7&nbsp;in) in southern parts of <a href="/wiki/Alentejo" title="Alentejo">Alentejo</a>. <a href="/wiki/Mount_Pico" title="Mount Pico">Mount Pico</a> is recognized as receiving the largest annual rainfall (over 6,250&nbsp;mm (246.1&nbsp;in) per year) in Portugal, according to <i><a href="/wiki/Instituto_Portugu%C3%AAs_do_Mar_e_da_Atmosfera" title="Instituto Português do Mar e da Atmosfera">Instituto Português do Mar e da Atmosfera</a></i>. </p>
      <p>In some areas, such as the Guadiana basin, annual diurnal average temperatures can be as high as 26&nbsp;°C (79&nbsp;°F), and summer's highest temperatures are routinely over 40&nbsp;°C (104&nbsp;°F). The record high of 47.4&nbsp;°C (117.3&nbsp;°F) was recorded in <a href="/wiki/Amareleja" title="Amareleja">Amareleja</a>, although this might not be the hottest spot in summer, according to satellite readings.<sup id="cite_ref-100" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-100">[95]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-101" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-101">[96]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Praia_da_Marinha_(2012-09-27),_by_Klugschnacker_in_Wikipedia_(86).JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bd/Praia_da_Marinha_%282012-09-27%29%2C_by_Klugschnacker_in_Wikipedia_%2886%29.JPG/200px-Praia_da_Marinha_%282012-09-27%29%2C_by_Klugschnacker_in_Wikipedia_%2886%29.JPG" decoding="async" width="200" height="301" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bd/Praia_da_Marinha_%282012-09-27%29%2C_by_Klugschnacker_in_Wikipedia_%2886%29.JPG/300px-Praia_da_Marinha_%282012-09-27%29%2C_by_Klugschnacker_in_Wikipedia_%2886%29.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bd/Praia_da_Marinha_%282012-09-27%29%2C_by_Klugschnacker_in_Wikipedia_%2886%29.JPG/400px-Praia_da_Marinha_%282012-09-27%29%2C_by_Klugschnacker_in_Wikipedia_%2886%29.JPG 2x" data-file-width="2848" data-file-height="4288"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Praia_da_Marinha_(2012-09-27),_by_Klugschnacker_in_Wikipedia_(86).JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The <a href="/wiki/Praia_da_Marinha" title="Praia da Marinha">Marinha Beach</a> in <a href="/wiki/Lagoa,_Algarve" title="Lagoa, Algarve">Lagoa</a>, <a href="/wiki/Algarve" title="Algarve">Algarve</a> is considered by the <a href="/wiki/Michelin_Guide" title="Michelin Guide">Michelin Guide</a> as one of the 10 most beautiful beaches in Europe and as one of the 100 most beautiful beaches in the world.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Snowfalls occur regularly in the winter in the interior North and Centre of the country in districts such as <a href="/wiki/Guarda_District" title="Guarda District">Guarda</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bragan%C3%A7a_District" title="Bragança District">Bragança</a>, <a href="/wiki/Viseu_District" title="Viseu District">Viseu</a> and <a href="/wiki/Vila_Real_District" title="Vila Real District">Vila Real</a>, particularly on the mountains. In winter, temperatures may drop below −10.0&nbsp;°C (14.0&nbsp;°F), particularly in <a href="/wiki/Serra_da_Estrela" title="Serra da Estrela">Serra da Estrela</a>, <a href="/wiki/Serra_do_Ger%C3%AAs" class="mw-redirect" title="Serra do Gerês">Serra do Gerês</a>, <a href="/wiki/Serra_do_Mar%C3%A3o" title="Serra do Marão">Serra do Marão</a> and <a href="/wiki/Montesinho_Natural_Park" title="Montesinho Natural Park">Serra de Montesinho</a>. In these places snow can fall any time from October to May. In the South of the country snowfalls are rare but still occur in the highest elevations. While the official absolute minimum by <a href="/wiki/Instituto_Portugu%C3%AAs_do_Mar_e_da_Atmosfera" title="Instituto Português do Mar e da Atmosfera">IPMA</a> is −16.0&nbsp;°C (3.2&nbsp;°F) in <a href="/wiki/Penhas_da_Sa%C3%BAde" title="Penhas da Saúde">Penhas da Saúde</a> and <a href="/wiki/Miranda_do_Douro" title="Miranda do Douro">Miranda do Douro</a>, lower temperatures have been recorded, such as −17.5&nbsp;°C (0.5&nbsp;°F) by <a href="/wiki/Bragan%C3%A7a,_Portugal" title="Bragança, Portugal">Bragança</a> Polytechnic Institute in the outskirts of the city in 1983, and below −20.0&nbsp;°C (−4.0&nbsp;°F) in Serra da Estrela. </p>
      <p>Continental Portugal has around 2300 to 3200 hours of sunshine a year, an average of 4–6&nbsp;h in winter and 10–12&nbsp;h in the summer, with higher values in the south-east, south-west and the Algarve coast and lower in the north-west. Insolation values are lower in the archipelagos, with around 1600 h in the humid <a href="/wiki/Flores_Island_(Azores)" title="Flores Island (Azores)">Flores Island</a> and around 2300 h in the island of Madeira and Porto Santo. Insolation in the <a href="/wiki/Salvages" class="mw-redirect" title="Salvages">Salvages</a> is thought to be higher due to weaker <a href="/wiki/Orographic_lift" title="Orographic lift">orographic lift</a> and their relative proximity to the <a href="/wiki/Sahara_Desert" class="mw-redirect" title="Sahara Desert">Sahara Desert</a>. </p>
      <p>Portugal's central west and southwest coasts have an extreme ocean <a href="/wiki/Seasonal_lag" title="Seasonal lag">seasonal lag</a>, sea temperatures are warmer in October than in July and are their coldest in March. The average <a href="/wiki/Sea_surface_temperature" title="Sea surface temperature">sea surface temperature</a> on the west coast of mainland Portugal varies from 14–16&nbsp;°C (57.2–60.8&nbsp;°F) in January−March to 19–21&nbsp;°C (66.2–69.8&nbsp;°F) in August−October while on the south coast it ranges from 16&nbsp;°C (60.8&nbsp;°F) in January−March and rises in the summer to about 22–23&nbsp;°C (71.6–73.4&nbsp;°F), occasionally reaching 26&nbsp;°C (78.8&nbsp;°F).<sup id="cite_ref-102" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-102">[97]</a></sup> In the Azores, around 16&nbsp;°C (60.8&nbsp;°F) in February−April to 22–24&nbsp;°C (71.6–75.2&nbsp;°F) in July−September,<sup id="cite_ref-103" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-103">[98]</a></sup> and in Madeira, around 18&nbsp;°C (64.4&nbsp;°F) in February−April to 23–24&nbsp;°C (73.4–75.2&nbsp;°F) in August−October.<sup id="cite_ref-104" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-104">[99]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Both the archipelagos of the Azores and Madeira have a subtropical climate, although variations between islands exist, making weather predictions very difficult (owing to rough topography). The Madeira and Azorean archipelagos have a narrower temperature range, with annual average temperatures exceeding 20&nbsp;°C (68&nbsp;°F) in some parts of the coast (according to the Portuguese Meteorological Institute). Some islands in Azores do have drier months in the summer. Consequently, the islands of the Azores have been identified as having a <a href="/wiki/Mediterranean_Climate" class="mw-redirect" title="Mediterranean Climate">Mediterranean Climate</a> (both <i>Csa</i> and <i>Csb</i> types), while some islands (such as <a href="/wiki/Flores_Island_(Azores)" title="Flores Island (Azores)">Flores</a> or <a href="/wiki/Corvo_Island" title="Corvo Island">Corvo</a>) are classified as <a href="/wiki/Humid_subtropical" class="mw-redirect" title="Humid subtropical">Humid subtropical</a> (<i>Cfa</i>), transitioning into an <a href="/wiki/Oceanic_climate" title="Oceanic climate">Oceanic climate</a> (<i>Cfb</i>) at higher altitudes, according to Köppen-Geiger classification. </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Porto_Santo_Island" title="Porto Santo Island">Porto Santo Island</a> in Madeira has a warm semi-arid climate (<i>BSh</i>). The <a href="/wiki/Savage_Islands" title="Savage Islands">Savage Islands</a>, which are part of the regional territory of Madeira and a nature reserve are unique in being classified as a desert climate (<i>BWh</i>) with an annual average rainfall of approximately 150&nbsp;mm (5.9&nbsp;in). The sea surface temperature in these islands varies from 18.5&nbsp;°C (65.3&nbsp;°F) in winter to 23–24&nbsp;°C (73.4–75.2&nbsp;°F) in the summer occasionally reaching 25&nbsp;°C (77.0&nbsp;°F).<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (March 2017)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Biodiversity">Biodiversity</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Portugal&amp;action=edit&amp;section=18" title="Edit section: Biodiversity">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Geres1.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7a/Geres1.jpg/200px-Geres1.jpg" decoding="async" width="200" height="200" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7a/Geres1.jpg/300px-Geres1.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7a/Geres1.jpg/400px-Geres1.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1024" data-file-height="1024"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Geres1.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Peneda-Ger%C3%AAs_National_Park" title="Peneda-Gerês National Park">Peneda-Gerês National Park</a> is the only nationally designated park in Portugal, owing to the rarity and significance of its environment.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Portugal is home to six terrestrial ecoregions: <a href="/wiki/Azores_temperate_mixed_forests" title="Azores temperate mixed forests">Azores temperate mixed forests</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cantabrian_mixed_forests" title="Cantabrian mixed forests">Cantabrian mixed forests</a>, <a href="/wiki/Madeira_evergreen_forests" title="Madeira evergreen forests">Madeira evergreen forests</a>, <a href="/wiki/Iberian_sclerophyllous_and_semi-deciduous_forests" title="Iberian sclerophyllous and semi-deciduous forests">Iberian sclerophyllous and semi-deciduous forests</a>, <a href="/wiki/Northwest_Iberian_montane_forests" title="Northwest Iberian montane forests">Northwest Iberian montane forests</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Southwest_Iberian_Mediterranean_sclerophyllous_and_mixed_forests" title="Southwest Iberian Mediterranean sclerophyllous and mixed forests">Southwest Iberian Mediterranean sclerophyllous and mixed forests</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-DinersteinOlson2017_105-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-DinersteinOlson2017-105">[100]</a></sup> It had a 2019 <a href="/wiki/Forest_Landscape_Integrity_Index" title="Forest Landscape Integrity Index">Forest Landscape Integrity Index</a> mean score of 0.82/10, ranking it 168<sup>th</sup> globally out of 172 countries.<sup id="cite_ref-FLII-Supplementary_106-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FLII-Supplementary-106">[101]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In <a href="/wiki/Ger%C3%AAs" class="mw-redirect" title="Gerês">Gerês</a> both mature deciduous and coniferous forests can be found, an extremely rare worldwide mature Mediterranean forest remain in some parts of the <a href="/wiki/Arr%C3%A1bida" class="mw-redirect" title="Arrábida">Arrábida</a> mountain and a subtropical <a href="/wiki/Laurissilva" class="mw-redirect" title="Laurissilva">laurissilva</a> forest, dating back to the Tertiary period, covers its largest continuous area in the world in the Madeira main island. Due to the human population decrease and rural exodus, Pyrenean oak and other local native trees are colonizing many abandoned areas. </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Boar" class="mw-redirect" title="Boar">Boar</a>, Iberian red deer, roe deer, and the Iberian wild goat, are reported to have expanded greatly during recent decades. Boars were found recently roaming at night inside large urban areas, like in <a href="/wiki/Setubal" class="mw-redirect" title="Setubal">Setubal</a>. <a href="/wiki/Protected_areas_of_Portugal" title="Protected areas of Portugal">Protected areas of Portugal</a> include one national park, 12 natural parks, nine natural reserves, five natural monuments, and seven protected landscapes, which include the <a href="/wiki/Parque_Nacional_da_Peneda-Ger%C3%AAs" class="mw-redirect" title="Parque Nacional da Peneda-Gerês">Parque Nacional da Peneda-Gerês</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Parque_Natural_da_Serra_da_Estrela" class="mw-redirect" title="Parque Natural da Serra da Estrela">Parque Natural da Serra da Estrela</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Paul_de_Arzila" title="Paul de Arzila">Paul d'Arzila</a>. </p>
      <p>These natural environments are shaped by diverse flora, and include widespread species of pine (especially the <i><a href="/wiki/Pinus_pinaster" title="Pinus pinaster">Pinus pinaster</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Pinus_pinea" class="mw-redirect" title="Pinus pinea">Pinus pinea</a></i> species), the English oak (<i><a href="/wiki/Quercus_robur" title="Quercus robur">Quercus robur</a></i>), the Pyrenean oak (<i><a href="/wiki/Quercus_pyrenaica" title="Quercus pyrenaica">Quercus pyrenaica</a></i>) the chestnut (<i><a href="/wiki/Castanea_sativa" title="Castanea sativa">Castanea sativa</a></i>), the cork-oak (<i><a href="/wiki/Quercus_suber" title="Quercus suber">Quercus suber</a></i>), the holm oak (<i><a href="/wiki/Quercus_ilex" title="Quercus ilex">Quercus ilex</a></i>) or the Portuguese oak (<i><a href="/wiki/Quercus_faginea" title="Quercus faginea">Quercus faginea</a></i>). Due to their economic value, some species of the genus <i>Eucalyptus</i> were introduced and are now common, despite their environmental impact. </p> 
      <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r978413945/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">
      <div class="thumb tmulti tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:292px;max-width:292px">
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:137px;max-width:137px">
          <div class="thumbimage" style="height:99px;overflow:hidden">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Physalia_physalis_Azores.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/22/Physalia_physalis_Azores.jpg/135px-Physalia_physalis_Azores.jpg" decoding="async" width="135" height="101" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/22/Physalia_physalis_Azores.jpg/203px-Physalia_physalis_Azores.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/22/Physalia_physalis_Azores.jpg/270px-Physalia_physalis_Azores.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1600" data-file-height="1200"></a>
          </div>
         </div>
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:151px;max-width:151px">
          <div class="thumbimage" style="height:99px;overflow:hidden">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Chameleo.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/44/Chameleo.jpg/149px-Chameleo.jpg" decoding="async" width="149" height="99" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/44/Chameleo.jpg/224px-Chameleo.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/44/Chameleo.jpg/298px-Chameleo.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3456" data-file-height="2304"></a>
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:139px;max-width:139px">
          <div class="thumbimage" style="height:102px;overflow:hidden">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Band_rumped_storm_petrel_Andre_Raine_KESRP_(21789178016).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6b/Band_rumped_storm_petrel_Andre_Raine_KESRP_%2821789178016%29.jpg/137px-Band_rumped_storm_petrel_Andre_Raine_KESRP_%2821789178016%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="137" height="103" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6b/Band_rumped_storm_petrel_Andre_Raine_KESRP_%2821789178016%29.jpg/206px-Band_rumped_storm_petrel_Andre_Raine_KESRP_%2821789178016%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6b/Band_rumped_storm_petrel_Andre_Raine_KESRP_%2821789178016%29.jpg/274px-Band_rumped_storm_petrel_Andre_Raine_KESRP_%2821789178016%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4000" data-file-height="3000"></a>
          </div>
         </div>
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:149px;max-width:149px">
          <div class="thumbimage" style="height:102px;overflow:hidden">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Linces19.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b1/Linces19.jpg/147px-Linces19.jpg" decoding="async" width="147" height="108" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b1/Linces19.jpg/221px-Linces19.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b1/Linces19.jpg/294px-Linces19.jpg 2x" data-file-width="560" data-file-height="410"></a>
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="trow" style="display:flex">
         <div class="thumbcaption">
          Left-to-right: a <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_man_o%27_war" title="Portuguese man o' war">Portuguese man o' war</a>, a <a href="/wiki/Common_chameleon" title="Common chameleon">common chameleon</a>, a <a href="/wiki/Madeiran_storm_petrel" class="mw-redirect" title="Madeiran storm petrel">Madeiran storm petrel</a>, and an <a href="/wiki/Iberian_lynx" title="Iberian lynx">Iberian lynx</a>. Portugal acts as a meeting point for both <a href="/wiki/Atlantic" class="mw-redirect" title="Atlantic">Atlantic</a> and <a href="/wiki/Mediterranean_Basin" title="Mediterranean Basin">Mediterranean</a> species.
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p><a href="/wiki/Laurisilva" class="mw-redirect" title="Laurisilva">Laurisilva</a> is a unique type of subtropical rainforest, which nowadays, in Europe, is only restricted to the Iberian Peninsula: in the Azores, and in particular on the island of Madeira, there are large forests of endemic <i>Laurisilva</i> (the latter protected as a natural heritage preserve). There are several species of diverse <a href="/wiki/Mammal" title="Mammal">mammalian</a> fauna, including the <a href="/wiki/Red_fox" title="Red fox">red fox</a>, <a href="/wiki/European_badger" title="European badger">European badger</a>, <a href="/wiki/Iberian_lynx" title="Iberian lynx">iberian lynx</a>, <a href="/wiki/Iberian_wolf" title="Iberian wolf">iberian wolf</a>, <a href="/wiki/Wild_goat" title="Wild goat">wild goat</a> (<i><a href="/wiki/Capra_pyrenaica" class="mw-redirect" title="Capra pyrenaica">Capra pyrenaica</a></i>), wild cat (<i><a href="/wiki/Felis_silvestris" class="mw-redirect" title="Felis silvestris">Felis silvestris</a></i>), <a href="/wiki/Granada_hare" title="Granada hare">Granada hare</a>, <a href="/wiki/Weasel" title="Weasel">weasel</a>, <a href="/wiki/European_polecat" title="European polecat">polecat</a>, <a href="/wiki/Common_chameleon" title="Common chameleon">chameleon</a>, <a href="/wiki/Egyptian_mongoose" title="Egyptian mongoose">Egyptian mongoose</a>, <a href="/wiki/Common_genet" title="Common genet">common genet</a>, the occasional <a href="/wiki/Brown_bear" title="Brown bear">brown bear</a><sup id="cite_ref-107" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-107">[102]</a></sup> and many others. Portugal is an important stopover for migratory birds, in places such as <a href="/wiki/Cape_St._Vincent" title="Cape St. Vincent">Cape St. Vincent</a> or the <a href="/wiki/Serra_de_Monchique" title="Serra de Monchique">Monchique</a> mountains, where thousands of birds cross from Europe to Africa during the autumn or in the spring (return migration). </p>
      <p>Most of the avian species congregate along the <a href="/wiki/Iberian_Peninsula" title="Iberian Peninsula">Iberian Peninsula</a> since it is the closest stopover between Northern Europe and Africa. Six hundred bird species occur in Portugal (either for nesting or during the course of migration), and annually there are new registries of nesting species. The archipelagos of the Azores and Madeira are transient stopover for American, European, and African birds, while continental Portugal mostly encounters European and African bird species. </p>
      <p>There are more than 100 freshwater fish species, varying from the giant European catfish (in the <a href="/wiki/Tagus_International_Natural_Park" title="Tagus International Natural Park">Tagus International Natural Park</a>) to some small and endemic species that live only in small lakes (along the western portion of country, for example). Some of these rare and specific species are highly endangered because of habitat loss, pollution and drought. Up-welling along the west coast of Portugal makes the sea extremely rich in nutrients and diverse species of marine fish; the Portuguese marine waters are one of the richest in the world. <a href="/wiki/Marine_fish" class="mw-redirect" title="Marine fish">Marine fish</a> species are more common, and include thousands of species, such as the <a href="/wiki/Sardine" title="Sardine">sardine</a> (<i>Sardina pilchardus</i>), <a href="/wiki/Tuna" title="Tuna">tuna</a> and <a href="/wiki/Atlantic_mackerel" title="Atlantic mackerel">Atlantic mackerel</a>. Bioluminescent species are also well represented (including species in different colour spectrum and forms), like the glowing plankton that are possible to observe on some beaches. </p>
      <p>There are many endemic insect species, most only found in certain parts of Portugal, while other species are more widespread like the <a href="/wiki/Stag_beetle" title="Stag beetle">stag beetle</a> (<i>Lucanus cervus</i>) and the <a href="/wiki/Cicada" title="Cicada">cicada</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Macaronesia" title="Macaronesia">Macaronesian</a> islands (Azores and Madeira) have many endemic species (like birds, reptiles, bats, insects, snails and slugs) that evolved independently from other regions of Portugal. In Madeira, for example, it is possible to observe more than 250 species of land <a href="/wiki/Gastropods" class="mw-redirect" title="Gastropods">gastropods</a>. </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Government_and_politics">Government and politics</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Portugal&amp;action=edit&amp;section=19" title="Edit section: Government and politics">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Government_of_Portugal" title="Government of Portugal">Government of Portugal</a> and <a href="/wiki/Politics_of_Portugal" title="Politics of Portugal">Politics of Portugal</a>
      </div> 
      <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r978413945/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">
      <div class="thumb tmulti tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:212px;max-width:212px">
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:103px;max-width:103px">
          <div class="thumbimage" style="height:143px;overflow:hidden">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Marcelo_Rebelo_de_Sousa_em_fevereiro_de_2018.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/02/Marcelo_Rebelo_de_Sousa_em_fevereiro_de_2018.jpg/101px-Marcelo_Rebelo_de_Sousa_em_fevereiro_de_2018.jpg" decoding="async" width="101" height="141" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/02/Marcelo_Rebelo_de_Sousa_em_fevereiro_de_2018.jpg/152px-Marcelo_Rebelo_de_Sousa_em_fevereiro_de_2018.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/02/Marcelo_Rebelo_de_Sousa_em_fevereiro_de_2018.jpg/202px-Marcelo_Rebelo_de_Sousa_em_fevereiro_de_2018.jpg 2x" data-file-width="317" data-file-height="444"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           <div style="text-align: center;">
            <a href="/wiki/Marcelo_Rebelo_de_Sousa" title="Marcelo Rebelo de Sousa">Marcelo Rebelo de Sousa</a>, <a href="/wiki/List_of_Presidents_of_Portugal" class="mw-redirect" title="List of Presidents of Portugal">20th</a> <a href="/wiki/President_of_Portugal" title="President of Portugal">President of Portugal</a>
           </div>
          </div>
         </div>
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:105px;max-width:105px">
          <div class="thumbimage" style="height:143px;overflow:hidden">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Ant%C3%B3nio_Costa_em_2017.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7a/Ant%C3%B3nio_Costa_em_2017.jpg/103px-Ant%C3%B3nio_Costa_em_2017.jpg" decoding="async" width="103" height="147" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7a/Ant%C3%B3nio_Costa_em_2017.jpg/155px-Ant%C3%B3nio_Costa_em_2017.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7a/Ant%C3%B3nio_Costa_em_2017.jpg/206px-Ant%C3%B3nio_Costa_em_2017.jpg 2x" data-file-width="492" data-file-height="703"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           <div style="text-align: center;">
            <a href="/wiki/Ant%C3%B3nio_Costa" title="António Costa">António Costa</a>, <a href="/wiki/List_of_Prime_Ministers_of_Portugal" class="mw-redirect" title="List of Prime Ministers of Portugal">119th</a> <a href="/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Portugal" title="Prime Minister of Portugal">Prime Minister of Portugal</a>
           </div>
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Portugal has been a <a href="/wiki/Semi-presidential_system" title="Semi-presidential system">semi-presidential</a> <a href="/wiki/Representative_democracy" title="Representative democracy">representative democratic</a> <a href="/wiki/Republic" title="Republic">republic</a> since the ratification of the <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_Constitution_of_1976" class="mw-redirect" title="Portuguese Constitution of 1976">Constitution of 1976</a>, with <a href="/wiki/Lisbon" title="Lisbon">Lisbon</a>, the nation's largest city, as its capital<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (April 2019)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup>. The Constitution grants the division or separation of powers among four bodies referred as "organs of Sovereignty": the <a href="/wiki/President_of_Portugal" title="President of Portugal">President of the Republic</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Government_of_Portugal" title="Government of Portugal">Government</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_parliament" class="mw-redirect" title="Portuguese parliament">Assembly of the Republic</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Judiciary_of_Portugal" title="Judiciary of Portugal">Courts</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-constitution_108-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-constitution-108">[103]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The President, who is elected to a five-year term, has an executive role: the current President is <a href="/wiki/Marcelo_Rebelo_de_Sousa" title="Marcelo Rebelo de Sousa">Marcelo Rebelo de Sousa</a>. The Assembly of the Republic is a single chamber parliament composed of a maximum of 230 deputies elected for a four-year term. The Government is headed by the <a href="/wiki/List_of_Prime_Ministers_of_Portugal" class="mw-redirect" title="List of Prime Ministers of Portugal">Prime Minister</a> (currently <a href="/wiki/Ant%C3%B3nio_Costa" title="António Costa">António Costa</a>) and includes Ministers and Secretaries of State. The <a href="/wiki/Courts" class="mw-redirect" title="Courts">Courts</a> are organized into several levels, among the judicial, administrative and fiscal branches. The <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_Supreme_Court" class="mw-redirect" title="Portuguese Supreme Court">Supreme Courts</a> are institutions of last resort/appeal. A thirteen-member <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_Constitutional_Court" class="mw-redirect" title="Portuguese Constitutional Court">Constitutional Court</a> oversees the constitutionality of the laws. </p>
      <p>Portugal operates a multi-party system of competitive legislatures/local administrative governments at the national, regional and local levels. The Assembly of the Republic, Regional Assemblies and local municipalities and parishes, are dominated by two political parties, the <a href="/wiki/Socialist_Party_(Portugal)" title="Socialist Party (Portugal)">Socialist Party</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Social_Democratic_Party_(Portugal)" title="Social Democratic Party (Portugal)">Social Democratic Party</a>, in addition to the <a href="/wiki/Unitary_Democratic_Coalition" title="Unitary Democratic Coalition">Unitary Democratic Coalition</a> (<a href="/wiki/Portuguese_Communist_Party" title="Portuguese Communist Party">Portuguese Communist Party</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ecologist_Party_%22The_Greens%22" title="Ecologist Party &quot;The Greens&quot;">Ecologist Party "The Greens"</a>), the <a href="/wiki/Left_Bloc" title="Left Bloc">Left Bloc</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Democratic_and_Social_Centre_%E2%80%93_People%27s_Party" class="mw-redirect" title="Democratic and Social Centre – People's Party">Democratic and Social Centre&nbsp;– People's Party</a>, which garner between 5 and 15% of the vote regularly. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Presidency_of_the_Republic">Presidency of the Republic</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Portugal&amp;action=edit&amp;section=20" title="Edit section: Presidency of the Republic">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/President_of_Portugal" title="President of Portugal">President of Portugal</a> and <a href="/wiki/List_of_Presidents_of_Portugal" class="mw-redirect" title="List of Presidents of Portugal">List of Presidents of Portugal</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Lisboa,_Pal%C3%A1cio_Nacional_de_Bel%C3%A9m_(2).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/75/Lisboa%2C_Pal%C3%A1cio_Nacional_de_Bel%C3%A9m_%282%29.jpg/200px-Lisboa%2C_Pal%C3%A1cio_Nacional_de_Bel%C3%A9m_%282%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="200" height="150" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/75/Lisboa%2C_Pal%C3%A1cio_Nacional_de_Bel%C3%A9m_%282%29.jpg/300px-Lisboa%2C_Pal%C3%A1cio_Nacional_de_Bel%C3%A9m_%282%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/75/Lisboa%2C_Pal%C3%A1cio_Nacional_de_Bel%C3%A9m_%282%29.jpg/400px-Lisboa%2C_Pal%C3%A1cio_Nacional_de_Bel%C3%A9m_%282%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2048" data-file-height="1536"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Lisboa,_Pal%C3%A1cio_Nacional_de_Bel%C3%A9m_(2).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Bel%C3%A9m_Palace" title="Belém Palace">Belém Palace</a> serves as the official residence and workplace of the <a href="/wiki/President_of_Portugal" title="President of Portugal">President of the Republic</a>.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The Head of State of Portugal is the <a href="/wiki/President_of_Portugal" title="President of Portugal">President of the Republic</a>, elected to a five-year term by direct, <a href="/wiki/Universal_suffrage" title="Universal suffrage">universal suffrage</a>. He or she has also supervision and <a href="/wiki/Reserve_power" title="Reserve power">reserve powers</a>. Presidential powers include the appointment of the Prime Minister and the other members of the Government (where the President takes into account the results of legislative elections); dismissing the Prime Minister; dissolving the Assembly of the Republic (to call early elections); <a href="/wiki/Veto" title="Veto">vetoing</a> legislation (which may be overridden by the Assembly); and declaring a state of war or siege. The President is also the <i><a href="/wiki/Ex_officio" class="mw-redirect" title="Ex officio">ex officio</a></i> Commander-in-Chief of the Armed Forces. </p>
      <p>The President is advised on issues of importance by the <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_Council_of_State" class="mw-redirect" title="Portuguese Council of State">Council of State</a>, which is composed of six senior civilian officers, any former Presidents elected under the 1976 Constitution, five-members chosen by the Assembly, and five selected by the president. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Government">Government</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Portugal&amp;action=edit&amp;section=21" title="Edit section: Government">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Government_of_Portugal" title="Government of Portugal">Government of Portugal</a>, <a href="/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Portugal" title="Prime Minister of Portugal">Prime Minister of Portugal</a>, and <a href="/wiki/List_of_Prime_Ministers_of_Portugal" class="mw-redirect" title="List of Prime Ministers of Portugal">List of Prime Ministers of Portugal</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:262px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Lisboa_April_2014-15a.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ce/Lisboa_April_2014-15a.jpg/260px-Lisboa_April_2014-15a.jpg" decoding="async" width="260" height="94" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ce/Lisboa_April_2014-15a.jpg/390px-Lisboa_April_2014-15a.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ce/Lisboa_April_2014-15a.jpg/520px-Lisboa_April_2014-15a.jpg 2x" data-file-width="12707" data-file-height="4585"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Lisboa_April_2014-15a.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The <a href="/wiki/Pra%C3%A7a_do_Com%C3%A9rcio" title="Praça do Comércio">Praça do Comércio</a> houses multiple ministries of the <a href="/wiki/Government_of_Portugal" title="Government of Portugal">Government of Portugal</a>.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The Government is headed by the presidentially appointed <a href="/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Portugal" title="Prime Minister of Portugal">Prime Minister</a>, also including one or more Deputy Prime Ministers, Ministers, Secretaries of State and Under-Secretaries of State. </p>
      <p>The Government is both the organ of sovereignty that conducts the general politics of the country and the superior body of the public administration. </p>
      <p>It has essentially Executive powers, but has also limited legislative powers. The Government can legislate about its own organization, about areas covered by legislative authorizations conceded by the Assembly of the Republic and about the specific regulation of generalist laws issued by the Assembly. </p>
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Council_of_Ministers_(Portugal)" title="Council of Ministers (Portugal)">Council of Ministers</a> – under the presidency of the Prime Minister (or the President of Portugal at the latter's request) and the Ministers (may also include one or more Deputy Prime Ministers) – acts as the <a href="/wiki/Cabinet_(government)" title="Cabinet (government)">cabinet</a>. Each government is required to define the broad outline of its policies in a programme, and present it to the Assembly for a mandatory period of debate. The failure of the Assembly to reject the government programme by an absolute majority of deputies confirms the cabinet in office. </p> 
      <div style="clear:both;"></div> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Parliament">Parliament</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Portugal&amp;action=edit&amp;section=22" title="Edit section: Parliament">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Lisbon,_Portugal_(Sharon_Hahn_Darlin)_S%C3%A3o_Bento.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4b/Lisbon%2C_Portugal_%28Sharon_Hahn_Darlin%29_S%C3%A3o_Bento.jpg/220px-Lisbon%2C_Portugal_%28Sharon_Hahn_Darlin%29_S%C3%A3o_Bento.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="143" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4b/Lisbon%2C_Portugal_%28Sharon_Hahn_Darlin%29_S%C3%A3o_Bento.jpg/330px-Lisbon%2C_Portugal_%28Sharon_Hahn_Darlin%29_S%C3%A3o_Bento.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4b/Lisbon%2C_Portugal_%28Sharon_Hahn_Darlin%29_S%C3%A3o_Bento.jpg/440px-Lisbon%2C_Portugal_%28Sharon_Hahn_Darlin%29_S%C3%A3o_Bento.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4044" data-file-height="2621"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Lisbon,_Portugal_(Sharon_Hahn_Darlin)_S%C3%A3o_Bento.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/S%C3%A3o_Bento_Palace" title="São Bento Palace">São Bento Palace</a> is the seat of the <a href="/wiki/Assembly_of_the_Republic_(Portugal)" title="Assembly of the Republic (Portugal)">Portuguese Legislature</a>.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Assembly_of_the_Republic_(Portugal)" title="Assembly of the Republic (Portugal)">Assembly of the Republic (Portugal)</a> and <a href="/wiki/List_of_political_parties_in_Portugal" title="List of political parties in Portugal">List of political parties in Portugal</a>
      </div> 
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Assembly_of_the_Republic_(Portugal)" title="Assembly of the Republic (Portugal)">Assembly of the Republic</a>, in Lisbon, is the national <a href="/wiki/Parliament" title="Parliament">parliament</a> of Portugal. It is the main legislative body, although the Government also has limited legislative powers. </p>
      <p>The Assembly of the Republic is a unicameral body composed of up to 230 deputies. Elected by universal suffrage according to a system of <a href="/wiki/Closed_list" title="Closed list">closed</a> <a href="/wiki/Party-list_proportional_representation" title="Party-list proportional representation">party-list proportional representation</a>, deputies serve four-year terms of office, unless the President dissolves the Assembly and calls for new elections. </p>
      <p>Currently the Government (<a href="/wiki/Socialist_Party_(Portugal)" title="Socialist Party (Portugal)">PS</a>) and the parties supporting it through a <a href="/wiki/Confidence_and_supply" title="Confidence and supply">confidence-and-supply agreement</a> (<a href="/wiki/Left_Bloc" title="Left Bloc">BE</a>, <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_Communist_Party" title="Portuguese Communist Party">PCP</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ecologist_Party_%22The_Greens%22" title="Ecologist Party &quot;The Greens&quot;">PEV</a>) control parliament with the most seats. The <a href="/wiki/Social_Democratic_Party_(Portugal)" title="Social Democratic Party (Portugal)">PSD</a> and <a href="/wiki/CDS_%E2%80%93_People%27s_Party" title="CDS – People's Party">CDS-PP</a> parties form the opposition to the government alongside <a href="/wiki/People%E2%80%93Animals%E2%80%93Nature" class="mw-redirect" title="People–Animals–Nature">PAN</a>, Chega, Iniciativa Liberal and Partido Livre. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Law_and_drug_policy">Law and drug policy</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Portugal&amp;action=edit&amp;section=23" title="Edit section: Law and drug policy">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Campus_Justi%C3%A7a_(cropped).JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/16/Campus_Justi%C3%A7a_%28cropped%29.JPG/220px-Campus_Justi%C3%A7a_%28cropped%29.JPG" decoding="async" width="220" height="158" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/16/Campus_Justi%C3%A7a_%28cropped%29.JPG/330px-Campus_Justi%C3%A7a_%28cropped%29.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/16/Campus_Justi%C3%A7a_%28cropped%29.JPG/440px-Campus_Justi%C3%A7a_%28cropped%29.JPG 2x" data-file-width="1305" data-file-height="940"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Campus_Justi%C3%A7a_(cropped).JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Lisbon's Campus of Justice
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Judiciary_of_Portugal" title="Judiciary of Portugal">Judiciary of Portugal</a>, <a href="/wiki/Law_of_Portugal" title="Law of Portugal">Law of Portugal</a>, <a href="/wiki/Drug_policy_of_Portugal" title="Drug policy of Portugal">Drug policy of Portugal</a>, and <a href="/wiki/LGBT_rights_in_Portugal" title="LGBT rights in Portugal">LGBT rights in Portugal</a>
      </div> 
      <p>The Portuguese legal system is part of the civil law legal system, also called the continental family legal system. The main laws include the Constitution (1976, as amended), the <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_Civil_Code" title="Portuguese Civil Code">Portuguese Civil Code</a> (1966, as amended) and the <a href="/wiki/Penal_Code_of_Portugal" title="Penal Code of Portugal">Penal Code of Portugal</a> (1982, as amended). Other relevant laws are the <i>Commercial Code</i> (1888, as amended) and the <i>Civil Procedure Code</i> (1961, as amended). </p>
      <p>The supreme national courts are the <a href="/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_Justice_(Portugal)" title="Supreme Court of Justice (Portugal)">Supreme Court of Justice</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Constitutional_Court_of_Portugal" class="mw-redirect" title="Constitutional Court of Portugal">Constitutional Court</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Public_Ministry_(Portugal)" class="mw-redirect" title="Public Ministry (Portugal)">Public Ministry</a>, headed by the Attorney General of the Republic, constitutes the independent body of public prosecutors. </p>
      <p>Portuguese laws were applied in the former <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_colonies" class="mw-redirect" title="Portuguese colonies">colonies and territories</a> and continue to be major influences for those countries. </p>
      <p>Portugal was the first country in the world to abolish <a href="/wiki/Life_imprisonment" title="Life imprisonment">life imprisonment</a> (in 1884) and was one of the first countries to <a href="/wiki/Capital_punishment_in_Portugal" title="Capital punishment in Portugal">abolish the death penalty</a>. Maximum jail sentences are limited to 25 years. </p>
      <p>Portugal is also known for having decriminalized the usage of all common drugs in 2001, the first country in the world to do so. Portugal decriminalized possession of effectively all drugs that are still illegal in other developed nations including <a href="/wiki/Cannabis" title="Cannabis">cannabis</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cocaine" title="Cocaine">cocaine</a>, <a href="/wiki/Heroin" title="Heroin">heroin</a>, and <a href="/wiki/LSD" class="mw-redirect" title="LSD">LSD</a>. While possession is legal, trafficking and possession of more than "10 days worth of personal use" are still punishable by jail time and fines. People caught with small amounts of any drug are given the choice to go to a rehab facility, and may refuse treatment without consequences. Despite criticism from other European nations, who stated Portugal's drug consumption would tremendously increase, overall drug use has declined along with the number of <a href="/wiki/HIV" title="HIV">HIV</a> infection cases, which had dropped 50 percent by 2009. Drug use among 16- to 18-year-olds also declined, however the use of marijuana rose only slightly among that age group.<sup id="cite_ref-109" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-109">[104]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-110" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-110">[105]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-111" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-111">[106]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="LGBTI_rights">LGBTI rights</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Portugal&amp;action=edit&amp;section=24" title="Edit section: LGBTI rights">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/LGBT_rights_in_Portugal" title="LGBT rights in Portugal">LGBT rights in Portugal</a>
      </div> 
      <p><a href="/wiki/LGBT_rights_in_Portugal" title="LGBT rights in Portugal">LGBTI rights</a> have increased substantially in the past years. On 27 August 2003, Portugal added the anti-discrimination employment law on the basis of sexual orientation.<sup id="cite_ref-112" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-112">[107]</a></sup> At 24 July 2004, sexual orientation was added to the Constitution as part of the protected from discrimination characteristics.<sup id="cite_ref-113" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-113">[108]</a></sup> On 31 May 2010, Portugal became the sixth country in Europe and the eighth country in the world to legally recognize <a href="/wiki/Same-sex_marriage_in_Portugal" title="Same-sex marriage in Portugal">same-sex marriage</a> at the national level. The law came into force on 5 June 2010.<sup id="cite_ref-autogenerated2_114-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated2-114">[109]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/LGBT_adoption" title="LGBT adoption">Same-sex adoption</a> has been allowed since 1 March 2016<sup id="cite_ref-115" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-115">[110]</a></sup> as is female same-sex couple access to medically assisted reproduction since 13 May 2016.<sup id="cite_ref-116" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-116">[111]</a></sup> This bill was adopted by the Parliament and signed by President <a href="/wiki/Marcelo_Rebelo_de_Sousa" title="Marcelo Rebelo de Sousa">Marcelo Rebelo de Sousa</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-117" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-117">[112]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-118" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-118">[113]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-119" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-119">[114]</a></sup> As of January 2017 the New <i>Law of Gender Identity</i>,<sup id="cite_ref-120" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-120">[115]</a></sup> simplified the legal process of <a href="/wiki/Gender" title="Gender">gender</a> and name change for <a href="/wiki/Transgender" title="Transgender">transgender</a> people, making it easier for minors to change their <a href="/wiki/Sex_marker" class="mw-redirect" title="Sex marker">sex marker</a> in legal documents.<sup id="cite_ref-121" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-121">[116]</a></sup> At August 2018, the right to <a href="/wiki/Gender_identity" title="Gender identity">gender identity</a> and <a href="/wiki/Gender_expression" title="Gender expression">gender expression</a> self-determination became protected, <a href="/wiki/Intersex" title="Intersex">intersex</a> minors became protected by law from unnecessary <a href="/wiki/Intersex_medical_interventions" title="Intersex medical interventions">medical procedures</a> "until the minor gender identity manifests" and the right of protection from discrimination on the basis of <a href="/wiki/Sex_characteristics_(legal_term)" title="Sex characteristics (legal term)">sex characteristics</a> also became protected by the same law.<sup id="cite_ref-122" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-122">[117]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Law_enforcement">Law enforcement</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Portugal&amp;action=edit&amp;section=25" title="Edit section: Law enforcement">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Render_da_Guarda_no_Palacio_de_Belem_22.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ca/Render_da_Guarda_no_Palacio_de_Belem_22.JPG/200px-Render_da_Guarda_no_Palacio_de_Belem_22.JPG" decoding="async" width="200" height="301" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ca/Render_da_Guarda_no_Palacio_de_Belem_22.JPG/300px-Render_da_Guarda_no_Palacio_de_Belem_22.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ca/Render_da_Guarda_no_Palacio_de_Belem_22.JPG/400px-Render_da_Guarda_no_Palacio_de_Belem_22.JPG 2x" data-file-width="2848" data-file-height="4288"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Render_da_Guarda_no_Palacio_de_Belem_22.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>A cavalryman of the <a href="/wiki/National_Republican_Guard_(Portugal)" title="National Republican Guard (Portugal)">National Republican Guard</a>'s honour guard
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Law_enforcement_in_Portugal" title="Law enforcement in Portugal">Law enforcement in Portugal</a>
      </div> 
      <p>Portugal's main police organizations are the <i><a href="/wiki/Guarda_Nacional_Republicana" class="mw-redirect" title="Guarda Nacional Republicana">Guarda Nacional Republicana</a>&nbsp;– GNR</i> (<a href="/wiki/National_Republican_Guard_(Portugal)" title="National Republican Guard (Portugal)">National Republican Guard</a>), a <a href="/wiki/Gendarmerie" title="Gendarmerie">gendarmerie</a>; the <i><a href="/wiki/Pol%C3%ADcia_de_Seguran%C3%A7a_P%C3%BAblica" title="Polícia de Segurança Pública">Polícia de Segurança Pública</a>&nbsp;– PSP</i> (Public Security Police), a civilian police force who work in urban areas; and the <i><a href="/wiki/Pol%C3%ADcia_Judici%C3%A1ria" title="Polícia Judiciária">Polícia Judiciária</a>&nbsp;– PJ</i> (Judicial Police), a highly specialized criminal investigation police that is overseen by the <a href="/wiki/Public_Ministry_(Portugal)" class="mw-redirect" title="Public Ministry (Portugal)">Public Ministry</a>. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Correctional_services">Correctional services</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Portugal&amp;action=edit&amp;section=26" title="Edit section: Correctional services">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <p>Portugal has 49 correctional facilities in total run by the Ministry of Justice. They include 17 central prisons, 4 special prisons, 27 regional prisons, and 1 'Cadeia de Apoio'(Support Detention Centre).<sup id="cite_ref-123" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-123">[118]</a></sup> Their current prison population is about 12,806 inmates, which comes to about 0.12% of their entire population.<sup id="cite_ref-:1_124-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:1-124">[119]</a></sup> Their incarceration rate has been on the rise since 2010, with a 15% increase over the past eight years.<sup id="cite_ref-:1_124-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:1-124">[119]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Administrative_divisions">Administrative divisions</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Portugal&amp;action=edit&amp;section=27" title="Edit section: Administrative divisions">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Administrative_divisions_of_Portugal" title="Administrative divisions of Portugal">Administrative divisions of Portugal</a>
      </div> 
      <p>Administratively, Portugal is divided into 308 <a href="/wiki/Municipalities_of_Portugal" title="Municipalities of Portugal">municipalities</a> (<a href="/wiki/Portuguese_language" title="Portuguese language">Portuguese</a>: <i lang="pt">municípios or <a href="/wiki/Concelhos" class="mw-redirect" title="Concelhos">concelhos</a></i>), which after a reform in <a href="/wiki/2013_Portuguese_local_election" class="mw-redirect" title="2013 Portuguese local election">2013</a> are subdivided into 3,092 civil parishes (<a href="/wiki/Portuguese_language" title="Portuguese language">Portuguese</a>: <i lang="pt"><a href="/wiki/Freguesia" title="Freguesia">freguesia</a></i>). Operationally, the municipality and civil parish, along with the national government, are the only legally <a href="/w/index.php?title=Local_administrative_unit&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Local administrative unit (page does not exist)">local administrative units</a> identified by the government of Portugal (for example, cities, towns or villages have no standing in law, although may be used as catchment for the defining services). For statistical purposes the Portuguese government also identifies <a href="/wiki/Nomenclature_of_Territorial_Units_for_Statistics" title="Nomenclature of Territorial Units for Statistics">Nomenclature of Territorial Units for Statistics</a> (NUTS), inter-municipal communities and informally, the district system, used until European integration (and being phased-out by the national government).<sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:No_original_research" title="Wikipedia:No original research"><span title="The material near this tag possibly contains original research. (February 2016)">original research?</span></a></i>]</sup> Continental Portugal is agglomerated into 18 districts, while the archipelagos of the Azores and Madeira are governed as <a href="/wiki/Autonomous_area" class="mw-redirect" title="Autonomous area">autonomous regions</a>; the largest units, established since 1976, are either <a href="/wiki/Mainland_Portugal" class="mw-redirect" title="Mainland Portugal">mainland Portugal</a> (<a href="/wiki/Portuguese_language" title="Portuguese language">Portuguese</a>: <i lang="pt">Portugal Continental</i>) and the <a href="/wiki/Autonomous_regions_of_Portugal" class="mw-redirect" title="Autonomous regions of Portugal">autonomous regions of Portugal</a> (<a href="/wiki/Azores" title="Azores">Azores</a> and <a href="/wiki/Madeira" title="Madeira">Madeira</a>). </p>
      <p>The 18 districts of mainland Portugal are: <a href="/wiki/Aveiro_District" title="Aveiro District">Aveiro</a>, <a href="/wiki/Beja_District" title="Beja District">Beja</a>, <a href="/wiki/Braga_District" title="Braga District">Braga</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bragan%C3%A7a_District" title="Bragança District">Bragança</a>, <a href="/wiki/Castelo_Branco_District" title="Castelo Branco District">Castelo Branco</a>, <a href="/wiki/Coimbra_District" title="Coimbra District">Coimbra</a>, <a href="/wiki/%C3%89vora_District" title="Évora District">Évora</a>, <a href="/wiki/Faro_District" title="Faro District">Faro</a>, <a href="/wiki/Guarda_District" title="Guarda District">Guarda</a>, <a href="/wiki/Leiria_District" title="Leiria District">Leiria</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lisbon_District" title="Lisbon District">Lisbon</a>, <a href="/wiki/Portalegre_District" title="Portalegre District">Portalegre</a>, <a href="/wiki/Porto_District" title="Porto District">Porto</a>, <a href="/wiki/Santar%C3%A9m_District" title="Santarém District">Santarém</a>, <a href="/wiki/Set%C3%BAbal_District" title="Setúbal District">Setúbal</a>, <a href="/wiki/Viana_do_Castelo_District" title="Viana do Castelo District">Viana do Castelo</a>, <a href="/wiki/Vila_Real_District" title="Vila Real District">Vila Real</a> and <a href="/wiki/Viseu_District" title="Viseu District">Viseu</a>&nbsp;– each district takes the name of the district capital. </p>
      <p>Within the European Union NUTS system, Portugal is divided into seven regions: the <a href="/wiki/Azores" title="Azores">Azores</a>, <a href="/wiki/Alentejo" title="Alentejo">Alentejo</a>, <a href="/wiki/Algarve" title="Algarve">Algarve</a>, <a href="/wiki/Centro,_Portugal" class="mw-redirect" title="Centro, Portugal">Centro</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lisboa_Region" title="Lisboa Region">Lisboa</a>, <a href="/wiki/Madeira" title="Madeira">Madeira</a> and <a href="/wiki/Norte,_Portugal" class="mw-redirect" title="Norte, Portugal">Norte</a>, and with the exception of the Azores and Madeira, NUTS areas are subdivided into 28 subregions. </p> 
      <table class="toccolours" style="width:100%; margin:auto; margin:1px; text-align:center; border-spacing:0; font-size:95%;"> 
       <tbody>
        <tr>

        </tr>
