      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Foreign_relations">Foreign relations</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Portugal&amp;action=edit&amp;section=28" title="Edit section: Foreign relations">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Foreign_relations_of_Portugal" title="Foreign relations of Portugal">Foreign relations of Portugal</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Pal%C3%A1cio_das_Necessidades_1997.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9d/Pal%C3%A1cio_das_Necessidades_1997.JPG/220px-Pal%C3%A1cio_das_Necessidades_1997.JPG" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9d/Pal%C3%A1cio_das_Necessidades_1997.JPG/330px-Pal%C3%A1cio_das_Necessidades_1997.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9d/Pal%C3%A1cio_das_Necessidades_1997.JPG/440px-Pal%C3%A1cio_das_Necessidades_1997.JPG 2x" data-file-width="2608" data-file-height="1952"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Pal%C3%A1cio_das_Necessidades_1997.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Palace_of_Necessidades" class="mw-redirect" title="Palace of Necessidades">Necessidades Palace</a> houses the <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Foreign_Affairs_(Portugal)" title="Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Portugal)">Ministry of Foreign Affairs</a>.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Ant%C3%B3nio_Guterres_2012.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a3/Ant%C3%B3nio_Guterres_2012.jpg/220px-Ant%C3%B3nio_Guterres_2012.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="154" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a3/Ant%C3%B3nio_Guterres_2012.jpg/330px-Ant%C3%B3nio_Guterres_2012.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a3/Ant%C3%B3nio_Guterres_2012.jpg/440px-Ant%C3%B3nio_Guterres_2012.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4858" data-file-height="3396"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Ant%C3%B3nio_Guterres_2012.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Current <a href="/wiki/Secretary-General_of_the_United_Nations" title="Secretary-General of the United Nations">Secretary-General of the United Nations</a> and former Prime Minister <a href="/wiki/Ant%C3%B3nio_Guterres" title="António Guterres">António Guterres</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>A member state of the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations" title="United Nations">United Nations</a> since 1955, Portugal is also a founding member of <a href="/wiki/NATO" title="NATO">NATO</a> (1949), <a href="/wiki/OECD" title="OECD">OECD</a> (1961) and <a href="/wiki/European_Free_Trade_Association" title="European Free Trade Association">EFTA</a> (1960); it left the last in 1986 to join the <a href="/wiki/European_Economic_Community" title="European Economic Community">European Economic Community</a>, which became the European Union in 1993. </p>
      <p>In 1996, Portugal co-founded the <a href="/wiki/Community_of_Portuguese_Language_Countries" title="Community of Portuguese Language Countries">Community of Portuguese Language Countries</a> (CPLP), also known as the Lusophone Commonwealth, an international organization and political association of <a href="/wiki/Lusophone" title="Lusophone">Lusophone</a> nations across four continents, where <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_language" title="Portuguese language">Portuguese</a> is an official language. The global headquarters of the CPLP is in <a href="/wiki/Penafiel_Palace" title="Penafiel Palace">Penafiel Palace</a>, in <a href="/wiki/Lisbon" title="Lisbon">Lisbon</a>. </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Ant%C3%B3nio_Guterres" title="António Guterres">António Guterres</a>, who has served as Prime Minister of Portugal from 1995 to 2002 and <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_High_Commissioner_for_Refugees" title="United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees">UN High Commissioner for Refugees</a> from 2005 to 2015, assumed the post of <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Secretary-General" class="mw-redirect" title="United Nations Secretary-General">UN Secretary-General</a> on 1 January 2017; making him the first Secretary-General from Western Europe since <a href="/wiki/Kurt_Waldheim" title="Kurt Waldheim">Kurt Waldheim</a> of Austria (1972–1981), the first former head of government to become Secretary-General and the first Secretary-General born after the establishment of the United Nations on 26 June 1945. </p>
      <p>In addition, Portugal is a full member of the <a href="/wiki/Latin_Union" title="Latin Union">Latin Union</a> (1983) and the <a href="/wiki/Organization_of_Ibero-American_States" title="Organization of Ibero-American States">Organization of Ibero-American States</a> (1949). It has a friendship alliance and <a href="/wiki/Multiple_citizenship" title="Multiple citizenship">dual citizenship</a> treaty with its former colony, Brazil. Portugal and the <a href="/wiki/United_Kingdom" title="United Kingdom">United Kingdom</a> share the world's oldest active military accord through their <a href="/wiki/Anglo-Portuguese_Alliance" title="Anglo-Portuguese Alliance">Anglo-Portuguese Alliance</a> (<a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Windsor_(1386)" title="Treaty of Windsor (1386)">Treaty of Windsor</a>), which was signed in 1373. </p>
      <p>There are two international territorial disputes, both with Spain: </p> 
      <ul>
       <li><a href="/wiki/Olivenza" title="Olivenza">Olivenza</a>. Under Portuguese sovereignty since 1297, the municipality of Olivenza was ceded to Spain under the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Badajoz_(1801)" title="Treaty of Badajoz (1801)">Treaty of Badajoz</a> in 1801, after the <a href="/wiki/War_of_the_Oranges" title="War of the Oranges">War of the Oranges</a>. Portugal claimed it back in 1815 under the <a href="/wiki/Congress_of_Vienna" title="Congress of Vienna">Treaty of Vienna</a>. However, since the 19th century, it has been continuously ruled by Spain which considers the territory theirs not only <i>de facto</i> but also <i>de jure</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-One-europe.net_2017-09-29_126-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-One-europe.net_2017-09-29-126">[121]</a></sup></li> 
       <li>The Ilhas Selvagens (<a href="/wiki/Savage_Islands" title="Savage Islands">Savage Islands</a>). The archipelago is under Portuguese domination but is geographically closer to the <a href="/wiki/Canary_Islands" title="Canary Islands">Canary Islands</a> (165&nbsp;km) than to <a href="/wiki/Madeira" title="Madeira">Madeira</a> (280&nbsp;km). Found in 1364 by Italian navigators, the islands belonged to private owners until 1971, when the Portuguese government bought them and established a natural reserve area covering the whole archipelago. The islands have been claimed by Spain since 1911 and the dispute has caused some periods of political tension between the two countries. The main problem is not so much their intrinsic value but the fact that they expand the <a href="/wiki/Exclusive_Economic_Zone" class="mw-redirect" title="Exclusive Economic Zone">Exclusive Economic Zone</a> of Portugal considerably to the south.<sup id="cite_ref-Algarvedailynews.com_2017-09-29_127-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Algarvedailynews.com_2017-09-29-127">[122]</a></sup></li>
      </ul> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Military">Military</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Portugal&amp;action=edit&amp;section=29" title="Edit section: Military">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_Armed_Forces" title="Portuguese Armed Forces">Portuguese Armed Forces</a>
      </div> 
      <p>The armed forces have three branches: <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_Navy" title="Portuguese Navy">Navy</a>, <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_Army" title="Portuguese Army">Army</a> and <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_Air_Force" title="Portuguese Air Force">Air Force</a>. They serve primarily as a self-defense force whose mission is to protect the territorial integrity of the country and provide humanitarian assistance and security at home and abroad. As of 2008<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Portugal&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, the three branches numbered 39,200 active personnel including 7,500 women. <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_military_expenditures" title="List of countries by military expenditures">Portuguese military expenditure</a> in 2009 was 5 billion US$,<sup id="cite_ref-128" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-128">[123]</a></sup> representing 2.1 per cent of GDP. Military conscription was abolished in 2004. The minimum age for voluntary recruitment is 18 years. </p>
      <p>The Army (21,000 personnel) comprises three brigades and other small units. An <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_Intervention_Brigade" class="mw-redirect" title="Portuguese Intervention Brigade">infantry brigade</a> (mainly equipped with <a href="/wiki/Pandur_II" title="Pandur II">Pandur II</a> <a href="/wiki/Armoured_personnel_carrier" title="Armoured personnel carrier">APC</a>), a <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_Mechanized_Brigade" class="mw-redirect" title="Portuguese Mechanized Brigade">mechanized brigade</a> (mainly equipped with <a href="/wiki/Leopard_2" title="Leopard 2">Leopard 2 A6</a> tanks and <a href="/wiki/M113" class="mw-redirect" title="M113">M113</a> APC) and a <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_Rapid_Reaction_Brigade" class="mw-redirect" title="Portuguese Rapid Reaction Brigade">Rapid Reaction Brigade</a> (consisting of <a href="/wiki/Paratroopers%27_Regiment" title="Paratroopers' Regiment">paratroopers</a>, <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_Army_Commandos" class="mw-redirect" title="Portuguese Army Commandos">commandos</a> and rangers). The Navy (10,700 personnel, of which 1,580 are <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_Marines" class="mw-redirect" title="Portuguese Marines">marines</a>), the world's oldest surviving naval force, has five frigates, seven corvettes, two submarines, and 28 patrol and auxiliary vessels. The Air Force (7,500 personnel) has the <a href="/wiki/Lockheed_F-16_Fighting_Falcon" class="mw-redirect" title="Lockheed F-16 Fighting Falcon">Lockheed F-16 Fighting Falcon</a> as the main combat aircraft. </p>
      <p>In addition to the three branches of the armed forces, there is the <a href="/wiki/National_Republican_Guard_(Portugal)" title="National Republican Guard (Portugal)">National Republican Guard</a>, a security force subject to military law and organization (<a href="/wiki/Gendarmerie" title="Gendarmerie">gendarmerie</a>) comprising 25,000 personnel. This force is under the authority of both the Defense and the Interior Ministry. It has provided detachments for participation in international operations in Iraq and East Timor. </p> 
      <table class="toccolours" style="float:right; margin:0 0 1em 1em; border:1px #ddd solid;"> 
       <caption>
        <b>Branches of the Portuguese Armed Forces</b> 
       </caption> 
       <tbody>
        <tr style="text-align:center;"> 
         <td style="width:130px;"><a href="/wiki/File:PoA_Chaimite_V-200_convoy_DF-SD-04-08002.JPEG" class="image"><img alt="PoA Chaimite V-200 convoy DF-SD-04-08002.JPEG" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/PoA_Chaimite_V-200_convoy_DF-SD-04-08002.JPEG/150px-PoA_Chaimite_V-200_convoy_DF-SD-04-08002.JPEG" decoding="async" width="150" height="100" class="thumbborder" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/PoA_Chaimite_V-200_convoy_DF-SD-04-08002.JPEG/225px-PoA_Chaimite_V-200_convoy_DF-SD-04-08002.JPEG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/PoA_Chaimite_V-200_convoy_DF-SD-04-08002.JPEG/300px-PoA_Chaimite_V-200_convoy_DF-SD-04-08002.JPEG 2x" data-file-width="1728" data-file-height="1152"></a><br><small><a href="/wiki/Portuguese_Army" title="Portuguese Army">Portuguese Army</a><br><a href="/wiki/Bravia_Chaimite" title="Bravia Chaimite">Chaimite V-200</a></small> </td> 
         <td style="width:130px;"><a href="/wiki/File:POS_Corte_Real_(F_332).jpg" class="image"><img alt="POS Corte Real (F 332).jpg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2b/POS_Corte_Real_%28F_332%29.jpg/150px-POS_Corte_Real_%28F_332%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="150" height="100" class="thumbborder" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2b/POS_Corte_Real_%28F_332%29.jpg/224px-POS_Corte_Real_%28F_332%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2b/POS_Corte_Real_%28F_332%29.jpg/299px-POS_Corte_Real_%28F_332%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3872" data-file-height="2592"></a><br><small><a href="/wiki/Portuguese_Navy" title="Portuguese Navy">Portuguese Navy</a><br><a href="/wiki/MEKO_200" title="MEKO 200">MEKO-200 PN</a></small> </td> 
         <td style="width:130px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Lockheed_F-16A_Fighting_Falcon,_Portugal_-_Air_Force_AN1088466.jpg" class="image"><img alt="Lockheed F-16A Fighting Falcon, Portugal - Air Force AN1088466.jpg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/Lockheed_F-16A_Fighting_Falcon%2C_Portugal_-_Air_Force_AN1088466.jpg/150px-Lockheed_F-16A_Fighting_Falcon%2C_Portugal_-_Air_Force_AN1088466.jpg" decoding="async" width="150" height="100" class="thumbborder" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/Lockheed_F-16A_Fighting_Falcon%2C_Portugal_-_Air_Force_AN1088466.jpg/225px-Lockheed_F-16A_Fighting_Falcon%2C_Portugal_-_Air_Force_AN1088466.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/Lockheed_F-16A_Fighting_Falcon%2C_Portugal_-_Air_Force_AN1088466.jpg/300px-Lockheed_F-16A_Fighting_Falcon%2C_Portugal_-_Air_Force_AN1088466.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1200" data-file-height="800"></a><br><small><a href="/wiki/Portuguese_Air_Force" title="Portuguese Air Force">Portuguese Air Force</a><br><a href="/wiki/General_Dynamics_F-16_Fighting_Falcon" title="General Dynamics F-16 Fighting Falcon">F-16 Fighting Falcon</a></small> </td>
        </tr>
       </tbody>
      </table> 
      <p>The United States maintains a military presence with 770 troops in the <a href="/wiki/Lajes_Air_Base" class="mw-redirect" title="Lajes Air Base">Lajes Air Base</a> at <a href="/wiki/Terceira_Island" title="Terceira Island">Terceira Island</a>, in the Azores. The <a href="/wiki/Allied_Joint_Force_Command_Lisbon" title="Allied Joint Force Command Lisbon">Allied Joint Force Command Lisbon</a> (JFC Lisbon)&nbsp;– one of the three main subdivisions of <a href="/wiki/NATO" title="NATO">NATO</a>'s <a href="/wiki/Allied_Command_Operations" title="Allied Command Operations">Allied Command Operations</a>&nbsp;– it is based in <a href="/wiki/Oeiras_Municipality,_Portugal" class="mw-redirect" title="Oeiras Municipality, Portugal">Oeiras</a>, near Lisbon. </p>
      <p>In the 20th century, Portugal engaged in two major conflicts: <a href="/wiki/Portugal_in_the_Great_War" class="mw-redirect" title="Portugal in the Great War">World War I</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_Colonial_War" title="Portuguese Colonial War">Portuguese Colonial War</a> (1961–1974). After the end of the <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_Empire" title="Portuguese Empire">Portuguese Empire</a> in 1975, the Portuguese Armed Forces have participated in peacekeeping missions in East Timor, Bosnia, Kosovo, Afghanistan, Somalia, Iraq (<a href="/wiki/Nasiriyah" title="Nasiriyah">Nasiriyah</a>), Lebanon, <a href="/wiki/Mali" title="Mali">Mali</a><sup id="cite_ref-129" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-129">[124]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Central_African_Republic" title="Central African Republic">Central African Republic</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-130" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-130">[125]</a></sup> Portugal also conducted several independent unilateral military operations abroad, as were the cases of the interventions of the Portuguese Armed Forces in Angola in 1992 and in Guinea-Bissau in 1998 with the main objectives of protecting and withdrawing of Portuguese and foreign citizens threatened by local civil conflicts. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Government_finance">Government finance</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Portugal&amp;action=edit&amp;section=30" title="Edit section: Government finance">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Further information: <a href="/wiki/2010%E2%80%932014_Portuguese_financial_crisis" title="2010–2014 Portuguese financial crisis">2010–2014 Portuguese financial crisis</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Portuguese_debt_and_EU_average.png" class="image"><img alt="Portuguese debt compared to Eurozone average" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4f/Portuguese_debt_and_EU_average.png/220px-Portuguese_debt_and_EU_average.png" decoding="async" width="220" height="213" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4f/Portuguese_debt_and_EU_average.png/330px-Portuguese_debt_and_EU_average.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4f/Portuguese_debt_and_EU_average.png/440px-Portuguese_debt_and_EU_average.png 2x" data-file-width="703" data-file-height="681"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Portuguese_debt_and_EU_average.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Debt as a percentage of the <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_Portugal" title="Economy of Portugal">economy of Portugal</a>, compared to eurozone average
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The Portuguese government is heavily indebted, and received a 78-billion-euro bailout from the <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">European Union</a> and the <a href="/wiki/International_Monetary_Fund" title="International Monetary Fund">International Monetary Fund</a> in May 2011.<sup id="cite_ref-nytimes_131-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nytimes-131">[126]</a></sup> The ratio of Portugal's debt to its overall economy, was 107 per cent when it received the bailout.<sup id="cite_ref-nytimes_131-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nytimes-131">[126]</a></sup> As part of the deal, the country agreed to cut its budget deficit from 9.8 per cent of GDP in 2010 to 5.9 per cent in 2011, 4.5 per cent in 2012 and 3 per cent in 2013.<sup id="cite_ref-reuters1_132-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-reuters1-132">[127]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>After the bailout was announced, the Portuguese government headed by <a href="/wiki/Pedro_Passos_Coelho" title="Pedro Passos Coelho">Pedro Passos Coelho</a> managed to implement measures with the intention of improving the state's financial situation, including tax hikes, a freeze of civil service-related lower-wages and cuts of higher-wages by 14.3%, on top of the government's spending cuts. The Portuguese government also agreed to eliminate its <a href="/wiki/Golden_share" title="Golden share">golden share</a> in <a href="/wiki/Portugal_Telecom" class="mw-redirect" title="Portugal Telecom">Portugal Telecom</a> which gave it veto power over vital decisions.<sup id="cite_ref-133" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-133">[128]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-134" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-134">[129]</a></sup> In 2012, all public servants had already seen an average wage cut of 20% relative to their 2010 baseline, with cuts reaching 25% for those earning more than 1,500 euro per month.<sup id="cite_ref-135" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-135">[130]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The IMF, the <a href="/wiki/European_Commission" title="European Commission">European Commission</a> (EC) and the <a href="/wiki/European_Central_Bank" title="European Central Bank">European Central Bank</a> (ECB) said in September 2012 that Portugal's debt would peak at 124 per cent of gross domestic product in 2014.<sup id="cite_ref-October_2012_status_136-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-October_2012_status-136">[131]</a></sup> The IMF previously said in July 2012 that Portugal's debt would peak at about 118.5 per cent of GDP in 2013.<sup id="cite_ref-October_2012_status_136-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-October_2012_status-136">[131]</a></sup> In September 2013, the Portuguese Government reviewed again the public debt of Portugal for 2013 to 127.8 per cent, after a peak of 130.9 per cent in that month.<sup id="cite_ref-September_2013_status_137-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-September_2013_status-137">[132]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>A report released in January 2011 by the <a href="/wiki/Di%C3%A1rio_de_Not%C3%ADcias" title="Diário de Notícias">Diário de Notícias</a><sup id="cite_ref-138" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-138">[133]</a></sup> and published in Portugal by <a href="/wiki/Gradiva" title="Gradiva">Gradiva</a>, had demonstrated that in the period between the <a href="/wiki/Carnation_Revolution" title="Carnation Revolution">Carnation Revolution</a> in 1974 and 2010, the democratic <a href="/wiki/Government_of_Portugal" title="Government of Portugal">Portuguese Republic governments</a> encouraged over-expenditure and investment bubbles through unclear <a href="/wiki/Public%E2%80%93private_partnership" title="Public–private partnership">Public–private partnerships</a> and funding of numerous ineffective and unnecessary external consultancy and advisory of committees and firms. This allowed considerable <a href="/wiki/Slippage_(finance)" title="Slippage (finance)">slippage</a> in state-managed <a href="/wiki/Public_works" title="Public works">public works</a> and inflated top management and head officer bonuses and wages. Persistent and lasting recruitment policies boosted the number of redundant public servants. Risky <a href="/wiki/Credit_(finance)" class="mw-redirect" title="Credit (finance)">credit</a>, <a href="/wiki/Public_debt" class="mw-redirect" title="Public debt">public debt</a> creation, and European <a href="/wiki/Structural_and_cohesion_funds" class="mw-redirect" title="Structural and cohesion funds">structural and cohesion funds</a> were mismanaged across almost four decades.<sup id="cite_ref-139" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-139">[134]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Two Portuguese banks, <a href="/wiki/Banco_Portugu%C3%AAs_de_Neg%C3%B3cios" title="Banco Português de Negócios">Banco Português de Negócios</a> (BPN) and <a href="/wiki/Banco_Privado_Portugu%C3%AAs" title="Banco Privado Português">Banco Privado Português</a> (BPP), had been accumulating losses for years due to bad investments, embezzlement and accounting fraud. The case of BPN was particularly serious because of its size, market share, and the political implications – Portugal's then President, Cavaco Silva and some of his political allies, maintained personal and business relationships with the bank and its CEO, who was eventually charged and arrested for fraud and other crimes.<sup id="cite_ref-140" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-140">[135]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-141" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-141">[136]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-142" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-142">[137]</a></sup> On grounds of avoiding a potentially serious financial crisis in the Portuguese economy, the Portuguese government decided to give them a bailout, eventually at a future loss to taxpayers and to the Portuguese people in general. </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Economy">Economy</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Portugal&amp;action=edit&amp;section=31" title="Edit section: Economy">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_Portugal" title="Economy of Portugal">Economy of Portugal</a> and <a href="/wiki/Economic_history_of_Portugal" title="Economic history of Portugal">Economic history of Portugal</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Portugal_Export_Treemap.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/91/Portugal_Export_Treemap.png/220px-Portugal_Export_Treemap.png" decoding="async" width="220" height="172" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/91/Portugal_Export_Treemap.png/330px-Portugal_Export_Treemap.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/91/Portugal_Export_Treemap.png/440px-Portugal_Export_Treemap.png 2x" data-file-width="853" data-file-height="667"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Portugal_Export_Treemap.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>A proportional representation of Portugal's exports, as of 2012<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Portugal&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Portugal is a <a href="/wiki/Developed_country" title="Developed country">developed</a> and a <a href="/wiki/High_income_countries" class="mw-redirect" title="High income countries">high-income country</a>, with a GDP per capita of 77% of the EU28 average in 2017 (increasing from 75% in 2012)<sup id="cite_ref-143" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-143">[138]</a></sup> and a <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_Human_Development_Index" title="List of countries by Human Development Index">HDI</a> of 0.850 (the 40th highest) in 2018.<sup id="cite_ref-144" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-144">[139]</a></sup> By the end of 2018, Portugal's GDP (PPP) was $32,554 per capita, according to OECD's report.<sup id="cite_ref-145" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-145">[140]</a></sup> The national currency of Portugal is the <a href="/wiki/Euro" title="Euro">euro</a> (€), which replaced the <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_Escudo" class="mw-redirect" title="Portuguese Escudo">Portuguese Escudo</a>, and the country was one of the original member states of the <a href="/wiki/Eurozone" title="Eurozone">eurozone</a>. Portugal's central bank is the <i><a href="/wiki/Banco_de_Portugal" title="Banco de Portugal">Banco de Portugal</a></i>, an integral part of the <a href="/wiki/European_System_of_Central_Banks" title="European System of Central Banks">European System of Central Banks</a>. Most industries, businesses and financial institutions are concentrated in the <a href="/wiki/Lisbon_metropolitan_area" title="Lisbon metropolitan area">Lisbon</a> and <a href="/wiki/Greater_Metropolitan_Area_of_Porto" class="mw-redirect" title="Greater Metropolitan Area of Porto">Porto</a> metropolitan areas – the <a href="/wiki/Set%C3%BAbal_District" title="Setúbal District">Setúbal</a>, <a href="/wiki/Aveiro_District" title="Aveiro District">Aveiro</a>, <a href="/wiki/Braga_District" title="Braga District">Braga</a>, <a href="/wiki/Coimbra_District" title="Coimbra District">Coimbra</a> and <a href="/wiki/Leiria_District" title="Leiria District">Leiria</a> districts are the biggest economic centres outside these two main areas. According to World Travel Awards, Portugal was Europe's Leading Golf Destination in 2012 and 2013.<sup id="cite_ref-146" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-146">[141]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-147" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-147">[142]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Avenida_da_Liberdade_(22344060581)_(cropped).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/Avenida_da_Liberdade_%2822344060581%29_%28cropped%29.jpg/220px-Avenida_da_Liberdade_%2822344060581%29_%28cropped%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="264" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/Avenida_da_Liberdade_%2822344060581%29_%28cropped%29.jpg/330px-Avenida_da_Liberdade_%2822344060581%29_%28cropped%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/Avenida_da_Liberdade_%2822344060581%29_%28cropped%29.jpg/440px-Avenida_da_Liberdade_%2822344060581%29_%28cropped%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2612" data-file-height="3133"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Avenida_da_Liberdade_(22344060581)_(cropped).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Avenida_da_Liberdade" title="Avenida da Liberdade">Avenida da Liberdade</a> leading to <a href="/wiki/Marquis_of_Pombal_Square" title="Marquis of Pombal Square">Marquis of Pombal Square</a>, Lisbon, is one of the <a href="/wiki/List_of_most_expensive_streets_by_city" title="List of most expensive streets by city">most expensive shopping streets in Europe</a>.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Since the <a href="/wiki/Carnation_Revolution" title="Carnation Revolution">Carnation Revolution</a> of 1974, which culminated in the end of one of Portugal's most notable <a href="/wiki/Economic_history_of_Portugal" title="Economic history of Portugal">phases of economic expansion</a> (that started in the 1960s),<sup id="cite_ref-148" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-148">[143]</a></sup> a significant change has occurred in the nation's annual economic growth.<sup id="cite_ref-149" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-149">[144]</a></sup> After the turmoil of the 1974 revolution and the <a href="/wiki/Processo_Revolucion%C3%A1rio_Em_Curso" title="Processo Revolucionário Em Curso">PREC</a> period, Portugal tried to adapt to a changing <a href="/wiki/Globalization" title="Globalization">modern global economy</a>, a process that continues in 2013. Since the 1990s, Portugal's <a href="/wiki/Consumption_(economics)" title="Consumption (economics)">public consumption</a>-based <a href="/wiki/Economic_development" title="Economic development">economic development</a> model has been slowly changing to a system that is focused on exports, <a href="/wiki/Investment" title="Investment">private investment</a> and the development of the <a href="/wiki/High-tech" class="mw-redirect" title="High-tech">high-tech</a> sector. Consequently, business services have overtaken more traditional industries such as textiles, clothing, footwear and <a href="/wiki/Cork_(material)" title="Cork (material)">cork</a> (Portugal is the world's leading cork producer),<sup id="cite_ref-150" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-150">[145]</a></sup> wood products and beverages.<sup id="cite_ref-autogenerated1_151-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated1-151">[146]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:November_2011_Austerity_Protest_in_Lisbon,_Portugal.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/61/November_2011_Austerity_Protest_in_Lisbon%2C_Portugal.JPG/220px-November_2011_Austerity_Protest_in_Lisbon%2C_Portugal.JPG" decoding="async" width="220" height="125" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/61/November_2011_Austerity_Protest_in_Lisbon%2C_Portugal.JPG/330px-November_2011_Austerity_Protest_in_Lisbon%2C_Portugal.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/61/November_2011_Austerity_Protest_in_Lisbon%2C_Portugal.JPG/440px-November_2011_Austerity_Protest_in_Lisbon%2C_Portugal.JPG 2x" data-file-width="4592" data-file-height="2615"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:November_2011_Austerity_Protest_in_Lisbon,_Portugal.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>November 2011 protests against austerity measures outside the <a href="/wiki/Assembly_of_the_Republic_(Portugal)" title="Assembly of the Republic (Portugal)">Assembly of the Republic</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>In the second decade of the 21st century, the Portuguese economy suffered its most severe recession since the 1970s, resulting in the country having to be bailed out by the European Commission, European Central Bank and International Monetary Fund (IMF). The bailout, agreed to in 2011, required <a href="/wiki/Portugal_and_the_IMF" class="mw-redirect" title="Portugal and the IMF">Portugal</a> to enter into a range of austerity measures in exchange for funding support of €78,000,000,000. In May 2014, the country exited the bailout but reaffirmed its commitment to maintaining its reformist momentum. At the time of exiting the bailout, the economy had contracted by 0.7% in the first quarter of 2014; however, unemployment, while still high, had fallen to 15.3%.<sup id="cite_ref-PortugalBailoutEnds_152-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-PortugalBailoutEnds-152">[147]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The average salary in Portugal is €910 per month, excluding self-employed individuals<sup id="cite_ref-153" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-153">[148]</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/Minimum_wage" title="Minimum wage">minimum wage</a>, which is regulated by law, is €635 per month (paid 14 times per annum) as of 2020.<sup id="cite_ref-154" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-154">[149]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Global_Competitiveness_Report" title="Global Competitiveness Report">Global Competitiveness Report</a> for 2019, published by the <a href="/wiki/World_Economic_Forum" title="World Economic Forum">World Economic Forum</a>, placed Portugal on the 34th position on the economic index. </p>
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Economist_Intelligence_Unit" title="Economist Intelligence Unit">Economist Intelligence Unit</a>'s quality of life index placed Portugal as the country with the 19th-best quality of life in the world for 2005, ahead of other economically and technologically advanced countries like France, Germany, the United Kingdom and South Korea, but 9 places behind its sole neighbour, Spain.<sup id="cite_ref-155" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-155">[150]</a></sup> This is despite the fact that Portugal remains as one of the countries with the lowest per capita GDP in Western Europe.<sup id="cite_ref-economia.publico.clix.pt_156-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-economia.publico.clix.pt-156">[151]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:292px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Gold_Reserves.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/50/Gold_Reserves.png/290px-Gold_Reserves.png" decoding="async" width="290" height="132" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/50/Gold_Reserves.png/435px-Gold_Reserves.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/50/Gold_Reserves.png/580px-Gold_Reserves.png 2x" data-file-width="3600" data-file-height="1640"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Gold_Reserves.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Portugal has the thirteenth-largest <a href="/wiki/Gold_reserve" title="Gold reserve">gold reserve</a> in the world.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Major <a href="/wiki/Government-owned_corporation" class="mw-redirect" title="Government-owned corporation">state-owned companies</a> include: <a href="/wiki/%C3%81guas_de_Portugal" title="Águas de Portugal">Águas de Portugal</a> (water), <a href="/wiki/Caixa_Geral_de_Dep%C3%B3sitos" title="Caixa Geral de Depósitos">Caixa Geral de Depósitos</a> (banking), <a href="/wiki/Comboios_de_Portugal" title="Comboios de Portugal">Comboios de Portugal</a> (railways), <a href="/wiki/Companhia_das_Lez%C3%ADrias" title="Companhia das Lezírias">Companhia das Lezírias</a> (agriculture) and <a href="/wiki/R%C3%A1dio_e_Televis%C3%A3o_de_Portugal" title="Rádio e Televisão de Portugal">RTP</a> (media). Some former state-owned entities are managed by state-run <a href="/wiki/Holding_company" title="Holding company">holding company</a> <a href="/wiki/Parp%C3%BAblica" title="Parpública">Parpública</a>, which is a <a href="/wiki/Shareholder" title="Shareholder">shareholder</a> of several public and private companies.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (May 2013)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> Among former state-owned companies recently privatized are: <a href="/wiki/CTT_Correios_de_Portugal,_S.A." title="CTT Correios de Portugal, S.A.">CTT</a> (postal service) and <a href="/wiki/ANA_Aeroportos_de_Portugal" title="ANA Aeroportos de Portugal">ANA</a> (airports). </p>
      <p>Companies listed on <a href="/wiki/Euronext_Lisbon" title="Euronext Lisbon">Euronext Lisbon</a> <a href="/wiki/Stock_exchange" title="Stock exchange">stock exchange</a> like <a href="/wiki/Energias_de_Portugal" class="mw-redirect" title="Energias de Portugal">EDP</a>, <a href="/wiki/Galp_Energia" title="Galp Energia">Galp</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jer%C3%B3nimo_Martins" title="Jerónimo Martins">Jerónimo Martins</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mota-Engil" title="Mota-Engil">Mota-Engil</a>, <a href="/wiki/Novabase" title="Novabase">Novabase</a>, <a href="/wiki/Semapa" title="Semapa">Semapa</a>, <a href="/wiki/Portucel_Soporcel" class="mw-redirect" title="Portucel Soporcel">Portucel Soporcel</a>, <a href="/wiki/Portugal_Telecom" class="mw-redirect" title="Portugal Telecom">Portugal Telecom</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sonae" title="Sonae">Sonae</a>, are amongst the largest corporations of Portugal by number of employees, <a href="/wiki/Net_income" title="Net income">net income</a> or international <a href="/wiki/Market_share" title="Market share">market share</a>. The Euronext Lisbon is the major stock exchange of Portugal and is part of the <a href="/wiki/NYSE_Euronext" title="NYSE Euronext">NYSE Euronext</a>, the first global stock exchange. The <a href="/wiki/PSI-20" title="PSI-20">PSI-20</a> is Portugal's most selective and widely known <a href="/wiki/Stock_index" class="mw-redirect" title="Stock index">stock index</a>. </p>
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/International_Monetary_Fund" title="International Monetary Fund">International Monetary Fund</a> issued an update report on the economy of Portugal in late-June 2017 with a strong near-term outlook and an increase in investments and exports over previous years. Because of a surplus in 2016, the country was no longer bound by the Excessive Deficit Procedure which had been implemented during an earlier financial crisis. The banking system was more stable, although there were still non-performing loans and corporate debt. The IMF recommended working on solving these problems for Portugal to be able to attract more private investment. "Sustained strong growth, together with continued public debt reduction, would reduce vulnerabilities arising from high indebtedness, particularly when monetary accommodation is reduced." The <a href="/wiki/OECD" title="OECD">OECD</a> economic reports since 2018 show recovery, albeit slow; and Portugal's growth prospects continue positive for 2020.<sup id="cite_ref-157" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-157">[152]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-158" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-158">[153]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-159" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-159">[154]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Primary_sector">Primary sector</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Portugal&amp;action=edit&amp;section=32" title="Edit section: Primary sector">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Agriculture_in_Portugal" title="Agriculture in Portugal">Agriculture in Portugal</a>, <a href="/wiki/Fishing_in_Portugal" title="Fishing in Portugal">Fishing in Portugal</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mining_in_Portugal" title="Mining in Portugal">Mining in Portugal</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_wine" title="Portuguese wine">Portuguese wine</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:292px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Campilhas_March_2015-1a.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/57/Campilhas_March_2015-1a.jpg/290px-Campilhas_March_2015-1a.jpg" decoding="async" width="290" height="97" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/57/Campilhas_March_2015-1a.jpg/435px-Campilhas_March_2015-1a.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/57/Campilhas_March_2015-1a.jpg/580px-Campilhas_March_2015-1a.jpg 2x" data-file-width="11283" data-file-height="3766"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Campilhas_March_2015-1a.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The <a href="/wiki/Alentejo" title="Alentejo">Alentejo</a> is known as the "bread basket of Portugal", being the country's leading region in wheat and cork production.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p><a href="/wiki/Agriculture_in_Portugal" title="Agriculture in Portugal">Agriculture in Portugal</a> is based on small to medium-sized family-owned dispersed units. However, the sector also includes larger scale <a href="/wiki/Intensive_farming" title="Intensive farming">intensive farming</a> export-oriented <a href="/wiki/Agrobusiness" class="mw-redirect" title="Agrobusiness">agrobusinesses</a> backed by companies (like <a href="/wiki/Grupo_RAR" title="Grupo RAR">Grupo RAR</a>'s <a href="/wiki/Vitacress" title="Vitacress">Vitacress</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sovena" class="mw-redirect" title="Sovena">Sovena</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lactogal" title="Lactogal">Lactogal</a>, <a href="/wiki/Vale_da_Rosa" title="Vale da Rosa">Vale da Rosa</a>, <a href="/wiki/Companhia_das_Lez%C3%ADrias" title="Companhia das Lezírias">Companhia das Lezírias</a> and <a href="/wiki/Valouro" title="Valouro">Valouro</a>). The country produces a wide variety of crops and livestock products, including: <a href="/wiki/Tomato" title="Tomato">tomatoes</a>, <a href="/wiki/Citrus" title="Citrus">citrus</a>, <a href="/wiki/Green_vegetables" class="mw-redirect" title="Green vegetables">green vegetables</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rice" title="Rice">rice</a>, <a href="/wiki/Wheat" title="Wheat">wheat</a>, <a href="/wiki/Barley" title="Barley">barley</a>, <a href="/wiki/Maize" title="Maize">maize</a>, <a href="/wiki/Olive" title="Olive">olives</a>, <a href="/wiki/Oilseed" class="mw-redirect" title="Oilseed">oilseeds</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nut_(fruit)" title="Nut (fruit)">nuts</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cherry" title="Cherry">cherries</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bilberry" title="Bilberry">bilberry</a>, <a href="/wiki/Table_grapes" class="mw-redirect" title="Table grapes">table grapes</a>, <a href="/wiki/Edible_mushroom" title="Edible mushroom">edible mushrooms</a>, <a href="/wiki/Dairy_products" class="mw-redirect" title="Dairy products">dairy products</a>, <a href="/wiki/Poultry" title="Poultry">poultry</a> and <a href="/wiki/Beef" title="Beef">beef</a>. According to <a href="/wiki/FAO" class="mw-redirect" title="FAO">FAO</a>, Portugal is the top producer of <a href="/wiki/Cork_(material)" title="Cork (material)">cork</a> and <a href="/wiki/Carob" title="Carob">carob</a> in the world, accounting to about 50% and 30% of world production respectively.<sup id="cite_ref-160" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-160">[155]</a></sup> </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Forestry" title="Forestry">Forestry</a> has also played an important economic role among the rural communities and industry (namely <a href="/wiki/Paper_industry" class="mw-redirect" title="Paper industry">paper industry</a> that includes <a href="/wiki/Portucel_Soporcel_Group" class="mw-redirect" title="Portucel Soporcel Group">Portucel Soporcel Group</a>, <a href="/wiki/Engineered_wood" title="Engineered wood">engineered wood</a> that includes <a href="/wiki/Sonae_Ind%C3%BAstria" title="Sonae Indústria">Sonae Indústria</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Furniture" title="Furniture">furniture</a> that includes several manufacturing plants in and around <a href="/wiki/Pa%C3%A7os_de_Ferreira" title="Paços de Ferreira">Paços de Ferreira</a>, the core of Portugal's major industrial operations of <a href="/wiki/IKEA" title="IKEA">IKEA</a>). In 2001, the gross agricultural product accounted for 4% of the national GDP. </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Tombstone_of_a_Wine_Maker,_Museu_de_%C3%89vora_-_Apr_2011.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d3/Tombstone_of_a_Wine_Maker%2C_Museu_de_%C3%89vora_-_Apr_2011.jpg/220px-Tombstone_of_a_Wine_Maker%2C_Museu_de_%C3%89vora_-_Apr_2011.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="146" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d3/Tombstone_of_a_Wine_Maker%2C_Museu_de_%C3%89vora_-_Apr_2011.jpg/330px-Tombstone_of_a_Wine_Maker%2C_Museu_de_%C3%89vora_-_Apr_2011.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d3/Tombstone_of_a_Wine_Maker%2C_Museu_de_%C3%89vora_-_Apr_2011.jpg/440px-Tombstone_of_a_Wine_Maker%2C_Museu_de_%C3%89vora_-_Apr_2011.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4288" data-file-height="2848"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Tombstone_of_a_Wine_Maker,_Museu_de_%C3%89vora_-_Apr_2011.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><i>"Cupa"</i>, Roman tombstones into the shape of wooden wine barrels, were used to mark the grave of wine makers in the 3rd century in <a href="/wiki/Alentejo" title="Alentejo">Alentejo</a>, a region to this day renowned for its <a href="/wiki/Alentejo_wine" title="Alentejo wine">wines.</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Traditionally a sea power, Portugal has had a strong tradition in <a href="/wiki/Fishing_in_Portugal" title="Fishing in Portugal">the Portuguese fishing sector</a> and is one of the countries with the highest fish consumption per capita.<sup id="cite_ref-161" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-161">[156]</a></sup> The main landing sites in Portugal (including Azores and Madeira), according to total landings in weight by year, are the harbours of <a href="/wiki/Matosinhos" title="Matosinhos">Matosinhos</a>, <a href="/wiki/Peniche,_Portugal" title="Peniche, Portugal">Peniche</a>, <a href="/wiki/Olh%C3%A3o" title="Olhão">Olhão</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sesimbra" title="Sesimbra">Sesimbra</a>, <a href="/wiki/Figueira_da_Foz" title="Figueira da Foz">Figueira da Foz</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sines,_Portugal" class="mw-redirect" title="Sines, Portugal">Sines</a>, <a href="/wiki/Portim%C3%A3o" title="Portimão">Portimão</a> and <a href="/wiki/Madeira" title="Madeira">Madeira</a>. Portuguese-processed fish products are exported through several companies, under a number of different brands and registered trademarks, such as <a href="/wiki/Conservas_Ramirez" title="Conservas Ramirez">Ramirez</a>, the world's oldest active canned fish producer. </p>
      <p>Portugal is a significant European <a href="/wiki/Minerals" class="mw-redirect" title="Minerals">minerals</a> producer and is ranked among Europe's leading <a href="/wiki/Copper" title="Copper">copper</a> producers. The nation is also a notable producer of <a href="/wiki/Tin" title="Tin">tin</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tungsten" title="Tungsten">tungsten</a> and <a href="/wiki/Uranium" title="Uranium">uranium</a>. However, the country lacks the potential to conduct <a href="/wiki/Hydrocarbon_exploration" title="Hydrocarbon exploration">hydrocarbon exploration</a> and <a href="/wiki/Aluminium" title="Aluminium">aluminium</a>, a limitation that has hindered the development of Portugal's <a href="/wiki/Mining_in_Portugal" title="Mining in Portugal">mining</a> and <a href="/wiki/Metallurgy" title="Metallurgy">metallurgy</a> sectors. Although the country has vast iron and coal reserves – mainly in the north – after the 1974 revolution and the consequent <a href="/wiki/Economic_globalization" title="Economic globalization">economic globalization</a>, low competitiveness forced a decrease in the extraction activity for these minerals. The <a href="/wiki/Panasqueira" title="Panasqueira">Panasqueira</a> and <a href="/wiki/Neves-Corvo_mine" title="Neves-Corvo mine">Neves-Corvo mines</a> are among the most recognized Portuguese mines that are still in operation.<sup id="cite_ref-162" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-162">[157]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Portugal is rich in its <a href="/wiki/Lithium" title="Lithium">lithium</a> subsoil, which is especially concentrated in the districts of <a href="/wiki/Guarda_District" title="Guarda District">Guarda</a>, <a href="/wiki/Viseu" title="Viseu">Viseu</a>, <a href="/wiki/Vila_Real" title="Vila Real">Vila Real</a> and <a href="/wiki/Viana_do_Castelo" title="Viana do Castelo">Viana do Castelo</a>, while most of the country's lithium comes from the Gonçalo aplite-pegmatite field. The largest <a href="/wiki/Lithium" title="Lithium">lithium</a> mine in Europe is operated by Grupo Mota, Felmica, in the Guarda region, which is estimated to have reserves for 30 years of production. It has 5 more deposits in its possession.<sup id="cite_ref-163" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-163">[158]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-164" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-164">[159]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-165" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-165">[160]</a></sup> Savannah Resources in May 2018 announced a 52% increase in the estimated lithium resources at the Mina do Barroso Lithium Project in northern Portugal, saying the country could become the first European supplier of <a href="/wiki/Spodumene" title="Spodumene">spodumene</a>, a lithium-bearing mineral.<sup id="cite_ref-166" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-166">[161]</a></sup> The company said the estimated mineral resources at the mine now stood at 14 million tonnes. Lithium prices have risen in expectation of growing demand for the mineral, which is used in batteries for electric vehicles and for storing electricity from the power grid. Europe consumes more than 20 per cent of the global supply of battery-grade lithium but currently has to import all its supplies of the mineral.<sup id="cite_ref-167" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-167">[162]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>W Resources stated in 2018 that it had started a new drilling campaign at its São Martinho <a href="/wiki/Gold" title="Gold">gold</a> project in Portugal. The so-called reverse circulation drilling program included 15 holes with around 2,000 metres of total drilling. The objective is to extend resources by integrating the data from 2016 drilling results with the expansion expected with the ongoing campaign.<sup id="cite_ref-168" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-168">[163]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-169" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-169">[164]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-170" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-170">[165]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Secondary_sector">Secondary sector</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Portugal&amp;action=edit&amp;section=33" title="Edit section: Secondary sector">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:292px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:F._Portucel_Soporcel.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3b/F._Portucel_Soporcel.jpg/290px-F._Portucel_Soporcel.jpg" decoding="async" width="290" height="102" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3b/F._Portucel_Soporcel.jpg/435px-F._Portucel_Soporcel.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3b/F._Portucel_Soporcel.jpg/580px-F._Portucel_Soporcel.jpg 2x" data-file-width="800" data-file-height="280"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:F._Portucel_Soporcel.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>A <a href="/wiki/Portucel_Soporcel" class="mw-redirect" title="Portucel Soporcel">Portucel Soporcel</a> pulp and paper factory in <a href="/wiki/Set%C3%BAbal,_Portugal" class="mw-redirect" title="Setúbal, Portugal">Setúbal</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Industry is diversified, ranging from <a href="/wiki/Automotive_industry" title="Automotive industry">automotive</a> (<a href="/wiki/Volkswagen_Autoeuropa" title="Volkswagen Autoeuropa">Volkswagen Autoeuropa</a> and <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_Citro%C3%ABn" class="mw-redirect" title="Peugeot Citroën">Peugeot Citroën</a>), <a href="/wiki/Aerospace_industry" class="mw-redirect" title="Aerospace industry">aerospace</a> (<a href="/wiki/Embraer" title="Embraer">Embraer</a> and <a href="/wiki/OGMA" title="OGMA">OGMA</a>), <a href="/wiki/Electronics_industry" title="Electronics industry">electronics</a> and <a href="/wiki/Textile_industry" title="Textile industry">textiles</a>, to <a href="/wiki/Food_industry" title="Food industry">food</a>, <a href="/wiki/Chemical_industry" title="Chemical industry">chemicals</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cement" title="Cement">cement</a> and <a href="/wiki/Wood_pulp" class="mw-redirect" title="Wood pulp">wood pulp</a>. Volkswagen Group's <a href="/wiki/AutoEuropa" class="mw-redirect" title="AutoEuropa">AutoEuropa</a> motor vehicle assembly plant in <a href="/wiki/Palmela" title="Palmela">Palmela</a> is among the largest <a href="/wiki/Foreign_direct_investment" title="Foreign direct investment">foreign direct investment</a> projects in Portugal. Modern non-traditional technology-based industries, such as <a href="/wiki/Aerospace" title="Aerospace">aerospace</a>, <a href="/wiki/Biotechnology" title="Biotechnology">biotechnology</a> and <a href="/wiki/Information_technology" title="Information technology">information technology</a>, have been developed in several locations across the country. <a href="/wiki/Alverca" class="mw-redirect" title="Alverca">Alverca</a>, <a href="/wiki/Covilh%C3%A3" title="Covilhã">Covilhã</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-171" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-171">[166]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/%C3%89vora" title="Évora">Évora</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-172" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-172">[167]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Ponte_de_Sor" title="Ponte de Sor">Ponte de Sor</a> are the main centres of the Portuguese aerospace industry, which is led by Brazil-based company Embraer and the Portuguese company OGMA. Following the turn of the 21st century, many major biotechnology and information technology industries have been founded, and are concentrated in the metropolitan areas of <a href="/wiki/Lisbon_metropolitan_area" title="Lisbon metropolitan area">Lisbon</a>, <a href="/wiki/Porto_Metropolitan_Area" class="mw-redirect" title="Porto Metropolitan Area">Porto</a>, <a href="/wiki/Braga" title="Braga">Braga</a>, <a href="/wiki/Coimbra" title="Coimbra">Coimbra</a> and <a href="/wiki/Aveiro,_Portugal" title="Aveiro, Portugal">Aveiro</a>.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (May 2013)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Tertiary_sector">Tertiary sector</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Portugal&amp;action=edit&amp;section=34" title="Edit section: Tertiary sector">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Tourism_in_Portugal" title="Tourism in Portugal">Tourism in Portugal</a>
      </div> 
      <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r978413945/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">
      <div class="thumb tmulti tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:292px;max-width:292px">
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:145px;max-width:145px">

          </div>
         </div>
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:143px;max-width:143px">

          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:144px;max-width:144px">
          <div class="thumbimage" style="height:94px;overflow:hidden">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Aveiro_Canal.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d3/Aveiro_Canal.jpg/142px-Aveiro_Canal.jpg" decoding="async" width="142" height="95" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d3/Aveiro_Canal.jpg/213px-Aveiro_Canal.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d3/Aveiro_Canal.jpg/284px-Aveiro_Canal.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4592" data-file-height="3056"></a>
          </div>
         </div>
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:144px;max-width:144px">
