          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="trow" style="display:flex">
         <div class="thumbcaption">
          Left-to-right: A view of <a href="/wiki/Estoril" title="Estoril">Estoril</a>, in <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_Riviera" title="Portuguese Riviera">Portuguese Riviera</a>; a view of <a href="/wiki/Nazar%C3%A9,_Portugal" title="Nazaré, Portugal">Nazaré</a>, in <a href="/wiki/Estremadura_Province_(historical)" title="Estremadura Province (historical)">Estremadura</a>; the canals of <a href="/wiki/Aveiro,_Portugal" title="Aveiro, Portugal">Aveiro</a>, in <a href="/wiki/Beira_Litoral_Province" title="Beira Litoral Province">Beira Litoral</a>; <a href="/wiki/Pena_National_Palace" class="mw-redirect" title="Pena National Palace">Pena National Palace</a>, in <a href="/wiki/Sintra,_Portugal" class="mw-redirect" title="Sintra, Portugal">Sintra</a>
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The banking and insurance sectors performed well until the <a href="/wiki/Financial_crisis_of_2007%E2%80%932008" title="Financial crisis of 2007–2008">financial crisis of 2007–2008</a>, and this partly reflected a rapid deepening of the market in Portugal. While sensitive to various types of market and underwriting <a href="/wiki/Risk" title="Risk">risks</a>, it has been estimated that overall both the life and non-life sectors will be able to withstand a number of severe shocks, even though the impact on individual insurers varies widely.<sup id="cite_ref-173" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-173">[168]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Travel and <a href="/wiki/Tourism_in_Portugal" title="Tourism in Portugal">tourism</a> continue to be extremely important for Portugal. It has been necessary for the country to focus upon its niche attractions, such as health, nature and rural tourism, to stay ahead of its competitors.<sup id="cite_ref-174" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-174">[169]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Portugal is among the top 20 most-visited countries in the world, receiving an average of 20,000,000 foreign tourists each year.<sup id="cite_ref-175" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-175">[170]</a></sup> In 2014, Portugal was elected <i>The Best European Country</i> by <a href="/wiki/USA_Today" title="USA Today">USA Today</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-176" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-176">[171]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In 2017, Portugal was elected both <i>Europe's Leading Destination</i><sup id="cite_ref-177" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-177">[172]</a></sup> and in 2018 and 2019, <i>World's Leading Destination</i><sup id="cite_ref-178" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-178">[173]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Tourist hotspots in Portugal are: <a href="/wiki/Lisbon" title="Lisbon">Lisbon</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cascais" title="Cascais">Cascais</a>, <a href="/wiki/F%C3%A1tima,_Portugal" title="Fátima, Portugal">Fatima</a>, <a href="/wiki/Algarve" title="Algarve">Algarve</a>, <a href="/wiki/Madeira" title="Madeira">Madeira</a>, <a href="/wiki/Porto" title="Porto">Porto</a> and <a href="/wiki/Coimbra" title="Coimbra">Coimbra</a>. Lisbon attracts the sixteenth-most tourists among European cities<sup id="cite_ref-179" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-179">[174]</a></sup> (with seven million tourists occupying the city's hotels in 2006).<sup id="cite_ref-180" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-180">[175]</a></sup> Notable luxury destinations include the <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_Riviera" title="Portuguese Riviera">Portuguese Riviera</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Comporta" title="Comporta">Comporta Coast</a>. </p>
      <p> Also, between 5–6 million religious pilgrims visit <a href="/wiki/F%C3%A1tima,_Portugal" title="Fátima, Portugal">Fatima</a> each year, where apparitions of the Blessed Virgin Mary to three shepherd children reportedly took place in 1917. The <a href="/wiki/Sanctuary_of_F%C3%A1tima" title="Sanctuary of Fátima">Sanctuary of Our Lady of Fatima</a> is one of the largest Roman Catholic shrines in the world. The Portuguese government continues to promote and develop new tourist destinations, such as the <a href="/wiki/Douro" title="Douro">Douro Valley</a>, the island of <a href="/wiki/Porto_Santo_Island" title="Porto Santo Island">Porto Santo</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Alentejo" title="Alentejo">Alentejo</a>.</p>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:PA2900302_galo_emiliarocha_medio.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3b/PA2900302_galo_emiliarocha_medio.jpg/220px-PA2900302_galo_emiliarocha_medio.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="240" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3b/PA2900302_galo_emiliarocha_medio.jpg/330px-PA2900302_galo_emiliarocha_medio.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3b/PA2900302_galo_emiliarocha_medio.jpg/440px-PA2900302_galo_emiliarocha_medio.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1499" data-file-height="1638"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:PA2900302_galo_emiliarocha_medio.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Barcelos rooster, an iconic Portuguese souvenir
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The legend of the <a href="/wiki/Rooster_of_Barcelos" title="Rooster of Barcelos">Rooster of Barcelos</a> tells the story of a dead rooster's miraculous intervention in proving the innocence of a man who had been falsely accused and sentenced to death. The story is associated with the 17th-century <a href="/wiki/Calvary_(sculpture)" title="Calvary (sculpture)">calvary</a> that is part of the collection of the Archaeological Museum located in Paço dos Condes, a gothic-style palace in <a href="/wiki/Barcelos,_Portugal" title="Barcelos, Portugal">Barcelos</a>, a city in northwest Portugal. The <a href="/wiki/Rooster_of_Barcelos" title="Rooster of Barcelos">Rooster of Barcelos</a> is bought by thousands of tourists as a national <a href="/wiki/Souvenir" title="Souvenir">souvenir</a>. </p>
      <p>On 30 November 2016, the United Nations added the Portuguese <i lang="pt" title="Portuguese-language text">Bisalhães</i> tradition of making black pottery to the UNESCO Heritage Protection List.<sup id="cite_ref-181" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-181">[176]</a></sup> On 7 December 2017, the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations" title="United Nations">United Nations</a> added the <i>Bonecos de Estremoz</i> – <i>Toys of <a href="/wiki/Estremoz" title="Estremoz">Estremoz</a></i> tradition as an <a href="/wiki/UNESCO_Intangible_Cultural_Heritage_Lists" title="UNESCO Intangible Cultural Heritage Lists">UNESCO Intangible Cultural Heritage</a> of Humankind.<sup id="cite_ref-182" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-182">[177]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Quaternary_sector">Quaternary sector</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Portugal&amp;action=edit&amp;section=35" title="Edit section: Quaternary sector">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r978413945/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">
      <div class="thumb tmulti tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:204px;max-width:204px">
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px">
          <div class="thumbimage">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Nanotecnologia.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/57/Nanotecnologia.jpg/200px-Nanotecnologia.jpg" decoding="async" width="200" height="103" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/57/Nanotecnologia.jpg/300px-Nanotecnologia.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/57/Nanotecnologia.jpg/400px-Nanotecnologia.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3616" data-file-height="1856"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           The <a href="/wiki/International_Iberian_Nanotechnology_Laboratory" title="International Iberian Nanotechnology Laboratory">International Iberian Nanotechnology Laboratory</a>, created in 2005, is based in <a href="/wiki/Braga" title="Braga">Braga</a>.
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px">
          <div class="thumbimage">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Fotooal.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/81/Fotooal.jpg/200px-Fotooal.jpg" decoding="async" width="200" height="151" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/81/Fotooal.jpg/300px-Fotooal.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/81/Fotooal.jpg/400px-Fotooal.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3442" data-file-height="2592"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           The <i><a href="/wiki/Lisbon_Astronomical_Observatory" title="Lisbon Astronomical Observatory">Observatório Astronómico de Lisboa</a></i> is Portugal's oldest (1878) astronomical observatory.
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px">
          <div class="thumbimage">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Champalimaud_Centre_for_the_Unknown_(26).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/aa/Champalimaud_Centre_for_the_Unknown_%2826%29.jpg/200px-Champalimaud_Centre_for_the_Unknown_%2826%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="200" height="150" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/aa/Champalimaud_Centre_for_the_Unknown_%2826%29.jpg/300px-Champalimaud_Centre_for_the_Unknown_%2826%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/aa/Champalimaud_Centre_for_the_Unknown_%2826%29.jpg/400px-Champalimaud_Centre_for_the_Unknown_%2826%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4320" data-file-height="3240"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           The <a href="/wiki/Champalimaud_Foundation" title="Champalimaud Foundation">Champalimaud Foundation</a>, in <a href="/wiki/Lisbon" title="Lisbon">Lisbon</a>, is one of the world's leading medical research centres.
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Science_and_technology_in_Portugal" title="Science and technology in Portugal">Science and technology in Portugal</a>
      </div> 
      <p>Scientific and technological research activities in Portugal are mainly conducted within a network of <a href="/wiki/R%26D" class="mw-redirect" title="R&amp;D">R&amp;D</a> units belonging to <a href="/wiki/List_of_universities_in_Portugal" class="mw-redirect" title="List of universities in Portugal">public universities</a> and state-managed autonomous research institutions like the <a href="/wiki/Instituto_Nacional_de_Engenharia,_Tecnologia_e_Inova%C3%A7%C3%A3o" title="Instituto Nacional de Engenharia, Tecnologia e Inovação">INETI&nbsp;– Instituto Nacional de Engenharia, Tecnologia e Inovação</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Instituto_Nacional_dos_Recursos_Biol%C3%B3gicos" title="Instituto Nacional dos Recursos Biológicos">INRB&nbsp;– Instituto Nacional dos Recursos Biológicos</a>. The funding and management of this research system is mainly conducted under the authority of the <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Science,_Technology_and_Higher_Education" title="Ministry of Science, Technology and Higher Education">Ministry of Science, Technology and Higher Education</a> (MCTES) and the MCTES's <a href="/wiki/Funda%C3%A7%C3%A3o_para_a_Ci%C3%AAncia_e_Tecnologia" title="Fundação para a Ciência e Tecnologia">Fundação para a Ciência e Tecnologia</a> (FCT). </p>
      <p>The largest R&amp;D units of the public universities by volume of research grants and peer-reviewed publications, include <a href="/wiki/Biosciences" class="mw-redirect" title="Biosciences">biosciences</a> research institutions like the <a href="/wiki/Instituto_de_Medicina_Molecular" title="Instituto de Medicina Molecular">Instituto de Medicina Molecular</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Centre_for_Neuroscience_and_Cell_Biology" title="Centre for Neuroscience and Cell Biology">Centre for Neuroscience and Cell Biology</a>, the <a href="/wiki/IPATIMUP" class="mw-redirect" title="IPATIMUP">IPATIMUP</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Instituto_de_Biologia_Molecular_e_Celular" title="Instituto de Biologia Molecular e Celular">Instituto de Biologia Molecular e Celular</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Abel_Salazar_Biomedical_Sciences_Institute" title="Abel Salazar Biomedical Sciences Institute">Abel Salazar Biomedical Sciences Institute</a>. </p>
      <p>Among the largest non-state-run research institutions in Portugal are the <a href="/wiki/Instituto_Gulbenkian_de_Ci%C3%AAncia" title="Instituto Gulbenkian de Ciência">Instituto Gulbenkian de Ciência</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Champalimaud_Foundation" title="Champalimaud Foundation">Champalimaud Foundation</a>, a neuroscience and oncology research centre which awards every year one of the highest monetary prizes of any science prize in the world. A number of both national and multinational high-tech and industrial companies, are also responsible for research and development projects. One of the oldest learned societies of Portugal is the <a href="/wiki/Sciences_Academy_of_Lisbon" class="mw-redirect" title="Sciences Academy of Lisbon">Sciences Academy of Lisbon</a>, founded in 1779. </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Iberian_peninsula" class="mw-redirect" title="Iberian peninsula">Iberian</a> bilateral state-supported research efforts include the <a href="/wiki/International_Iberian_Nanotechnology_Laboratory" title="International Iberian Nanotechnology Laboratory">International Iberian Nanotechnology Laboratory</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Ibercivis" title="Ibercivis">Ibercivis</a> <a href="/wiki/Distributed_computing" title="Distributed computing">distributed computing</a> platform, which are joint research programmes of both Portugal and Spain. Portugal is a member of several pan-European scientific organizations. These include the <a href="/wiki/European_Space_Agency" title="European Space Agency">European Space Agency</a> (ESA), the <a href="/wiki/European_Laboratory_for_Particle_Physics" class="mw-redirect" title="European Laboratory for Particle Physics">European Laboratory for Particle Physics</a> (CERN), <a href="/wiki/ITER" title="ITER">ITER</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/European_Southern_Observatory" title="European Southern Observatory">European Southern Observatory</a> (ESO). </p>
      <p>Portugal has the largest <a href="/wiki/Aquarium" title="Aquarium">aquarium</a> in Europe, the <a href="/wiki/Lisbon_Oceanarium" title="Lisbon Oceanarium">Lisbon Oceanarium</a>, and the Portuguese have several other notable organizations focused on science-related exhibits and divulgation, like the state agency <i>Ciência Viva</i>, a programme of the Portuguese Ministry of Science and Technology to the promotion of a scientific and technological culture among the Portuguese population,<sup id="cite_ref-183" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-183">[178]</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/Science_Museum_of_the_University_of_Coimbra" title="Science Museum of the University of Coimbra">Science Museum of the University of Coimbra</a>, the <a href="/wiki/List_of_natural_history_museums#Portugal" title="List of natural history museums">National Museum of Natural History</a> at the University of Lisbon, and the <a href="/wiki/Visionarium_(Portugal)" title="Visionarium (Portugal)">Visionarium</a>. With the emergence and growth of several <a href="/wiki/Science_park" title="Science park">science parks</a> throughout the world that helped create many thousands of scientific, technological and knowledge-based businesses, Portugal started to develop several<sup id="cite_ref-184" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-184">[179]</a></sup> science parks across the country. These include the <a href="/wiki/Taguspark" title="Taguspark">Taguspark</a> (in <a href="/wiki/Oeiras_Municipality,_Portugal" class="mw-redirect" title="Oeiras Municipality, Portugal">Oeiras</a>), the <a href="/wiki/Coimbra_iParque" title="Coimbra iParque">Coimbra iParque</a> (in <a href="/wiki/Coimbra" title="Coimbra">Coimbra</a>), the <a href="/wiki/Biocant" title="Biocant">biocant</a> (in <a href="/wiki/Cantanhede_Municipality" class="mw-redirect" title="Cantanhede Municipality">Cantanhede</a>), the <a href="/wiki/Madeira_Tecnopolo" title="Madeira Tecnopolo">Madeira Tecnopolo</a><sup id="cite_ref-185" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-185">[180]</a></sup> (in <a href="/wiki/Funchal" title="Funchal">Funchal</a>), <a href="/wiki/Sines_Tecnopolo" title="Sines Tecnopolo">Sines Tecnopolo</a><sup id="cite_ref-186" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-186">[181]</a></sup> (in <a href="/wiki/Sines,_Portugal" class="mw-redirect" title="Sines, Portugal">Sines</a>), Tecmaia<sup id="cite_ref-187" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-187">[182]</a></sup> (in <a href="/wiki/Maia_Municipality" class="mw-redirect" title="Maia Municipality">Maia</a>) and <a href="/wiki/Parkurbis" title="Parkurbis">Parkurbis</a><sup id="cite_ref-188" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-188">[183]</a></sup> (in <a href="/wiki/Covilh%C3%A3" title="Covilhã">Covilhã</a>). Companies locate in the Portuguese science parks to take advantage of a variety of services ranging from financial and legal advice through to marketing and technological support. </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Egas_Moniz" class="mw-redirect" title="Egas Moniz">Egas Moniz</a>, a Portuguese physician who developed the <a href="/wiki/Cerebral_angiography" title="Cerebral angiography">cerebral angiography</a> and <a href="/wiki/Leucotomy" class="mw-redirect" title="Leucotomy">leucotomy</a>, received in 1949 the <a href="/wiki/Nobel_Prize_in_Physiology_or_Medicine" title="Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine">Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine</a>&nbsp;– he is the first Portuguese recipient of a <a href="/wiki/Nobel_Prize" title="Nobel Prize">Nobel Prize</a> and the only in the sciences. </p>
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/European_Innovation_Scoreboard" class="mw-redirect" title="European Innovation Scoreboard">European Innovation Scoreboard</a> 2011, placed Portugal-based innovation in the 15th position, with an impressive increase in innovation expenditure and output.<sup id="cite_ref-189" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-189">[184]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Transport">Transport</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Portugal&amp;action=edit&amp;section=36" title="Edit section: Transport">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Transport_in_Portugal" title="Transport in Portugal">Transport in Portugal</a>
      </div> 
      <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r978413945/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">
      <div class="thumb tmulti tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:204px;max-width:204px">
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px">
          <div class="thumbimage">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Vasco_da_Gama_Bridge_03.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/Vasco_da_Gama_Bridge_03.JPG/200px-Vasco_da_Gama_Bridge_03.JPG" decoding="async" width="200" height="133" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/Vasco_da_Gama_Bridge_03.JPG/300px-Vasco_da_Gama_Bridge_03.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/Vasco_da_Gama_Bridge_03.JPG/400px-Vasco_da_Gama_Bridge_03.JPG 2x" data-file-width="1024" data-file-height="683"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           <a href="/wiki/Vasco_da_Gama_Bridge" title="Vasco da Gama Bridge">Vasco da Gama Bridge</a> is longest bridge in the <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">European Union</a>.
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px">
          <div class="thumbimage">
           <a href="/wiki/File:TAP_Air_Portugal_Airbus_A320-214;_CS-TNJ@FNC;12.07.2011_607bc_(5940056994).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/96/TAP_Air_Portugal_Airbus_A320-214%3B_CS-TNJ%40FNC%3B12.07.2011_607bc_%285940056994%29.jpg/200px-TAP_Air_Portugal_Airbus_A320-214%3B_CS-TNJ%40FNC%3B12.07.2011_607bc_%285940056994%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="200" height="129" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/96/TAP_Air_Portugal_Airbus_A320-214%3B_CS-TNJ%40FNC%3B12.07.2011_607bc_%285940056994%29.jpg/300px-TAP_Air_Portugal_Airbus_A320-214%3B_CS-TNJ%40FNC%3B12.07.2011_607bc_%285940056994%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/96/TAP_Air_Portugal_Airbus_A320-214%3B_CS-TNJ%40FNC%3B12.07.2011_607bc_%285940056994%29.jpg/400px-TAP_Air_Portugal_Airbus_A320-214%3B_CS-TNJ%40FNC%3B12.07.2011_607bc_%285940056994%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2459" data-file-height="1590"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           A <a href="/wiki/TAP_Air_Portugal" title="TAP Air Portugal">TAP Air Portugal</a> aircraft 
           <br>(<a href="/wiki/Airbus" title="Airbus">Airbus</a> <a href="/wiki/Airbus_A320_family" title="Airbus A320 family">A320-214</a>)
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px">
          <div class="thumbimage">
           <a href="/wiki/File:HPIM0530.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/96/HPIM0530.JPG/200px-HPIM0530.JPG" decoding="async" width="200" height="150" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/96/HPIM0530.JPG/300px-HPIM0530.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/96/HPIM0530.JPG/400px-HPIM0530.JPG 2x" data-file-width="1200" data-file-height="900"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           The <a href="/wiki/Lisbon_Metro" title="Lisbon Metro">Lisbon Metro</a> is Portugal's oldest and largest subway system.
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>By the early-1970s, Portugal's <a href="/wiki/Economic_history_of_Portugal" title="Economic history of Portugal">fast economic growth</a> with increasing <a href="/wiki/Mass_consumption" class="mw-redirect" title="Mass consumption">consumption</a> and purchase of new automobiles set the priority for improvements in transportation. Again in the 1990s, after joining the <a href="/wiki/European_Economic_Community" title="European Economic Community">European Economic Community</a>, the country built many new motorways. Today, the country has a 68,732&nbsp;km (42,708&nbsp;mi) road network, of which almost 3,000&nbsp;km (1,864&nbsp;mi) are part of system of 44 motorways. Opened in 1944, the first motorway (which linked Lisbon to the National Stadium) was an innovative project that made Portugal one of the first countries in the world to establish a motorway (this roadway eventually became the Lisbon-Cascais highway, or A5). </p>
      <p>Although a few other tracts were created (around 1960 and 1970), it was only after the beginning of the 1980s that large-scale motorway construction was implemented. In 1972, <a href="/wiki/BRISA_Auto-estradas_de_Portugal_S.A." class="mw-redirect" title="BRISA Auto-estradas de Portugal S.A.">Brisa</a>, the highway concessionaire, was founded to handle the management of many of the region's motorways. On many highways, a toll needs to be paid (see <a href="/wiki/Via_Verde" title="Via Verde">Via Verde</a>). <a href="/wiki/Vasco_da_Gama_bridge" class="mw-redirect" title="Vasco da Gama bridge">Vasco da Gama bridge</a> is the longest bridge in Europe at 12.345&nbsp;km.<sup id="cite_ref-190" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-190">[185]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-191" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-191">[186]</a></sup> </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Continental_Portugal" title="Continental Portugal">Continental Portugal</a>'s 89,015&nbsp;km<sup>2</sup> (34,369&nbsp;sq&nbsp;mi) territory is serviced by four international airports located near the principal cities of <a href="/wiki/Lisbon" title="Lisbon">Lisbon</a>, <a href="/wiki/Porto" title="Porto">Porto</a>, <a href="/wiki/Faro,_Portugal" title="Faro, Portugal">Faro</a> and <a href="/wiki/Beja_(Portugal)" class="mw-redirect" title="Beja (Portugal)">Beja</a>. Lisbon's geographical position makes it a stopover for many foreign airlines at several airports within the country. The primary <a href="/wiki/Flag-carrier" class="mw-redirect" title="Flag-carrier">flag-carrier</a> is <a href="/wiki/TAP_Air_Portugal" title="TAP Air Portugal">TAP Air Portugal</a>, although many other domestic airlines provide services within and without the country. The government decided to build a new airport outside Lisbon, in <a href="/wiki/Alcochete" title="Alcochete">Alcochete</a>, to replace <a href="/wiki/Lisbon_Portela_Airport" class="mw-redirect" title="Lisbon Portela Airport">Lisbon Portela Airport</a>, though this plan has been suspended due to austerity measures. Currently, the most important airports are in <a href="/wiki/Portela_Airport" class="mw-redirect" title="Portela Airport">Lisbon</a>, <a href="/wiki/Francisco_S%C3%A1_Carneiro_Airport" class="mw-redirect" title="Francisco Sá Carneiro Airport">Porto</a>, <a href="/wiki/Faro_Airport" title="Faro Airport">Faro</a>, <a href="/wiki/Madeira_Airport" class="mw-redirect" title="Madeira Airport">Funchal</a> (Madeira), and <a href="/wiki/Jo%C3%A3o_Paulo_II_Airport" title="João Paulo II Airport">Ponta Delgada</a> (Azores), managed by the national airport authority group <a href="/wiki/ANA_%E2%80%93_Aeroportos_de_Portugal" class="mw-redirect" title="ANA – Aeroportos de Portugal">ANA&nbsp;– Aeroportos de Portugal</a>. One other important airport is the Aeroporto Internacional das Lajes on the island of Terceira in the Azores. This airport serves as one of two international airports serving countries outside the European Union for all nine islands of the Azores. It also serves as a military air base for the United States Air Force. The base remains in use to the present day. </p>
      <p>A national railway system that extends throughout the country and into Spain, is supported and administered by <a href="/wiki/Comboios_de_Portugal" title="Comboios de Portugal">Comboios de Portugal</a> (CP). <a href="/wiki/Rail_transport" title="Rail transport">Rail transport</a> of passengers and goods is derived using the 2,791&nbsp;km (1,734&nbsp;mi) of railway lines currently in service, of which 1,430&nbsp;km (889&nbsp;mi) are electrified and about 900&nbsp;km (559&nbsp;mi) allow train speeds greater than 120&nbsp;km/h (75&nbsp;mph). The railway network is managed by <a href="/wiki/Infraestruturas_de_Portugal" title="Infraestruturas de Portugal">Infraestruturas de Portugal</a> while the transport of passengers and goods are the responsibility of CP, both public companies. In 2006, the CP carried 133,000,000 passengers and 9,750,000 <a href="/wiki/Tonne" title="Tonne">tonnes</a> (9,600,000 <a href="/wiki/Long_ton" title="Long ton">long tons</a>; 10,700,000 <a href="/wiki/Short_ton" title="Short ton">short tons</a>) of goods. </p>
      <p>The major seaports are located in <a href="/wiki/Sines,_Portugal" class="mw-redirect" title="Sines, Portugal">Sines</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lisbon" title="Lisbon">Lisbon</a>, <a href="/wiki/Leix%C3%B5es" title="Leixões">Leixões</a>, <a href="/wiki/Set%C3%BAbal" title="Setúbal">Setúbal</a>, <a href="/wiki/Aveiro,_Portugal" title="Aveiro, Portugal">Aveiro</a>, <a href="/wiki/Figueira_da_Foz" title="Figueira da Foz">Figueira da Foz</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Faro,_Portugal" title="Faro, Portugal">Faro</a>. </p>
      <p>The two largest metropolitan areas have subway systems: <a href="/wiki/Lisbon_Metro" title="Lisbon Metro">Lisbon Metro</a> and <i>Metro Sul do Tejo</i> in the <a href="/wiki/Lisbon_metropolitan_area" title="Lisbon metropolitan area">Lisbon metropolitan area</a> and <a href="/wiki/Porto_Metro" title="Porto Metro">Porto Metro</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Porto_Metropolitan_Area" class="mw-redirect" title="Porto Metropolitan Area">Porto Metropolitan Area</a>, each with more than 35&nbsp;km (22&nbsp;mi) of lines. In Portugal, <a href="/wiki/Trams_in_Lisbon" title="Trams in Lisbon">Lisbon tram services</a> have been supplied by the <i>Companhia de Carris de Ferro de Lisboa</i> (<a href="/wiki/Carris" title="Carris">Carris</a>), for over a century. In <a href="/wiki/Porto" title="Porto">Porto</a>, <a href="/wiki/Trams_in_Porto" title="Trams in Porto">a tram network</a>, of which only a tourist line on the shores of the <a href="/wiki/Douro" title="Douro">Douro</a> remains, began construction on 12 September 1895 (a first for the <a href="/wiki/Iberian_Peninsula" title="Iberian Peninsula">Iberian Peninsula</a>). All major cities and towns have their own local urban transport network, as well as taxi services. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Energy">Energy</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Portugal&amp;action=edit&amp;section=37" title="Edit section: Energy">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Energy_in_Portugal" title="Energy in Portugal">Energy in Portugal</a>
      </div> 
      <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r978413945/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">
      <div class="thumb tmulti tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:204px;max-width:204px">
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px">
          <div class="thumbimage">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Paul_da_Serra,_Madeira_-_Jan_2012_-_07.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/42/Paul_da_Serra%2C_Madeira_-_Jan_2012_-_07.jpg/200px-Paul_da_Serra%2C_Madeira_-_Jan_2012_-_07.jpg" decoding="async" width="200" height="112" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/42/Paul_da_Serra%2C_Madeira_-_Jan_2012_-_07.jpg/300px-Paul_da_Serra%2C_Madeira_-_Jan_2012_-_07.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/42/Paul_da_Serra%2C_Madeira_-_Jan_2012_-_07.jpg/400px-Paul_da_Serra%2C_Madeira_-_Jan_2012_-_07.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4000" data-file-height="2248"></a>
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px">
          <div class="thumbimage">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Alqueva_dam.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/82/Alqueva_dam.JPG/200px-Alqueva_dam.JPG" decoding="async" width="200" height="150" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/82/Alqueva_dam.JPG/300px-Alqueva_dam.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/82/Alqueva_dam.JPG/400px-Alqueva_dam.JPG 2x" data-file-width="1600" data-file-height="1200"></a>
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="trow" style="display:flex">
         <div class="thumbcaption">
          Solar farms in Madeira (top) and <a href="/wiki/Alqueva_Dam" title="Alqueva Dam">Alqueva Hydroelectric Dam</a> (bottom)
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Portugal has considerable resources of wind and river power, the two most cost-effective renewable energy sources. Since the turn of the 21st century, there has been a trend towards the development of a renewable resource industry and reduction of both consumption and use of fossil fuels. In 2006, the world's largest <a href="/wiki/Solar_energy" title="Solar energy">solar power</a> plant at that date, the <a href="/wiki/Moura_Photovoltaic_Power_Station" title="Moura Photovoltaic Power Station">Moura Photovoltaic Power Station</a>, began operating near <a href="/wiki/Moura,_Portugal" title="Moura, Portugal">Moura</a>, in the south, while the world's first commercial <a href="/wiki/Wave_power" title="Wave power">wave power</a> farm, the <a href="/wiki/Agu%C3%A7adoura_Wave_Farm" title="Aguçadoura Wave Farm">Aguçadoura Wave Farm</a>, opened in the <a href="/wiki/Norte_Region,_Portugal" title="Norte Region, Portugal">Norte region</a> (2008). By the end of 2006, 66% of the country's electrical production was from coal and fuel power plants, while 29% were derived from <a href="/wiki/Hydroelectric" class="mw-redirect" title="Hydroelectric">hydroelectric</a> dams, and 6% by <a href="/wiki/Wind_energy" class="mw-redirect" title="Wind energy">wind energy</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-192" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-192">[187]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In 2008, renewable energy resources were producing 43% of the nation's consumption of electricity, even as hydroelectric production decreased with severe droughts.<sup id="cite_ref-193" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-193">[188]</a></sup> As of June 2010, electricity exports had outnumbered imports. In the period between January and May 2010, 70% of the national production of energy came from renewable sources.<sup id="cite_ref-194" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-194">[189]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Portugal's national energy transmission company, <a href="/wiki/Redes_Energ%C3%A9ticas_Nacionais" title="Redes Energéticas Nacionais">Redes Energéticas Nacionais</a> (REN), uses sophisticated modelling to predict weather, especially wind patterns, and computer programs to calculate energy from the various renewable-energy plants. Before the solar/wind revolution, Portugal had generated electricity from hydropower plants on its rivers for decades. New programmes combine wind and water: wind-driven turbines pump water uphill at night, the most blustery period; then the water flows downhill by day, generating electricity, when consumer demand is highest. Portugal's distribution system is also now a two-way street. Instead of just delivering electricity, it draws electricity from even the smallest generators, like rooftop solar panels. The government aggressively encouraged such contributions by setting a premium price for those who buy rooftop-generated solar electricity. </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Demographics">Demographics</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Portugal&amp;action=edit&amp;section=38" title="Edit section: Demographics">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Demographics_of_Portugal" title="Demographics of Portugal">Demographics of Portugal</a>
      </div> 
      <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r978413945/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">
      <div class="thumb tmulti tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:204px;max-width:204px">
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px">
          <div class="thumbimage">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Viana_do_Castelo,_Portugal_(4922364383).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/70/Viana_do_Castelo%2C_Portugal_%284922364383%29.jpg/200px-Viana_do_Castelo%2C_Portugal_%284922364383%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="200" height="150" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/70/Viana_do_Castelo%2C_Portugal_%284922364383%29.jpg/300px-Viana_do_Castelo%2C_Portugal_%284922364383%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/70/Viana_do_Castelo%2C_Portugal_%284922364383%29.jpg/400px-Viana_do_Castelo%2C_Portugal_%284922364383%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2369" data-file-height="1777"></a>
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px">
          <div class="thumbimage">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Fado1_-_Fadistas_a_los_Jeronimos.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/72/Fado1_-_Fadistas_a_los_Jeronimos.JPG/200px-Fado1_-_Fadistas_a_los_Jeronimos.JPG" decoding="async" width="200" height="150" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/72/Fado1_-_Fadistas_a_los_Jeronimos.JPG/300px-Fado1_-_Fadistas_a_los_Jeronimos.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/72/Fado1_-_Fadistas_a_los_Jeronimos.JPG/400px-Fado1_-_Fadistas_a_los_Jeronimos.JPG 2x" data-file-width="2272" data-file-height="1704"></a>
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="trow" style="display:flex">
         <div class="thumbcaption">
          Young people in traditional attire from <a href="/wiki/Minho_(province)" class="mw-redirect" title="Minho (province)">Minho</a> (top) and <a href="/wiki/Fado" title="Fado">fadistas</a> playing at <a href="/wiki/Jer%C3%B3nimos_Monastery" title="Jerónimos Monastery">Jerónimos Monastery</a> (bottom)
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The Statistics Portugal (<a href="/wiki/Portuguese_language" title="Portuguese language">Portuguese</a>: <i lang="pt">INE – <a href="/wiki/Instituto_Nacional_de_Estat%C3%ADstica_(Portugal)" title="Instituto Nacional de Estatística (Portugal)">Instituto Nacional de Estatística</a></i>) estimates that, according to the 2011 census, the population was 10,562,178 (of which 52% was female, 48% was male). In 2019 and according to more up-to-date figures, the population decreased to 10,295,909, although it was an increase compared with 2018.<sup id="cite_ref-auto2_10-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto2-10">[7]</a></sup> This population has been relatively homogeneous for most of its history: a single religion (Roman Catholicism) and a single language have contributed to this ethnic and national unity.<sup id="cite_ref-195" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-195">[190]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The most important demographic influence in the modern Portuguese seems to be the oldest one; current interpretation of <a href="/wiki/Y-chromosome" class="mw-redirect" title="Y-chromosome">Y-chromosome</a> and <a href="/wiki/MtDNA" class="mw-redirect" title="MtDNA">mtDNA</a> data suggests that the Portuguese have their origin in <a href="/wiki/Paleolithic" title="Paleolithic">Paleolithic</a> peoples that began arriving to the European continent around 45,000 years ago. All subsequent migrations did leave an impact, genetically and culturally, but the main population source of the Portuguese is still Paleolithic. Genetic studies show Portuguese populations not to be significantly different from other European populations.<sup id="cite_ref-196" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-196">[191]</a></sup> Portuguese people have a preponderancy of genetics (Iron Age Period)<sup id="cite_ref-:0_197-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:0-197">[192]</a></sup> which belong to R1b haplogroup family along with <a href="/wiki/Brittonic_languages" title="Brittonic languages">Brythonic</a>, <a href="/wiki/Alpine_states" title="Alpine states">Alpine</a> and <a href="/wiki/Goidelic_languages" title="Goidelic languages">Goidelic</a> genetical markers. Also expectable but not so common are South European (Sardinian, Italian and Balkans), Broadly Northwestern (West Germanic) and to a lesser extent British/Irish (Brythonic/Gaelic) and French (Alpine). With a low confidence range there are Scandinavian and East European genetical markers.<sup id="cite_ref-:0_197-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:0-197">[192]</a></sup> Other sources would point out a small presence of <a href="/wiki/Berbers" title="Berbers">Berber</a> and Jewish that would be also part of a low confidence region.<sup id="cite_ref-198" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-198">[193]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Native Portuguese are an <a href="/wiki/Iberian_Peninsula" title="Iberian Peninsula">Iberian</a> ethnic group and they form 95% of the whole population, whose ancestry is very similar to <a href="/wiki/Spaniards" title="Spaniards">Spaniards</a> and have strong ties with fellow <a href="/wiki/Atlantic_Europe" title="Atlantic Europe">Atlantic Arc countries</a> like Ireland, British Isles, France and Belgium due to maritime trade dated as far back as the Bronze Age. These maritime contacts and the prevalence of R1b haplogroup as the main genetical marker of these countries suggest a common ancestry and cultural proximity. Other maritime contacts with the Mediterranean especially with Greeks, Phoenicians, Romans and Moors add some particular phenotypes in Southern Portugal and particularly Southern Spain (<a href="/wiki/Tartessos" title="Tartessos">Tartessos</a> culture) making Portugal and Northwestern Spain a bridge between North Western Europe and the Mediterranean but maintaining the <a href="/wiki/Atlantic" class="mw-redirect" title="Atlantic">Atlantic</a> character. </p>
      <p>Despite the good economic development in the past three decades the Portuguese were the shortest in Europe since 1890. This emerging height gap took place in the 1840s and has increased since. One of the driving factors was the modest real wage development, given the late industrialization and economic growth in Portugal compared to the European core. Another determinant was the delayed <a href="/wiki/Human_capital" title="Human capital">human capital</a> formation.<sup id="cite_ref-199" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-199">[194]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Bev%C3%B6lkerungspyramide_Portugal_2016.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/28/Bev%C3%B6lkerungspyramide_Portugal_2016.png/220px-Bev%C3%B6lkerungspyramide_Portugal_2016.png" decoding="async" width="220" height="153" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/28/Bev%C3%B6lkerungspyramide_Portugal_2016.png/330px-Bev%C3%B6lkerungspyramide_Portugal_2016.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/28/Bev%C3%B6lkerungspyramide_Portugal_2016.png/440px-Bev%C3%B6lkerungspyramide_Portugal_2016.png 2x" data-file-width="610" data-file-height="425"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Bev%C3%B6lkerungspyramide_Portugal_2016.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Population pyramid (2016)
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The total fertility rate (TFR) as of 2015<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Portugal&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup> was estimated at 1.52 children born/woman, one of the lowest in the world, which is below the replacement rate of 2.1,<sup id="cite_ref-200" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-200">[195]</a></sup> it remains considerably below the high of 5.02 children born per woman in 1911.<sup id="cite_ref-201" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-201">[196]</a></sup> In 2016, 52.8% of births were to unmarried women.<sup id="cite_ref-202" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-202">[197]</a></sup> Like most Western countries, Portugal has to deal with low fertility levels: the country has experienced a <a href="/wiki/Sub-replacement_fertility_rate" class="mw-redirect" title="Sub-replacement fertility rate">sub-replacement fertility rate</a> since the 1980s.<sup id="cite_ref-203" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-203">[198]</a></sup> Portugal subsequently has the 17th oldest population in the world, with the average age of 43.7 years.<sup id="cite_ref-204" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-204">[199]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The structure of Portuguese society is characterized by a significant inequality which in 2016 placed the country in the lowest seventh of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Social_Justice_Index&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Social Justice Index (page does not exist)">Social Justice Index</a> for the European Union.<sup id="cite_ref-205" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-205">[200]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Portugal's parliament in 2018 approved a budget plan for 2019 that includes tax breaks for returning emigrants in a bid to lure back those who left during the <a href="/wiki/Financial_crisis_of_2007%E2%80%932008" title="Financial crisis of 2007–2008">financial crisis of 2007–2008</a>. The expansionary 2019 budget, backed by a <a href="/wiki/Left-wing" class="mw-redirect" title="Left-wing">left-wing</a> majority in parliament, also aims to boost the purchasing power of households while cutting the already low deficit even further. <a href="/wiki/Circular_migration" title="Circular migration">Returning emigrants</a> will be allowed to declare only half their taxable income for five years if they return, provided they lived abroad for at least three years. The "Return Programme" is to run for two years. Around 500,000 residents left Portugal between 2010 and 2015 after the <a href="/wiki/Great_Recession" title="Great Recession">Great Recession</a>. Although some 350,000 have since returned, Lisbon wants to tempt the rest to come home – in a similar scheme to the Irish one.<sup id="cite_ref-206" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-206">[201]</a></sup> Portugal has approved a credit line for Portuguese emigrants aiming to invest in the country on their return. Furthermore, Emigrants returning in 2019 and 2020 will see their taxes halved as part of the stimulus to bring native Portuguese back and revitalize the population and promote continued economic growth <sup id="cite_ref-207" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-207">[202]</a></sup> – as Portugal struggles with a low birth rate and an <a href="/wiki/Ageing_population" class="mw-redirect" title="Ageing population">ageing population</a>. According to projections by the national statistics office, Portugal's population will fall to 7.7 million by 2080 from 10.3 million now and the population will continue to age.<sup id="cite_ref-208" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-208">[203]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Urbanization">Urbanization</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Portugal&amp;action=edit&amp;section=39" title="Edit section: Urbanization">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <table class="navbox"> 
       <tbody>
        <tr> 
         <th colspan="10" class="navbox-title">
          <div style="float:right; width:6em; height:2.6em">
           &nbsp;

           </ul>
          </div> 
          <div style="height:2.6em;line-height:1.3em;">
           <span style="font-size:110%;">Largest cities or towns in Portugal</span>
           <br>
           <div style="display:inline;font-weight:normal;">
            <a href="/wiki/Instituto_Nacional_de_Estat%C3%ADstica_(Portugal)" title="Instituto Nacional de Estatística (Portugal)">INE</a> 2011 Census
           </div>
          </div> </th>
        </tr> 
        <tr> 
         <th></th> 
         <th>Rank </th>

      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Metropolitan_areas">Metropolitan areas</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Portugal&amp;action=edit&amp;section=40" title="Edit section: Metropolitan areas">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Metropolitan_areas_of_Portugal" class="mw-redirect" title="Metropolitan areas of Portugal">Metropolitan areas of Portugal</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:262px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Densidade_populacional_por_concelho_-_INE_2001.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b1/Densidade_populacional_por_concelho_-_INE_2001.png/260px-Densidade_populacional_por_concelho_-_INE_2001.png" decoding="async" width="260" height="297" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b1/Densidade_populacional_por_concelho_-_INE_2001.png/390px-Densidade_populacional_por_concelho_-_INE_2001.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b1/Densidade_populacional_por_concelho_-_INE_2001.png/520px-Densidade_populacional_por_concelho_-_INE_2001.png 2x" data-file-width="529" data-file-height="605"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Densidade_populacional_por_concelho_-_INE_2001.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>A map of Portugal showing the population density (number of inhabitants / km<sup>2</sup>) by municipality
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>There are two Greater Metropolitan Areas (<a href="/wiki/Grande_%C3%81rea_Metropolitana" class="mw-redirect" title="Grande Área Metropolitana">GAMs</a>): <a href="/wiki/%C3%81rea_Metropolitana_de_Lisboa" class="mw-redirect" title="Área Metropolitana de Lisboa">Lisbon</a> and <a href="/wiki/%C3%81rea_Metropolitana_do_Porto" class="mw-redirect" title="Área Metropolitana do Porto">Porto</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-209" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-209">[204]</a></sup> The following is a list of those with mainland <a href="/wiki/Larger_urban_zone" title="Larger urban zone">Functional Urban Areas (FUA)</a>. </p> 
      <table class="wikitable" style="text-align:right; font-size: 95%;"> 
       <caption>
        <span style="float:left; align:left; font-size: 90%;" class="editlink noprint plainlinks nourlexpansion"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Template:Portugal&amp;action=edit">e</a>&nbsp;•&nbsp;<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template_talk:Portugal&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template talk:Portugal (page does not exist)">d</a></span>&nbsp; 
       </caption> 
       <tbody>
        <tr style="background: #efefef;"> 
         <th align="right">Rank </th> 
         <th align="left">City name </th> 
         <th align="left">Population<sup id="cite_ref-210" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-210">[205]</a></sup> </th>
        </tr> 
        <tr style="text-align:right;"> 
         <td>1</td> 
         <td align="left"><a href="/wiki/Lisbon" title="Lisbon">Lisbon</a></td> 
         <td align="left">2,818,000 </td>
        </tr> 
        <tr style="text-align:right;"> 
         <td>2</td> 
         <td align="left"><a href="/wiki/Porto" title="Porto">Porto</a></td> 
         <td align="left">1,758,531 </td>
        </tr> 
        <tr style="text-align:right;"> 
         <td>3</td> 
         <td align="left"><a href="/wiki/Coimbra" title="Coimbra">Coimbra</a></td> 
         <td align="left">270,000 </td>
        </tr> 
        <tr style="text-align:right;"> 
         <td>4</td> 
         <td align="left"><a href="/wiki/Braga" title="Braga">Braga</a></td> 
         <td align="left">250,000 </td>
        </tr> 
        <tr style="text-align:right;"> 
         <td>5</td> 
         <td align="left"><a href="/wiki/Funchal" title="Funchal">Funchal</a></td> 
         <td align="left">210,000 </td>
        </tr> 
        <tr style="text-align:right;"> 
         <td>6</td> 
         <td align="left"><a href="/wiki/Guimar%C3%A3es" title="Guimarães">Guimarães</a></td>

        </tr> 
        <tr style="text-align:right;"> 
         <td>9</td>

      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Regions_by_HDI">Regions by HDI</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Portugal&amp;action=edit&amp;section=41" title="Edit section: Regions by HDI">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:178px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Regions_of_Portugal_by_HDI_(2017).svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/72/Regions_of_Portugal_by_HDI_%282017%29.svg/176px-Regions_of_Portugal_by_HDI_%282017%29.svg.png" decoding="async" width="176" height="305" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/72/Regions_of_Portugal_by_HDI_%282017%29.svg/265px-Regions_of_Portugal_by_HDI_%282017%29.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/72/Regions_of_Portugal_by_HDI_%282017%29.svg/353px-Regions_of_Portugal_by_HDI_%282017%29.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="512" data-file-height="885"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Regions_of_Portugal_by_HDI_(2017).svg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Map of Portuguese regions by Human Development Index in 2017
         <br> <b>Legend:</b> 
         <style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r981673959">.mw-parser-output .legend{page-break-inside:avoid;break-inside:avoid-column}.mw-parser-output .legend-color{display:inline-block;min-width:1.25em;height:1.25em;line-height:1.25;margin:1px 0;text-align:center;border:1px solid black;background-color:transparent;color:black}.mw-parser-output .legend-text{}</style>
         <div class="legend">
          <span class="legend-color" style="background-color:#00023a; color:white;">&nbsp;</span>&nbsp;&gt; 0.880
         </div> 
         <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959">
         <div class="legend">
          <span class="legend-color" style="background-color:#000074; color:white;">&nbsp;</span>&nbsp;0.840 – 0.880
         </div> 
         <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959">
         <div class="legend">
          <span class="legend-color" style="background-color:#0010c0; color:white;">&nbsp;</span>&nbsp;0.820 – 0.840
         </div> 
         <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959">
         <div class="legend">

         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>This is a list of <a href="/wiki/NUTS_statistical_regions_of_Portugal" title="NUTS statistical regions of Portugal">NUTS2 statistical regions of Portugal</a> by <a href="/wiki/Human_Development_Index" title="Human Development Index">Human Development Index</a> as of 2017.<sup id="cite_ref-211" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-211">[206]</a></sup> </p>

        <tr style="background:#e6e6e6"> 
         <td>– </td> 
         <td><b><span class="flagicon"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5c/Flag_of_Portugal.svg/23px-Flag_of_Portugal.svg.png" decoding="async" width="23" height="15" class="thumbborder" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5c/Flag_of_Portugal.svg/35px-Flag_of_Portugal.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5c/Flag_of_Portugal.svg/45px-Flag_of_Portugal.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="600" data-file-height="400">&nbsp;</span><a class="mw-selflink selflink">Portugal</a> (average)</b> </td>

        <tr> 
         <td>7 </td> 
         <td><a href="/wiki/Azores" title="Azores">Azores</a></td> 
         <td>0.795 </td>
        </tr>
       </tbody>
      </table> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Immigration">Immigration</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Portugal&amp;action=edit&amp;section=42" title="Edit section: Immigration">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Immigration_to_Portugal" title="Immigration to Portugal">Immigration to Portugal</a>
      </div> 
      <p>In 2007, Portugal had 10,617,575 inhabitants of whom about 332,137 were legal <a href="/wiki/Immigration_to_Portugal" title="Immigration to Portugal">immigrants</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-213" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-213">[208]</a></sup> In 2015, Portugal had 10,341,330 inhabitants of whom about 383,759 were legal migrants, making up 3.7% of the population.<sup id="cite_ref-ine.pt_214-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ine.pt-214">[209]</a></sup> In 2017, Portugal had 416,682 legal residents of foreign origin, of which 203,753 identified as male, and 212,929 as female.<sup id="cite_ref-Noticia_do_Publico_sobre_imigração_215-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Noticia_do_Publico_sobre_imigração-215">[210]</a></sup> In 2019, 21,099 residents of foreign origin acquired the Portuguese nationality, of which 11,179 were female and 9,920 were male.<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.pordata.pt/en/Portugal/Foreign+population+that+acquired+portuguese+nationality+total+and+by+sex-3250-292118">PORDATA - Foreign population that acquired portuguese nationality: total and by sex</a> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:262px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:COB_data_Portugal.PNG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/15/COB_data_Portugal.PNG/260px-COB_data_Portugal.PNG" decoding="async" width="260" height="120" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/15/COB_data_Portugal.PNG/390px-COB_data_Portugal.PNG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/15/COB_data_Portugal.PNG/520px-COB_data_Portugal.PNG 2x" data-file-width="1357" data-file-height="628"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:COB_data_Portugal.PNG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Top origins for foreign-born naturalized citizens of Portugal
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Portugal's <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_Empire" title="Portuguese Empire">colonial history</a> has long since been a cornerstone of its national identity, as has its geographic position at the south-western corner of Europe, looking out into the Atlantic Ocean. It was one of the last western colonial European powers to give up its overseas territories (among them <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_West_Africa" class="mw-redirect" title="Portuguese West Africa">Angola</a> and <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_East_Africa" class="mw-redirect" title="Portuguese East Africa">Mozambique</a> in 1975), turning over the administration of <a href="/wiki/Macau" title="Macau">Macau</a> to the People's Republic of China at the end of 1999. Consequently, it has both influenced and been influenced by cultures from former colonies or dependencies, resulting in immigration from these former territories for both economic and personal reasons. Portugal, long a country of emigration (the vast majority of <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_Brazilian" class="mw-redirect" title="Portuguese Brazilian">Brazilians</a> have Portuguese ancestry),<sup id="cite_ref-diaspora_216-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-diaspora-216">[211]</a></sup> has now become a country of net immigration,<sup id="cite_ref-217" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-217">[212]</a></sup> and not just from the last <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_India" title="Portuguese India">Indian</a> (Portuguese until 1961), <a href="/wiki/Portuguese-speaking_African_countries" title="Portuguese-speaking African countries">African</a> (Portuguese until 1975), and <a href="/wiki/Macau" title="Macau">Far East Asian</a> (Portuguese until 1999) overseas territories. An estimated 800,000 Portuguese returned to Portugal as the country's African possessions gained independence in 1975.<sup id="cite_ref-diaspora_216-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-diaspora-216">[211]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Since the 1990s, along with a boom in <a href="/wiki/Construction" title="Construction">construction</a>, several new waves of <a href="/wiki/Ukrainians" title="Ukrainians">Ukrainian</a>, <a href="/wiki/Brazilians" title="Brazilians">Brazilian</a>, <a href="/wiki/Portuguese-speaking_African_countries" title="Portuguese-speaking African countries">Lusophone Africans</a> and other <a href="/wiki/Africans" class="mw-redirect" title="Africans">Africans</a> have settled in the country. <a href="/wiki/Romanian_people" class="mw-redirect" title="Romanian people">Romanians</a>, <a href="/wiki/Moldovans" title="Moldovans">Moldovans</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kosovo_Albanians" title="Kosovo Albanians">Kosovo Albanians</a>, <a href="/wiki/Russian_people" class="mw-redirect" title="Russian people">Russians</a> and <a href="/wiki/Chinese_people" title="Chinese people">Chinese</a> have also migrated to the country. Portugal's <a href="/wiki/Romani_people" title="Romani people">Romani</a> population is estimated to be at about 40,000.<sup id="cite_ref-218" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-218">[213]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Numbers of <a href="/wiki/Venezuelan_people" class="mw-redirect" title="Venezuelan people">Venezuelan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pakistani_people" class="mw-redirect" title="Pakistani people">Pakistani</a> and <a href="/wiki/Indian_people" title="Indian people">Indian</a> migrants are also significant. It is estimated that over 30,000 seasonal, often <a href="/wiki/Illegal_immigrants" class="mw-redirect" title="Illegal immigrants">illegal immigrants</a> work in <a href="/wiki/Agriculture" title="Agriculture">agriculture</a>, mainly in the south where they are often exploited by organised seasonal-worker's networks. The workers sometimes get paid less than half the minimum pay established by law. These migrants who often arrive without due documentation or work-contracts, make make over 90% of agricultural workers in the south of Portugal. Most are Indo-Asians, from India, <a href="/wiki/Bangladesh" title="Bangladesh">Bangladesh</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nepal" title="Nepal">Nepal</a>, Pakistan and <a href="/wiki/Thailand" title="Thailand">Thailand</a>. In the interior of the <a href="/wiki/Alentejo" title="Alentejo">Alentejo</a> there are many African workers. Significant numbers also come from Eastern Europe, Moldova, Ukraine, Romania and Brazil.<sup id="cite_ref-219" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-219">[214]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In addition, a number of <a href="/wiki/EU_citizen" class="mw-redirect" title="EU citizen">EU citizens</a>, mostly from the United Kingdom or other northern European countries, have become permanent residents in the country (with the British community being mostly composed of retired pensioners who live in the Algarve and Madeira).<sup id="cite_ref-220" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-220">[215]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Religion">Religion</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Portugal&amp;action=edit&amp;section=43" title="Edit section: Religion">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Religion_in_Portugal" title="Religion in Portugal">Religion in Portugal</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="barbox tright" style="overflow-x: auto;"> 
       <div style="border:1px solid silver; font-size:88%; padding:0.4em; width:auto; background: white;"> 
        <table style="text-align:left; border-collapse:collapse; width:100%;"> 
         <tbody>
          <tr style="background:#ddd">
           <th style="text-align:center;" colspan="5">Religions in Portugal (Census 2011)<sup id="cite_ref-CIS_221-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CIS-221">[216]</a></sup></th>
          </tr> 
          <tr style="font-size:88%; height:4px;"> 
           <td colspan="2" style="padding:0 4px; text-align:left;"></td> 
           <td style="width:100px; text-align:left;"></td> 
           <td colspan="2" style="padding:0 4px; width:1em; text-align:right;"></td> 
          </tr> 
          <tr> 
           <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; min-width: 8em;"><a href="/wiki/Roman_Catholic" class="mw-redirect" title="Roman Catholic">Roman Catholicism</a></td> 
           <td style="width: 100px; border-left: solid 1px silver; border-right: solid 1px silver;">
            <div style="background:blue; width:81.0%; overflow: hidden;">
              
            </div></td> 
           <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; text-align: right;">81.0%</td> 
          </tr> 
          <tr> 
           <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; min-width: 8em;">Other <a href="/wiki/Christianity" title="Christianity">Christianity</a></td> 
           <td style="width: 100px; border-left: solid 1px silver; border-right: solid 1px silver;">
            <div style="background:purple; width:3.3%; overflow: hidden;">
              
            </div></td> 
           <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; text-align: right;">3.3%</td> 
          </tr> 
          <tr> 
           <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; min-width: 8em;">Others</td> 
           <td style="width: 100px; border-left: solid 1px silver; border-right: solid 1px silver;">
            <div style="background:grey; width:0.6%; overflow: hidden;">
              
            </div></td> 
           <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; text-align: right;">0.6%</td> 
          </tr> 
          <tr> 
           <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; min-width: 8em;">No Religion</td> 
           <td style="width: 100px; border-left: solid 1px silver; border-right: solid 1px silver;">
            <div style="background:red; width:6.8%; overflow: hidden;">
              
            </div></td> 
           <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; text-align: right;">6.8%</td> 
          </tr> 
          <tr> 
           <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; min-width: 8em;">Undeclared</td> 
           <td style="width: 100px; border-left: solid 1px silver; border-right: solid 1px silver;">
            <div style="background:yellow; width:8.3%; overflow: hidden;">
              
            </div></td> 
           <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; text-align: right;">8.3%</td> 
          </tr> 
         </tbody>
        </table> 
       </div> 
      </div> 
      <p>According to the 2011 Census, 81.0% of the Portuguese population was <a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church" title="Catholic Church">Roman Catholic Christian</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-222" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-222">[217]</a></sup> The country has small Protestant, <a href="/wiki/The_Church_of_Jesus_Christ_of_Latter-day_Saints" title="The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints">Latter-day Saint</a>, <a href="/wiki/Islam_in_Portugal" title="Islam in Portugal">Muslim</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hinduism_in_Portugal" title="Hinduism in Portugal">Hindu</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sikh" class="mw-redirect" title="Sikh">Sikh</a>, <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Orthodox_Church" title="Eastern Orthodox Church">Eastern Orthodox Church</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jehovah%27s_Witnesses" title="Jehovah's Witnesses">Jehovah's Witnesses</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bah%C3%A1%CA%BC%C3%AD_Faith" title="Baháʼí Faith">Baháʼí</a>, <a href="/wiki/Buddhism" title="Buddhism">Buddhist</a>, <a href="/wiki/Judaism" title="Judaism">Jewish</a> and <a href="/wiki/Spiritism" title="Spiritism">Spiritist</a> communities. Influences from <a href="/wiki/African_Traditional_Religion" class="mw-redirect" title="African Traditional Religion">African Traditional Religion</a> and Chinese Traditional Religion are also felt among many people, particularly in fields related with Traditional Chinese Medicine and Traditional African Herbal Medicine. Some 6.8% of the population declared themselves to be non-religious, and 8.3% did not give any answer about their religion.<sup id="cite_ref-223" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-223">[218]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Many Portuguese holidays, festivals and traditions have a Christian origin or connotation. Although relations between the Portuguese state and the Roman Catholic Church were generally amiable and stable since the earliest years of the Portuguese nation, their relative power fluctuated. In the <a href="/wiki/History_of_Portugal_(1279-1415)" class="mw-redirect" title="History of Portugal (1279-1415)">13th and 14th centuries</a>, the church enjoyed both riches and power stemming from its role in the <a href="/wiki/Reconquista" title="Reconquista">reconquest</a>, its close identification with early Portuguese nationalism and the foundation of the Portuguese educational system, including its <a href="/wiki/University_of_Coimbra" title="University of Coimbra">first university</a>. </p>
      <p>The growth of the <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_Empire" title="Portuguese Empire">Portuguese overseas empire</a> made its <a href="/wiki/Mission_(Christian)" class="mw-redirect" title="Mission (Christian)">missionaries</a> important agents of <a href="/wiki/Colonization" title="Colonization">colonization</a>, with important roles in the <a href="/wiki/Teaching" class="mw-redirect" title="Teaching">education</a> and <a href="/wiki/Evangelization" class="mw-redirect" title="Evangelization">evangelization</a> of people from all the inhabited continents. The growth of <a href="/wiki/Liberal_Revolution_of_1820" title="Liberal Revolution of 1820">liberal</a> and nascent <a href="/wiki/Republicanism" title="Republicanism">republican</a> movements during the eras leading to the formation of the <a href="/wiki/First_Portuguese_Republic" title="First Portuguese Republic">First Portuguese Republic</a> (1910–26) changed the role and importance of organized religion. </p>
      <p>Portugal is a <a href="/wiki/Secular_state" title="Secular state">secular state</a>: <a href="/wiki/Separation_of_church_and_state" title="Separation of church and state">church and state were formally separated</a> during the First Portuguese Republic, and this was reiterated in the 1976 <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_Constitution" class="mw-redirect" title="Portuguese Constitution">Portuguese Constitution</a>. Other than the Constitution, the two most important documents relating to <a href="/wiki/Religious_freedom" class="mw-redirect" title="Religious freedom">religious freedom</a> in Portugal are the 1940 Concordata (later amended in 1971) between Portugal and the <a href="/wiki/Holy_See" title="Holy See">Holy See</a> and the 2001 Religious Freedom Act. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Languages">Languages</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Portugal&amp;action=edit&amp;section=44" title="Edit section: Languages">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Languages_of_Portugal" title="Languages of Portugal">Languages of Portugal</a> and <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_language" title="Portuguese language">Portuguese language</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Gen%C3%ADsio04.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/64/Gen%C3%ADsio04.jpg/220px-Gen%C3%ADsio04.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="121" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/64/Gen%C3%ADsio04.jpg/330px-Gen%C3%ADsio04.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/64/Gen%C3%ADsio04.jpg/440px-Gen%C3%ADsio04.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1600" data-file-height="880"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Gen%C3%ADsio04.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>A sign in <a href="/wiki/Mirandese_language" title="Mirandese language">Mirandese</a> in <a href="/wiki/Miranda_do_Douro" title="Miranda do Douro">Miranda do Douro</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tr%C3%A1s-os-Montes_e_Alto_Douro_Province" title="Trás-os-Montes e Alto Douro Province">Trás-os-Montes</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Portuguese is the official language of Portugal. It is a <a href="/wiki/Romance_language" class="mw-redirect" title="Romance language">Romance language</a> that is derived from <a href="/wiki/Galician-Portuguese" title="Galician-Portuguese">Galician-Portuguese</a>, which was spoken in what is now <a href="/wiki/Galicia_(Spain)" title="Galicia (Spain)">Galicia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Northern_Portugal" class="mw-redirect" title="Northern Portugal">Northern Portugal</a>. There are still many similarities between the <a href="/wiki/Galicians" title="Galicians">Galician</a> and <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_people" title="Portuguese people">Portuguese</a> cultures. Galicia is a consultative observer of the <a href="/wiki/Community_of_Portuguese_Language_Countries" title="Community of Portuguese Language Countries">Community of Portuguese Language Countries</a>. </p>
      <p>The Portuguese language is derived from the <a href="/wiki/Latin_language" class="mw-redirect" title="Latin language">Latin</a> spoken by the <a href="/wiki/Romanization_(cultural)" title="Romanization (cultural)">romanized</a> <a href="/wiki/Pre-Roman_peoples_of_the_Iberian_Peninsula" class="mw-redirect" title="Pre-Roman peoples of the Iberian Peninsula">pre-Roman peoples of the Iberian Peninsula</a> around 2000 years ago – particularly the <a href="/wiki/Celts" title="Celts">Celts</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-ReferenceA_28-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ReferenceA-28">[24]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Conii" class="mw-redirect" title="Conii">Conii</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-224" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-224">[219]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Lusitanians" title="Lusitanians">Lusitanians</a><sup id="cite_ref-academia.edu_27-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-academia.edu-27">[23]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Turduli" title="Turduli">Turduli</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-225" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-225">[220]</a></sup> In the 15th and 16th centuries, the language spread worldwide as Portugal established a colonial and commercial empire between 1415 and 1999.<sup id="cite_ref-226" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-226">[221]</a></sup> Portuguese is spoken as a native language in five different continents, with Brazil accounting for the largest number of native Portuguese speakers of any country. In 2013 the Portuguese language is the official language spoken in Brazil, Angola, Mozambique, Cape Verde, São Tomé and Príncipe, Guinea-Bissau, Equatorial Guinea, and <a href="/wiki/East_Timor" title="East Timor">East Timor</a>. These countries, plus <a href="/wiki/Macau" title="Macau">Macau</a> Special Administrative Region (People's Republic of China) where Portuguese is co-official with <a href="/wiki/Cantonese" title="Cantonese">Cantonese</a>, make up the <a href="/wiki/Lusosphere" class="mw-redirect" title="Lusosphere">Lusosphere</a>, a term derived from the ancient <a href="/wiki/Roman_province" title="Roman province">Roman province</a> of "<a href="/wiki/Lusitania" title="Lusitania">Lusitania</a>", which currently matches the Portuguese territory south of the <a href="/wiki/Douro" title="Douro">Douro</a> river.<sup id="cite_ref-227" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-227">[222]</a></sup> </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Mirandese_language" title="Mirandese language">Mirandese</a> is also recognized as a co-official regional language in some municipalities of North-Eastern Portugal. It is part of the <a href="/wiki/Astur-Leonese" class="mw-redirect" title="Astur-Leonese">Astur-Leonese</a> group of languages.<sup id="cite_ref-228" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-228">[223]</a></sup> An estimate of between 6,000 and 7,000 Mirandese speakers has been documented for Portugal.<sup id="cite_ref-229" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-229">[224]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>According to the <a href="/wiki/EF_English_Proficiency_Index" title="EF English Proficiency Index">International English Proficiency Index</a>, Portugal has a high proficiency level in <a href="/wiki/English_language" title="English language">English</a>, higher than those of other Romance-speaking European countries like Italy, France or Spain.<sup id="cite_ref-230" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-230">[225]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Education">Education</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Portugal&amp;action=edit&amp;section=45" title="Edit section: Education">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Education_in_Portugal" title="Education in Portugal">Education in Portugal</a>
      </div> 
      <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r978413945/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">
      <div class="thumb tmulti tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:254px;max-width:254px">
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:252px;max-width:252px">
          <div class="thumbimage">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Coimbra_December_2011-19a.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c0/Coimbra_December_2011-19a.jpg/250px-Coimbra_December_2011-19a.jpg" decoding="async" width="250" height="99" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c0/Coimbra_December_2011-19a.jpg/375px-Coimbra_December_2011-19a.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c0/Coimbra_December_2011-19a.jpg/500px-Coimbra_December_2011-19a.jpg 2x" data-file-width="9536" data-file-height="3776"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           Founded in 1290, the <a href="/wiki/University_of_Coimbra" title="University of Coimbra">University of Coimbra</a> is Portugal's oldest and most prestigious, as well as one of the <a href="/wiki/List_of_oldest_universities_in_continuous_operation" title="List of oldest universities in continuous operation">world's oldest universities</a>.
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:252px;max-width:252px">
          <div class="thumbimage">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Up_reitoria.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bb/Up_reitoria.jpg/250px-Up_reitoria.jpg" decoding="async" width="250" height="158" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bb/Up_reitoria.jpg/375px-Up_reitoria.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bb/Up_reitoria.jpg/500px-Up_reitoria.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1000" data-file-height="631"></a>
          </div>
