          <div class="thumbcaption">
           The <a href="/wiki/University_of_Porto" title="University of Porto">University of Porto</a> is Portugal's second largest and its leading research university.
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The educational system is divided into preschool (for those under age 6), basic education (9 years, in three stages, compulsory), secondary education (3 years, compulsory since 2010), and higher education (subdivided in university and <a href="/wiki/Polytechnic_(Portugal)" title="Polytechnic (Portugal)">polytechnic</a> education). Universities are usually organized into <a href="/wiki/Faculty_(division)" title="Faculty (division)">faculties</a>. Institutes and schools are also common designations for autonomous subdivisions of <a href="/wiki/List_of_colleges_and_universities_in_Portugal" class="mw-redirect" title="List of colleges and universities in Portugal">Portuguese higher education institutions</a>. </p>
      <p>The total adult literacy rate is 99.4 per cent. Portuguese primary school enrolments are 100 per cent. </p>
      <p>According to the <a href="/wiki/Programme_for_International_Student_Assessment" title="Programme for International Student Assessment">Programme for International Student Assessment</a> (PISA) 2015, the average Portuguese 15-year-old student, when rated in terms of reading literacy, mathematics and science knowledge, is placed significantly above the <a href="/wiki/OECD" title="OECD">OECD</a>'s average, at a similar level as those students from Norway, Denmark and Belgium, with 501 points (493 is the average). The PISA results of the Portuguese students have been continuously improving, overcoming a number of other highly developed western countries like the US, Austria, France and Sweden.<sup id="cite_ref-231" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-231">[226]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-232" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-232">[227]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>About 46,9% of college-age citizens (20 years old) attend one of Portugal's higher education institutions<sup id="cite_ref-233" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-233">[228]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-234" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-234">[229]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-235" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-235">[230]</a></sup> (compared with 50% in the United States and 35% in the OECD countries). In addition to being a destination for <a href="/wiki/International_student" title="International student">international students</a>, Portugal is also among the top places of origin for international students. All higher education students, both domestic and international, totalled 380,937 in 2005. </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:254px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:University_of_Evora_(36815429156).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f0/University_of_Evora_%2836815429156%29.jpg/252px-University_of_Evora_%2836815429156%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="252" height="168" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f0/University_of_Evora_%2836815429156%29.jpg/378px-University_of_Evora_%2836815429156%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f0/University_of_Evora_%2836815429156%29.jpg/504px-University_of_Evora_%2836815429156%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="6000" data-file-height="4000"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:University_of_Evora_(36815429156).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/University_of_%C3%89vora" title="University of Évora">University of Evora</a>, Portugal's second oldest university.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Portuguese universities have existed since 1290. The <a href="/wiki/University_of_Coimbra" title="University of Coimbra">oldest Portuguese university</a><sup id="cite_ref-236" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-236">[231]</a></sup> was first established in Lisbon before moving to <a href="/wiki/Coimbra" title="Coimbra">Coimbra</a>. Historically, within the scope of the Portuguese Empire, the Portuguese founded the oldest engineering school of the <a href="/wiki/Americas" title="Americas">Americas</a> (the <i><a href="/wiki/Real_Academia_de_Artilharia,_Fortifica%C3%A7%C3%A3o_e_Desenho" class="mw-redirect" title="Real Academia de Artilharia, Fortificação e Desenho">Real Academia de Artilharia, Fortificação e Desenho</a></i> of <a href="/wiki/Rio_de_Janeiro" title="Rio de Janeiro">Rio de Janeiro</a>) in 1792, as well as the oldest medical college in Asia (the <i><a href="/wiki/Escola_M%C3%A9dico-Cir%C3%BArgica_de_Goa" class="mw-redirect" title="Escola Médico-Cirúrgica de Goa">Escola Médico-Cirúrgica</a></i> of <a href="/wiki/Goa" title="Goa">Goa</a>) in 1842. Presently, the largest university in Portugal is the <a href="/wiki/University_of_Lisbon" title="University of Lisbon">University of Lisbon</a>. </p>
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Bologna_process" class="mw-redirect" title="Bologna process">Bologna process</a> has been adopted by Portuguese universities and poly-technical institutes in 2006. Higher education in state-run educational establishments is provided on a competitive basis, a system of <i><a href="/wiki/Numerus_clausus" title="Numerus clausus">numerus clausus</a></i> is enforced through a national database on student admissions. However, every higher education institution offers also a number of additional vacant places through other extraordinary admission processes for sportsmen, mature applicants (over 23 years old), <a href="/wiki/International_students" class="mw-redirect" title="International students">international students</a>, foreign students from the <a href="/wiki/Lusosphere" class="mw-redirect" title="Lusosphere">Lusosphere</a>, degree owners from other institutions, students from other institutions (<a href="/wiki/Transfer_admissions_in_the_United_States" title="Transfer admissions in the United States">academic transfer</a>), former students (readmission), and course change, which are subject to specific standards and regulations set by each institution or course department. </p>
      <p>Most student costs are supported with public money. However, with the increasing tuition fees a student has to pay to attend a Portuguese state-run higher education institution and the attraction of new types of students (many as part-time students or in evening classes) like employees, businessmen, parents, and pensioners, many departments make a substantial profit from every additional student enrolled in courses, with benefits for the college or university's gross tuition revenue and without loss of educational quality (teacher per student, computer per student, classroom size per student, etc.). </p>
      <p>Portugal has entered into <a href="/wiki/Higher_education_in_Portugal#International_partnership_agreements" title="Higher education in Portugal">cooperation agreements with the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and other US institutions</a> to further develop and increase the effectiveness of Portuguese higher education and research. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Health">Health</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Portugal&amp;action=edit&amp;section=46" title="Edit section: Health">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Health_in_Portugal" title="Health in Portugal">Health in Portugal</a>
      </div> 
      <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r978413945/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">
      <div class="thumb tmulti tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:204px;max-width:204px">
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px">
          <div class="thumbimage">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Miragaia-Rua_do_Prof._Vicente_Jose_de_Carvalho-Hospital_Sto._Ant%C3%B3nio.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/Miragaia-Rua_do_Prof._Vicente_Jose_de_Carvalho-Hospital_Sto._Ant%C3%B3nio.jpg/200px-Miragaia-Rua_do_Prof._Vicente_Jose_de_Carvalho-Hospital_Sto._Ant%C3%B3nio.jpg" decoding="async" width="200" height="133" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/Miragaia-Rua_do_Prof._Vicente_Jose_de_Carvalho-Hospital_Sto._Ant%C3%B3nio.jpg/300px-Miragaia-Rua_do_Prof._Vicente_Jose_de_Carvalho-Hospital_Sto._Ant%C3%B3nio.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/Miragaia-Rua_do_Prof._Vicente_Jose_de_Carvalho-Hospital_Sto._Ant%C3%B3nio.jpg/400px-Miragaia-Rua_do_Prof._Vicente_Jose_de_Carvalho-Hospital_Sto._Ant%C3%B3nio.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3543" data-file-height="2362"></a>
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px">
          <div class="thumbimage">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Hospital_de_Santa_Maria.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ac/Hospital_de_Santa_Maria.jpg/200px-Hospital_de_Santa_Maria.jpg" decoding="async" width="200" height="150" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ac/Hospital_de_Santa_Maria.jpg/300px-Hospital_de_Santa_Maria.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ac/Hospital_de_Santa_Maria.jpg/400px-Hospital_de_Santa_Maria.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3072" data-file-height="2304"></a>
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="trow" style="display:flex">
         <div class="thumbcaption">
          St António Hospital, in <a href="/wiki/Porto" title="Porto">Porto</a> (above), and St Maria Hospital, in Lisbon (bottom)
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>According to the <a href="/wiki/Human_Development_Report" title="Human Development Report">Human Development Report</a>, the average <a href="/wiki/Life_expectancy" title="Life expectancy">life expectancy</a> in Portugal had reached 82 years in 2017,<sup id="cite_ref-237" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-237">[232]</a></sup> in 2020 it is estimated at 82.11 years.<sup id="cite_ref-238" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-238">[233]</a></sup> As projected by the United Nations, the life expectancy of the Portuguese population will be over 90 years when we reach 2100.<sup id="cite_ref-239" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-239">[234]</a></sup> The trajectory of the Portuguese life expectancy is visualized with historical data from 1950 and future projections up to 2100, as can be seen in the graph on the left. </p>
      <p>Portugal ranks 12th in the best public health systems in the world, ahead of other countries like the <a href="/wiki/United_Kingdom" title="United Kingdom">United Kingdom</a>, <a href="/wiki/Germany" title="Germany">Germany</a> or <a href="/wiki/Sweden" title="Sweden">Sweden</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-240" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-240">[235]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-241" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-241">[236]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The Portuguese health system is characterized by three coexisting systems: the National Health Service (<i>Serviço Nacional de Saúde</i>, SNS), special social health insurance schemes for certain professions (health subsystems) and voluntary private health insurance. The SNS provides universal coverage. In addition, about 25% of the population is covered by the health subsystems, 10% by private insurance schemes and another 7% by mutual funds. </p>
      <p>The Ministry of Health is responsible for developing health policy as well as managing the SNS. Five regional health administrations are in charge of implementing the national health policy objectives, developing guidelines and protocols and supervising health care delivery. Decentralization efforts have aimed at shifting financial and management responsibility to the regional level. In practice, however, the autonomy of regional health administrations over budget setting and spending has been limited to primary care. </p>
      <p>The SNS is predominantly funded through general taxation. Employer (including the state) and employee contributions represent the main funding sources of the health subsystems. In addition, direct payments by the patient and voluntary health insurance premiums account for a large proportion of funding. </p> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:FCM-UNL.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c2/FCM-UNL.JPG/220px-FCM-UNL.JPG" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c2/FCM-UNL.JPG/330px-FCM-UNL.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c2/FCM-UNL.JPG/440px-FCM-UNL.JPG 2x" data-file-width="1600" data-file-height="1200"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:FCM-UNL.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The Medical Department of the <a href="/wiki/Universidade_Nova_de_Lisboa" class="mw-redirect" title="Universidade Nova de Lisboa">Universidade Nova de Lisboa</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Similar to the other Eur-A countries, most Portuguese die from <a href="/wiki/Noncommunicable_diseases" class="mw-redirect" title="Noncommunicable diseases">noncommunicable diseases</a>. Mortality from <a href="/wiki/Cardiovascular_diseases" class="mw-redirect" title="Cardiovascular diseases">cardiovascular diseases</a> (CVD) is higher than in the <a href="/wiki/Eurozone" title="Eurozone">eurozone</a>, but its two main components, ischaemic heart disease and cerebrovascular disease, display inverse trends compared with the Eur-A, with <a href="/wiki/Cerebrovascular_disease" title="Cerebrovascular disease">cerebrovascular disease</a> being the single biggest killer in Portugal (17%). Portuguese people die 12% less often from cancer than in the Eur-A, but mortality is not declining as rapidly as in the Eur-A. Cancer is more frequent among children as well as among women younger than 44 years. Although lung cancer (slowly increasing among women) and breast cancer (decreasing rapidly) are scarcer, cervical cancer and prostate cancer are more frequent. Portugal has the highest mortality rate for diabetes in the Eur-A, with a sharp increase since the 1980s. </p>
      <p>Portugal's <a href="/wiki/Infant_mortality_rate" class="mw-redirect" title="Infant mortality rate">infant mortality rate</a> is around 2 deaths per 1000 newborns, with 2.4 deaths per 1000 live births. </p>
      <p>People are usually well informed about their health status, the positive and negative effects of their behaviour on their health, and their use of health care services. Yet their perceptions of their health, can differ from what administrative and examination-based data show about levels of illness within populations. Thus, survey results based on self-reporting at household level, complement other data on health status and the use of services. </p>
      <p>Only one third of adults rated their health as good or very good in Portugal (Kasmel et al., 2004). This is the lowest of the Eur-A countries reporting and reflects the relatively adverse situation of the country in terms of mortality and selected morbidity.<sup id="cite_ref-242" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-242">[237]</a></sup><a href="/wiki/Hospital_de_Santa_Maria" title="Hospital de Santa Maria">Hospital de Santa Maria</a> is the largest university hospital in Portugal.<sup id="cite_ref-243" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-243">[238]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Culture">Culture</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Portugal&amp;action=edit&amp;section=47" title="Edit section: Culture">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_Portugal" title="Culture of Portugal">Culture of Portugal</a>
      </div> 
      <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r978413945/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">
      <div class="thumb tmulti tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:204px;max-width:204px">
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px">
          <div class="thumbimage">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Jer%C3%B3nimos_April_2009-4.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6e/Jer%C3%B3nimos_April_2009-4.jpg/200px-Jer%C3%B3nimos_April_2009-4.jpg" decoding="async" width="200" height="128" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6e/Jer%C3%B3nimos_April_2009-4.jpg/300px-Jer%C3%B3nimos_April_2009-4.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6e/Jer%C3%B3nimos_April_2009-4.jpg/400px-Jer%C3%B3nimos_April_2009-4.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2861" data-file-height="1827"></a>
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px">
          <div class="thumbimage">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Torre_Bel%C3%A9m_April_2009-4a.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/65/Torre_Bel%C3%A9m_April_2009-4a.jpg/200px-Torre_Bel%C3%A9m_April_2009-4a.jpg" decoding="async" width="200" height="191" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/65/Torre_Bel%C3%A9m_April_2009-4a.jpg/300px-Torre_Bel%C3%A9m_April_2009-4a.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/65/Torre_Bel%C3%A9m_April_2009-4a.jpg/400px-Torre_Bel%C3%A9m_April_2009-4a.jpg 2x" data-file-width="5035" data-file-height="4805"></a>
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px">
          <div class="thumbimage">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Casamusicaexterior.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/60/Casamusicaexterior.jpg/200px-Casamusicaexterior.jpg" decoding="async" width="200" height="96" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/60/Casamusicaexterior.jpg/300px-Casamusicaexterior.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/60/Casamusicaexterior.jpg/400px-Casamusicaexterior.jpg 2x" data-file-width="5412" data-file-height="2585"></a>
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="trow" style="display:flex">
         <div class="thumbcaption">
          <a href="/wiki/Jer%C3%B3nimos_Monastery" title="Jerónimos Monastery">Jerónimos Monastery</a> (top) and <a href="/wiki/Bel%C3%A9m_Tower" title="Belém Tower">Belém Tower</a> (middle) are <a href="/wiki/Masterpiece" title="Masterpiece">magna opera</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Manueline_style" class="mw-redirect" title="Manueline style">Manueline style</a> and symbols of Portuguese nationhood. <a href="/wiki/Casa_da_M%C3%BAsica" title="Casa da Música">Casa da Música</a> (bottom) is an example of post-Millennium architecture.
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Portugal has developed a specific culture while being influenced by various civilizations that have crossed the Mediterranean and the European continent, or were introduced when it played an active role during the <a href="/wiki/Portugal_in_the_Age_of_Discovery" class="mw-redirect" title="Portugal in the Age of Discovery">Age of Discovery</a>. In the 1990s and 2000s (decade), Portugal modernized its public cultural facilities, in addition to the <a href="/wiki/Calouste_Gulbenkian_Foundation" title="Calouste Gulbenkian Foundation">Calouste Gulbenkian Foundation</a> established in 1956 in Lisbon. </p>
      <p>These include the <a href="/wiki/Bel%C3%A9m_Cultural_Centre" class="mw-redirect" title="Belém Cultural Centre">Belém Cultural Centre</a> in Lisbon, <a href="/wiki/Serralves_Foundation" class="mw-redirect" title="Serralves Foundation">Serralves Foundation</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Casa_da_M%C3%BAsica" title="Casa da Música">Casa da Música</a>, both in <a href="/wiki/Porto" title="Porto">Porto</a>, as well as new public cultural facilities like municipal libraries and concert halls that were built or renovated in many municipalities across the country. Portugal is home to <a href="/wiki/List_of_World_Heritage_Sites_in_Portugal" title="List of World Heritage Sites in Portugal">17</a> UNESCO <a href="/wiki/World_Heritage_Site" title="World Heritage Site">World Heritage Sites</a>, ranking it <a href="/wiki/World_Heritage_Sites_by_country" title="World Heritage Sites by country">9th in Europe and 18th in the world.</a> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Architecture">Architecture</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Portugal&amp;action=edit&amp;section=48" title="Edit section: Architecture">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Architecture_of_Portugal" class="mw-redirect" title="Architecture of Portugal">Architecture of Portugal</a> and <a href="/wiki/Classification_of_Built_Heritage_in_Portugal" title="Classification of Built Heritage in Portugal">Classification of Built Heritage in Portugal</a>
      </div> 
      <p>Traditional architecture is distinctive and include the <a href="/wiki/Manueline" title="Manueline">Manueline</a>, also known as Portuguese late <a href="/wiki/Gothic_architecture" title="Gothic architecture">Gothic</a> a sumptuous, composite Portuguese style of architectural ornamentation of the first decades of the 16th century, followed by <a href="/wiki/Pombaline_style" title="Pombaline style">Pombaline style</a> of the 18th century. A 20th-century interpretation of traditional architecture, <a href="/wiki/Soft_Portuguese_style" title="Soft Portuguese style">Soft Portuguese style</a>, appears extensively in major cities, especially Lisbon. Modern Portugal has given the world renowned architects like <a href="/wiki/Eduardo_Souto_de_Moura" title="Eduardo Souto de Moura">Eduardo Souto de Moura</a>, <a href="/wiki/%C3%81lvaro_Siza_Vieira" title="Álvaro Siza Vieira">Álvaro Siza Vieira</a> (both <a href="/wiki/Pritzker_Prize" class="mw-redirect" title="Pritzker Prize">Pritzker Prize</a> winners) and <a href="/wiki/Gon%C3%A7alo_Byrne" title="Gonçalo Byrne">Gonçalo Byrne</a>. In Portugal <a href="/wiki/Tom%C3%A1s_Taveira" title="Tomás Taveira">Tomás Taveira</a> is also noteworthy, particularly for stadium design.<sup id="cite_ref-244" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-244">[239]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-245" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-245">[240]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-246" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-246">[241]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Cinema">Cinema</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Portugal&amp;action=edit&amp;section=49" title="Edit section: Cinema">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Cinema_of_Portugal" title="Cinema of Portugal">Cinema of Portugal</a>
      </div> 
      <p><a href="/wiki/Cinema_of_Portugal" title="Cinema of Portugal">Portuguese cinema</a> has a long tradition, reaching back to the birth of the medium in the late 19th century. <a href="/wiki/Ant%C3%B3nio_Lopes_Ribeiro" title="António Lopes Ribeiro">António Lopes Ribeiro</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ant%C3%B3nio_Reis" title="António Reis">António Reis</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pedro_Costa" title="Pedro Costa">Pedro Costa</a>, <a href="/wiki/Manoel_de_Oliveira" title="Manoel de Oliveira">Manoel de Oliveira</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jo%C3%A3o_C%C3%A9sar_Monteiro" title="João César Monteiro">João César Monteiro</a>, <a href="/wiki/Edgar_P%C3%AAra" title="Edgar Pêra">Edgar Pêra</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ant%C3%B3nio-Pedro_Vasconcelos" title="António-Pedro Vasconcelos">António-Pedro Vasconcelos</a>, <a href="/wiki/Fernando_Lopes_(filmmaker)" title="Fernando Lopes (filmmaker)">Fernando Lopes</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jo%C3%A3o_Botelho" title="João Botelho">João Botelho</a> and <a href="/wiki/Leonel_Vieira" title="Leonel Vieira">Leonel Vieira</a>, are among those that gained notability. Noted Portuguese film actors include <a href="/wiki/Joaquim_de_Almeida" title="Joaquim de Almeida">Joaquim de Almeida</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nuno_Lopes" title="Nuno Lopes">Nuno Lopes</a>, <a href="/wiki/Daniela_Ruah" title="Daniela Ruah">Daniela Ruah</a>, <a href="/wiki/Maria_de_Medeiros" title="Maria de Medeiros">Maria de Medeiros</a>, <a href="/wiki/Diogo_Infante" title="Diogo Infante">Diogo Infante</a>, <a href="/wiki/Soraia_Chaves" title="Soraia Chaves">Soraia Chaves</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ribeirinho" title="Ribeirinho">Ribeirinho</a>, <a href="/wiki/L%C3%BAcia_Moniz" title="Lúcia Moniz">Lúcia Moniz</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Diogo_Morgado" title="Diogo Morgado">Diogo Morgado</a>. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Literature">Literature</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Portugal&amp;action=edit&amp;section=50" title="Edit section: Literature">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_literature" title="Portuguese literature">Portuguese literature</a>
      </div> 
      <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r978413945/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">
      <div class="thumb tmulti tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:312px;max-width:312px">
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:171px;max-width:171px">
          <div class="thumbimage" style="height:188px;overflow:hidden">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Cam%C3%B5es,_por_Fern%C3%A3o_Gomes.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f3/Cam%C3%B5es%2C_por_Fern%C3%A3o_Gomes.jpg/169px-Cam%C3%B5es%2C_por_Fern%C3%A3o_Gomes.jpg" decoding="async" width="169" height="189" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f3/Cam%C3%B5es%2C_por_Fern%C3%A3o_Gomes.jpg/254px-Cam%C3%B5es%2C_por_Fern%C3%A3o_Gomes.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f3/Cam%C3%B5es%2C_por_Fern%C3%A3o_Gomes.jpg/338px-Cam%C3%B5es%2C_por_Fern%C3%A3o_Gomes.jpg 2x" data-file-width="640" data-file-height="714"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           <a href="/wiki/Lu%C3%ADs_Vaz_de_Cam%C3%B5es" class="mw-redirect" title="Luís Vaz de Camões">Luís Vaz de Camões</a>, legendary poet of the <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_Renaissance" title="Portuguese Renaissance">Portuguese Renaissance</a>
          </div>
         </div>
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:137px;max-width:137px">
          <div class="thumbimage" style="height:188px;overflow:hidden">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Pessoa_chapeu.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/32/Pessoa_chapeu.jpg/135px-Pessoa_chapeu.jpg" decoding="async" width="135" height="188" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/32/Pessoa_chapeu.jpg/203px-Pessoa_chapeu.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/32/Pessoa_chapeu.jpg/270px-Pessoa_chapeu.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1084" data-file-height="1513"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           <a href="/wiki/Fernando_Pessoa" title="Fernando Pessoa">Fernando Pessoa</a>, prolific writer in 20th-century <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_language" title="Portuguese language">Portuguese</a> literature
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Portuguese literature, one of the earliest Western literatures, developed through text as well as song. Until 1350, the <a href="/wiki/Portuguese-Galician" class="mw-redirect" title="Portuguese-Galician">Portuguese-Galician</a> <a href="/wiki/Troubadour" title="Troubadour">troubadours</a> spread their literary influence to most of the Iberian Peninsula.<sup id="cite_ref-247" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-247">[242]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Gil_Vicente" title="Gil Vicente">Gil Vicente</a> (c. 1465–c. 1536) was one of the founders of Portuguese dramatic traditions. </p>
      <p>Adventurer and poet <a href="/wiki/Lu%C3%ADs_de_Cam%C3%B5es" title="Luís de Camões">Luís de Camões</a> (c. 1524–1580) wrote the epic poem <i><a href="/wiki/Os_Lus%C3%ADadas" title="Os Lusíadas">Os Lusíadas</a></i> (<i>The Lusiads</i>), with <a href="/wiki/Virgil" title="Virgil">Virgil</a>'s <i><a href="/wiki/Aeneid" title="Aeneid">Aeneid</a></i> as his main influence.<sup id="cite_ref-WDL_248-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WDL-248">[243]</a></sup> Modern Portuguese poetry is rooted in neoclassic and contemporary styles, as exemplified by <a href="/wiki/Manuel_Maria_Barbosa_du_Bocage" title="Manuel Maria Barbosa du Bocage">Bocage</a> (1765–1805), <a href="/wiki/Antero_de_Quental" title="Antero de Quental">Antero de Quental</a> (1842–1891) and <a href="/wiki/Fernando_Pessoa" title="Fernando Pessoa">Fernando Pessoa</a> (1888–1935). Modern Portuguese literature is represented by authors such as <a href="/wiki/Almeida_Garrett" title="Almeida Garrett">Almeida Garrett</a>, <a href="/wiki/Camilo_Castelo_Branco" title="Camilo Castelo Branco">Camilo Castelo Branco</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_Maria_de_E%C3%A7a_de_Queir%C3%B3s" title="José Maria de Eça de Queirós">Eça de Queirós</a>, <a href="/wiki/Fernando_Pessoa" title="Fernando Pessoa">Fernando Pessoa</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sophia_de_Mello_Breyner_Andresen" title="Sophia de Mello Breyner Andresen">Sophia de Mello Breyner Andresen</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ant%C3%B3nio_Lobo_Antunes" title="António Lobo Antunes">António Lobo Antunes</a> and <a href="/wiki/Miguel_Torga" title="Miguel Torga">Miguel Torga</a>. Particularly popular and distinguished is <a href="/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_Saramago" title="José Saramago">José Saramago</a>, recipient of the 1998 <a href="/wiki/Nobel_Prize_in_Literature" title="Nobel Prize in Literature">Nobel Prize in Literature</a>. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Cuisine">Cuisine</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Portugal&amp;action=edit&amp;section=51" title="Edit section: Cuisine">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_cuisine" title="Portuguese cuisine">Portuguese cuisine</a> and <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_wine" title="Portuguese wine">Portuguese wine</a>
      </div> 
      <p>Portuguese cuisine is very diverse. The Portuguese consume a lot of dry <a href="/wiki/Cod" title="Cod">cod</a> (<i><a href="/wiki/Bacalhau" title="Bacalhau">bacalhau</a></i> in Portuguese), for which there are hundreds of <a href="/wiki/Bacalhau#Bacalhau_dishes" title="Bacalhau">recipes</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-249" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-249">[244]</a></sup> There are more than enough <i><a href="/wiki/Bacalhau" title="Bacalhau">bacalhau</a></i> dishes; over one for each day of the year. Two other popular fish recipes are grilled <a href="/wiki/Sardines" class="mw-redirect" title="Sardines">sardines</a> and <a href="/wiki/Caldeirada" title="Caldeirada">caldeirada</a>, a tomato-based <a href="/wiki/Stew" title="Stew">stew</a> that can be made from several types of fish with a mix of onion, garlic, peppers, potatoes, tomatoes, parsley or <a href="/wiki/Coriander" title="Coriander">coriander</a>. Typical Portuguese meat recipes made out of beef, pork, lamb, goat or chicken include <i><a href="/wiki/Cozido_%C3%A0_portuguesa" title="Cozido à portuguesa">cozido à portuguesa</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Feijoada" title="Feijoada">feijoada</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Frango_de_churrasco" class="mw-redirect" title="Frango de churrasco">frango de churrasco</a></i>, <i>leitão</i> (roast <a href="/wiki/Suckling_pig" title="Suckling pig">suckling pig</a>), <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Chanfana&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Chanfana (page does not exist)">chanfana</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Carne_de_porco_%C3%A0_alentejana" title="Carne de porco à alentejana">carne de porco à alentejana</a></i>. A very popular northern dish is <a href="/wiki/Dobrada" title="Dobrada">dobrada</a>, a tripe with white beans and carrots stew, often served with steamed white rice. <a href="/wiki/Peri-peri" title="Peri-peri">Peri-peri</a> chicken is a spicy charcoal chicken dish served with rice and vegetables, a favourite throughout Portugal, but most common in the <a href="/wiki/Algarve" title="Algarve">Algarve</a> region. </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:MargaretCafe_PasteisDeNata.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2b/MargaretCafe_PasteisDeNata.JPG/220px-MargaretCafe_PasteisDeNata.JPG" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2b/MargaretCafe_PasteisDeNata.JPG/330px-MargaretCafe_PasteisDeNata.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2b/MargaretCafe_PasteisDeNata.JPG/440px-MargaretCafe_PasteisDeNata.JPG 2x" data-file-width="2400" data-file-height="1600"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:MargaretCafe_PasteisDeNata.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Pasteis de Nata in <a href="/wiki/Lisboa" class="mw-redirect" title="Lisboa">Lisboa</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Typical fast food dishes include the <a href="/wiki/Francesinha" title="Francesinha">Francesinha</a> (Frenchie) from Porto, "Tripas à moda do Porto" which is also a traditional plate from Porto, and <i>bifanas</i> (grilled pork) or <i>prego</i> (grilled beef) <a href="/wiki/Sandwich" title="Sandwich">sandwiches</a>, which are well known around the country. The Portuguese art of <a href="/wiki/Pastry" title="Pastry">pastry</a> has its origins in the many <a href="/wiki/Medieval" class="mw-redirect" title="Medieval">medieval</a> Catholic monasteries spread widely across the country. These monasteries, using very few ingredients (mostly almonds, <a href="/wiki/Vanilla" title="Vanilla">vanilla</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cinnamon" title="Cinnamon">cinnamon</a>, flour, eggs and some liquor), managed to create a spectacular wide range of different pastries, of which <a href="/wiki/Past%C3%A9is_de_Bel%C3%A9m" class="mw-redirect" title="Pastéis de Belém">pastéis de Belém</a> (or <i>pastéis de nata</i>) originally from Lisbon, and <i><a href="/wiki/Ovos_moles" title="Ovos moles">ovos moles</a></i> from Aveiro are examples. Portuguese cuisine is very diverse, with different regions having their own traditional dishes. The Portuguese have a culture of good food, and throughout the country there are myriads of good restaurants and typical small <i>tasquinhas</i>. </p>
      <p>Portuguese wines have enjoyed international recognition since the times of the Romans, who associated Portugal with their god <a href="/wiki/Dionysus" title="Dionysus">Bacchus</a>. Today, the country is known by wine lovers and its wines have won several international prizes. Some of the best Portuguese wines are <a href="/wiki/Vinho_Verde" title="Vinho Verde">Vinho Verde</a>, <a href="/wiki/Vinho_Alvarinho" class="mw-redirect" title="Vinho Alvarinho">Vinho Alvarinho</a>, <a href="/wiki/Vinho_do_Douro" class="mw-redirect" title="Vinho do Douro">Vinho do Douro</a>, <a href="/wiki/Vinho_do_Alentejo" class="mw-redirect" title="Vinho do Alentejo">Vinho do Alentejo</a>, <a href="/wiki/Vinho_do_D%C3%A3o" class="mw-redirect" title="Vinho do Dão">Vinho do Dão</a>, <a href="/wiki/Vinho_da_Bairrada" class="mw-redirect" title="Vinho da Bairrada">Vinho da Bairrada</a> and the sweet <a href="/wiki/Port_Wine" class="mw-redirect" title="Port Wine">Port Wine</a>, <a href="/wiki/Madeira_Wine" class="mw-redirect" title="Madeira Wine">Madeira Wine</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Moscatel" class="mw-redirect" title="Moscatel">Moscatel</a> from <a href="/wiki/Set%C3%BAbal" title="Setúbal">Setúbal</a> and <a href="/wiki/Favaios" title="Favaios">Favaios</a>. Port and Madeira are particularly appreciated in a wide range of places around the world. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Music">Music</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Portugal&amp;action=edit&amp;section=52" title="Edit section: Music">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Music_of_Portugal" title="Music of Portugal">Music of Portugal</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Jose_malhoa_fado.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/01/Jose_malhoa_fado.jpg/220px-Jose_malhoa_fado.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="188" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/01/Jose_malhoa_fado.jpg/330px-Jose_malhoa_fado.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/01/Jose_malhoa_fado.jpg/440px-Jose_malhoa_fado.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1116" data-file-height="952"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Jose_malhoa_fado.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Fado" title="Fado">Fado</a>, depicted in this famous painting (c. 1910) by <a href="/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_Malhoa" title="José Malhoa">José Malhoa</a>, is Portugal's traditional music.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p><a href="/wiki/Music_of_Portugal" title="Music of Portugal">Portuguese music</a> encompasses a wide variety of genres. The traditional one is the Portuguese folk music which has deep roots in local customs having as instruments <a href="/wiki/Bagpipes" title="Bagpipes">bagpipes</a> (<i><a href="/wiki/Gaita_(bagpipe)" class="mw-redirect" title="Gaita (bagpipe)">gaita</a></i>), drums, flutes, tambourines, accordions and ukuleles (<i><a href="/wiki/Cavaquinho" title="Cavaquinho">cavaquinho</a></i>). Within Portuguese folk music is the renowned genre of <a href="/wiki/Fado" title="Fado">Fado</a>, a melancholic urban music originated in <a href="/wiki/Lisbon" title="Lisbon">Lisbon</a> in the 19th century, probably inside bohemian environments, usually associated with the <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_guitar" title="Portuguese guitar">Portuguese guitar</a> and <i>saudade</i>, or longing. <a href="/wiki/Coimbra_fado" class="mw-redirect" title="Coimbra fado">Coimbra fado</a>, a unique type of "<a href="/wiki/Troubadour" title="Troubadour">troubadour</a> serenading" fado, is also noteworthy. Internationally notable performers include <a href="/wiki/Am%C3%A1lia_Rodrigues" title="Amália Rodrigues">Amália Rodrigues</a>, <a href="/wiki/Carlos_Paredes" title="Carlos Paredes">Carlos Paredes</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_Afonso" class="mw-redirect" title="José Afonso">José Afonso</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mariza" title="Mariza">Mariza</a>, <a href="/wiki/Carlos_do_Carmo" title="Carlos do Carmo">Carlos do Carmo</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ant%C3%B3nio_Chainho" title="António Chainho">António Chainho</a>, <a href="/wiki/M%C3%ADsia" title="Mísia">Mísia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Dulce_Pontes" title="Dulce Pontes">Dulce Pontes</a> and <a href="/wiki/Madredeus" title="Madredeus">Madredeus</a>. </p>
      <p>In the classical music domain, Portugal is represented by names as the pianists <a href="/wiki/Artur_Pizarro" title="Artur Pizarro">Artur Pizarro</a>, <a href="/wiki/Maria_Jo%C3%A3o_Pires" title="Maria João Pires">Maria João Pires</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sequeira_Costa" title="Sequeira Costa">Sequeira Costa</a>, the violinists Carlos Damas, <a href="/wiki/Gerardo_Ribeiro" title="Gerardo Ribeiro">Gerardo Ribeiro</a> and in the past by the great cellist <a href="/wiki/Guilhermina_Suggia" title="Guilhermina Suggia">Guilhermina Suggia</a>. Notable composers include <a href="/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_Vianna_da_Motta" title="José Vianna da Motta">José Vianna da Motta</a>, <a href="/wiki/Carlos_Seixas" title="Carlos Seixas">Carlos Seixas</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jo%C3%A3o_Domingos_Bomtempo" title="João Domingos Bomtempo">João Domingos Bomtempo</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jo%C3%A3o_de_Sousa_Carvalho" title="João de Sousa Carvalho">João de Sousa Carvalho</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lu%C3%ADs_de_Freitas_Branco" title="Luís de Freitas Branco">Luís de Freitas Branco</a> and his student <a href="/wiki/Joly_Braga_Santos" title="Joly Braga Santos">Joly Braga Santos</a>, <a href="/wiki/Fernando_Lopes-Gra%C3%A7a" title="Fernando Lopes-Graça">Fernando Lopes-Graça</a>, <a href="/wiki/Emmanuel_Nunes" title="Emmanuel Nunes">Emmanuel Nunes</a> and <a href="/wiki/S%C3%A9rgio_Azevedo" title="Sérgio Azevedo">Sérgio Azevedo</a>. Similarly, contemporary composers such as Nuno Malo and Miguel d'Oliveira have achieved some international success writing. </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:AmaliaRodrigues1969_(cropped).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/80/AmaliaRodrigues1969_%28cropped%29.jpg/220px-AmaliaRodrigues1969_%28cropped%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="180" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/80/AmaliaRodrigues1969_%28cropped%29.jpg/330px-AmaliaRodrigues1969_%28cropped%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/80/AmaliaRodrigues1969_%28cropped%29.jpg/440px-AmaliaRodrigues1969_%28cropped%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2363" data-file-height="1930"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:AmaliaRodrigues1969_(cropped).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Am%C3%A1lia_Rodrigues" title="Amália Rodrigues">Amália Rodrigues</a>, known as the <i>Queen of <a href="/wiki/Fado" title="Fado">Fado</a></i>, performing in 1969
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>In addition to <a href="/wiki/Folk_music" title="Folk music">Folk</a>, Fado and Classical music, other genres are present at Portugal like pop and other types of modern music, particularly from North America and the United Kingdom, as well as a wide range of Portuguese, Caribbean, Lusophone African and Brazilian artists and bands. Artists with international recognition include <a href="/wiki/Dulce_Pontes" title="Dulce Pontes">Dulce Pontes</a>, <a href="/wiki/Moonspell" title="Moonspell">Moonspell</a>, <a href="/wiki/Buraka_Som_Sistema" title="Buraka Som Sistema">Buraka Som Sistema</a>, <a href="/wiki/Blasted_Mechanism" title="Blasted Mechanism">Blasted Mechanism</a>, <a href="/wiki/David_Carreira" title="David Carreira">David Carreira</a> and <a href="/wiki/The_Gift_(band)" title="The Gift (band)">The Gift</a>, with the three latter being nominees for a <a href="/wiki/MTV_Europe_Music_Award" class="mw-redirect" title="MTV Europe Music Award">MTV Europe Music Award</a>. </p>
      <p>Portugal has several summer music festivals, such as <i><a href="/wiki/Festival_Sudoeste" class="mw-redirect" title="Festival Sudoeste">Festival Sudoeste</a></i> in <a href="/wiki/Zambujeira_do_Mar" title="Zambujeira do Mar">Zambujeira do Mar</a>, <i><a href="/wiki/Festival_de_Paredes_de_Coura" class="mw-redirect" title="Festival de Paredes de Coura">Festival de Paredes de Coura</a></i> in <a href="/wiki/Paredes_de_Coura" title="Paredes de Coura">Paredes de Coura</a>, <i><a href="/wiki/Festival_Vilar_de_Mouros" class="mw-redirect" title="Festival Vilar de Mouros">Festival Vilar de Mouros</a></i> near <a href="/wiki/Caminha" title="Caminha">Caminha</a>, <a href="/wiki/Boom_Festival" title="Boom Festival">Boom Festival</a> in <a href="/wiki/Idanha-a-Nova_Municipality" class="mw-redirect" title="Idanha-a-Nova Municipality">Idanha-a-Nova Municipality</a>, <i><a href="/wiki/NOS_Alive" title="NOS Alive">NOS Alive</a></i>, <i>Sumol Summer Fest</i> in <a href="/wiki/Ericeira" title="Ericeira">Ericeira</a>, <i><a href="/wiki/Rock_in_Rio#Lisboa,_Portugal,_and_Madrid,_Spain" title="Rock in Rio">Rock in Rio Lisboa</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Super_Bock_Super_Rock" title="Super Bock Super Rock">Super Bock Super Rock</a></i> in <a href="/wiki/Greater_Lisbon" class="mw-redirect" title="Greater Lisbon">Greater Lisbon</a>. Out of the summer season, Portugal has a large number of festivals, designed more to an urban audience, like Flowfest or Hip Hop Porto. Furthermore, one of the largest international <a href="/wiki/Goa_trance" title="Goa trance">Goa trance</a> festivals takes place in central Portugal every two years, the Boom Festival, that is also the only festival in Portugal to win international awards: European Festival Award 2010 – Green'n'Clean Festival of the Year and the Greener Festival Award Outstanding 2008 and 2010. There is also the student festivals of <i><a href="/wiki/Queima_das_Fitas" title="Queima das Fitas">Queima das Fitas</a></i> are major events in a number of cities across Portugal. In 2005, Portugal held the <a href="/wiki/MTV_Europe_Music_Awards" title="MTV Europe Music Awards">MTV Europe Music Awards</a>, in <a href="/wiki/Pavilh%C3%A3o_Atl%C3%A2ntico" class="mw-redirect" title="Pavilhão Atlântico">Pavilhão Atlântico</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lisbon" title="Lisbon">Lisbon</a>. Furthermore, Portugal won the <a href="/wiki/Eurovision_Song_Contest_2017" title="Eurovision Song Contest 2017">Eurovision Song Contest 2017</a> in <a href="/wiki/Kyiv" title="Kyiv">Kyiv</a> with the song "<a href="/wiki/Amar_pelos_dois" title="Amar pelos dois">Amar pelos dois</a>" presented by <a href="/wiki/Salvador_Sobral" title="Salvador Sobral">Salvador Sobral</a>, and subsequently hosted the <a href="/wiki/Eurovision_Song_Contest_2018" title="Eurovision Song Contest 2018">2018 contest</a> at the <a href="/wiki/Altice_Arena" title="Altice Arena">Altice Arena</a> in <a href="/wiki/Lisbon" title="Lisbon">Lisbon</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-250" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-250">[245]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-251" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-251">[246]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Visual_arts">Visual arts</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Portugal&amp;action=edit&amp;section=53" title="Edit section: Visual arts">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_art" title="Portuguese art">Portuguese art</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:A_Adora%C3%A7%C3%A3o_dos_Magos_(1828)_-_Domingos_Sequeira.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e9/A_Adora%C3%A7%C3%A3o_dos_Magos_%281828%29_-_Domingos_Sequeira.png/220px-A_Adora%C3%A7%C3%A3o_dos_Magos_%281828%29_-_Domingos_Sequeira.png" decoding="async" width="220" height="159" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e9/A_Adora%C3%A7%C3%A3o_dos_Magos_%281828%29_-_Domingos_Sequeira.png/330px-A_Adora%C3%A7%C3%A3o_dos_Magos_%281828%29_-_Domingos_Sequeira.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e9/A_Adora%C3%A7%C3%A3o_dos_Magos_%281828%29_-_Domingos_Sequeira.png/440px-A_Adora%C3%A7%C3%A3o_dos_Magos_%281828%29_-_Domingos_Sequeira.png 2x" data-file-width="2210" data-file-height="1599"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:A_Adora%C3%A7%C3%A3o_dos_Magos_(1828)_-_Domingos_Sequeira.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Domingos_Sequeira" title="Domingos Sequeira">Domingos Sequeira</a> was one of the most prolific <a href="/wiki/Neoclassicism" title="Neoclassicism">neoclassical</a> painters. (<a href="/wiki/Adoration_of_the_Magi_(Sequeira)" title="Adoration of the Magi (Sequeira)"><i>Adoration of the Magi</i>; 1828</a>)
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Portugal has a <a href="/wiki/List_of_Portuguese_artists" title="List of Portuguese artists">rich history in painting</a>. The first well-known painters date back to the 15th century&nbsp;– like <a href="/wiki/Nuno_Gon%C3%A7alves" title="Nuno Gonçalves">Nuno Gonçalves</a> and <a href="/wiki/Gr%C3%A3o_Vasco" title="Grão Vasco">Vasco Fernandes</a>&nbsp;– were part of the late Gothic painting period. During the renaissance Portuguese painting was highly influenced by north European painting. In the Baroque period <a href="/wiki/Josefa_de_%C3%93bidos" title="Josefa de Óbidos">Josefa de Óbidos</a> and <a href="/wiki/Vieira_Lusitano" title="Vieira Lusitano">Vieira Lusitano</a> were the most prolific painters. <a href="/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_Malhoa" title="José Malhoa">José Malhoa</a>, known for his work <i>Fado</i>, and <a href="/wiki/Columbano_Bordalo_Pinheiro" title="Columbano Bordalo Pinheiro">Columbano Bordalo Pinheiro</a> (who painted the portraits of <a href="/wiki/Te%C3%B3filo_Braga" title="Teófilo Braga">Teófilo Braga</a> and <a href="/wiki/Antero_de_Quental" title="Antero de Quental">Antero de Quental</a>) were both references in <a href="/wiki/Naturalist_school_of_painting" class="mw-redirect" title="Naturalist school of painting">naturalist painting</a>. </p>
      <p>The 20th century saw the arrival of <a href="/wiki/Modernism" title="Modernism">Modernism</a>, and along with it came the most prominent Portuguese painters: <a href="/wiki/Amadeo_de_Souza-Cardoso" class="mw-redirect" title="Amadeo de Souza-Cardoso">Amadeo de Souza-Cardoso</a>, who was heavily influenced by French painters, particularly the Delaunays (<a href="/wiki/Robert_Delaunay" title="Robert Delaunay">Robert</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sonia_Delaunay" title="Sonia Delaunay">Sonia</a>). Among his best-known works is <i>Canção Popular a Russa e o Fígaro</i>. Another great modernist painters/writers were <a href="/wiki/Carlos_Botelho" title="Carlos Botelho">Carlos Botelho</a> and <a href="/wiki/Almada_Negreiros" class="mw-redirect" title="Almada Negreiros">Almada Negreiros</a>, friend to the poet <a href="/wiki/Fernando_Pessoa" title="Fernando Pessoa">Fernando Pessoa</a>, who painted Pessoa's portrait. He was deeply influenced by both <a href="/wiki/Cubist" class="mw-redirect" title="Cubist">Cubist</a> and <a href="/wiki/Futurism_(art)" class="mw-redirect" title="Futurism (art)">Futurist</a> trends. </p>
      <p>Prominent international figures in visual arts nowadays include painters <a href="/wiki/Vieira_da_Silva" class="mw-redirect" title="Vieira da Silva">Vieira da Silva</a>, <a href="/wiki/J%C3%BAlio_Pomar" title="Júlio Pomar">Júlio Pomar</a>, Helena Almeida, <a href="/wiki/Joana_Vasconcelos" title="Joana Vasconcelos">Joana Vasconcelos</a>, <a href="/wiki/Juli%C3%A3o_Sarmento" title="Julião Sarmento">Julião Sarmento</a> and <a href="/wiki/Paula_Rego" title="Paula Rego">Paula Rego</a>. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Sport">Sport</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Portugal&amp;action=edit&amp;section=54" title="Edit section: Sport">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Sport_in_Portugal" title="Sport in Portugal">Sport in Portugal</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:IRNPOR_match_2018_FIFA_World_Cup_11_(cropped).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e6/IRNPOR_match_2018_FIFA_World_Cup_11_%28cropped%29.jpg/220px-IRNPOR_match_2018_FIFA_World_Cup_11_%28cropped%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="193" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e6/IRNPOR_match_2018_FIFA_World_Cup_11_%28cropped%29.jpg/330px-IRNPOR_match_2018_FIFA_World_Cup_11_%28cropped%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e6/IRNPOR_match_2018_FIFA_World_Cup_11_%28cropped%29.jpg/440px-IRNPOR_match_2018_FIFA_World_Cup_11_%28cropped%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="710" data-file-height="623"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:IRNPOR_match_2018_FIFA_World_Cup_11_(cropped).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Cristiano_Ronaldo" title="Cristiano Ronaldo">Cristiano Ronaldo</a> is consistently ranked as the best football player in the world and considered to be one of the greatest players of all time.<sup id="cite_ref-252" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-252">[247]</a></sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p><a href="/wiki/Association_football" title="Association football">Football</a> is the most popular sport in Portugal. There are several football competitions ranging from local amateur to world-class professional level. The legendary <a href="/wiki/Eus%C3%A9bio" title="Eusébio">Eusébio</a> is still a major symbol of <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_football" class="mw-redirect" title="Portuguese football">Portuguese football</a> history. <a href="/wiki/FIFA_World_Player_of_the_Year" title="FIFA World Player of the Year">FIFA World Player of the Year</a> winners <a href="/wiki/Lu%C3%ADs_Figo" title="Luís Figo">Luís Figo</a> and <a href="/wiki/Cristiano_Ronaldo" title="Cristiano Ronaldo">Cristiano Ronaldo</a>, who won the <a href="/wiki/FIFA_Ballon_d%27Or" title="FIFA Ballon d'Or">FIFA Ballon d'Or</a>, are two world-class Portuguese football players. Portuguese football managers are also noteworthy, with <a href="/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_Mourinho" title="José Mourinho">José Mourinho</a> being among the most renowned. </p>
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Portugal_national_football_team" title="Portugal national football team">Portugal national football team</a>&nbsp;– <i>Seleção Nacional</i>&nbsp;– have won one <a href="/wiki/UEFA_European_Championship" title="UEFA European Championship">UEFA European Championship</a> title: the <a href="/wiki/UEFA_Euro_2016" title="UEFA Euro 2016">UEFA Euro 2016</a>, with a 1–0 victory in the <a href="/wiki/UEFA_Euro_2016_Final" title="UEFA Euro 2016 Final">final</a> over <a href="/wiki/France_national_football_team" title="France national football team">France</a>, the tournament hosts. In addition, Portugal finished first in the <a href="/wiki/2018%E2%80%9319_UEFA_Nations_League" title="2018–19 UEFA Nations League">2018–19 UEFA Nations League</a> with a 1–0 win over the <a href="/wiki/Netherlands_national_football_team" title="Netherlands national football team">Netherlands</a> in the <a href="/wiki/2019_UEFA_Nations_League_Final" title="2019 UEFA Nations League Final">final</a> (held in Portugal), second in the <a href="/wiki/2004_European_Football_Championship" class="mw-redirect" title="2004 European Football Championship">Euro 2004</a> (also held in Portugal), third in the <a href="/wiki/1966_FIFA_World_Cup" title="1966 FIFA World Cup">1966 FIFA World Cup</a> and <a href="/wiki/2017_FIFA_Confederations_Cup" title="2017 FIFA Confederations Cup">2017 FIFA Confederations Cup</a>, and fourth in the <a href="/wiki/2006_FIFA_World_Cup" title="2006 FIFA World Cup">2006 FIFA World Cup</a>. At youth level, Portugal have won two <a href="/wiki/FIFA_World_Youth_Championship" class="mw-redirect" title="FIFA World Youth Championship">FIFA World Youth Championships</a> (in <a href="/wiki/1989_FIFA_World_Youth_Championship" title="1989 FIFA World Youth Championship">1989</a> and <a href="/wiki/1991_FIFA_World_Youth_Championship" title="1991 FIFA World Youth Championship">1991</a>) and several <a href="/wiki/UEFA" title="UEFA">UEFA</a> European Youth Championships. </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/S.L._Benfica" title="S.L. Benfica">S.L. Benfica</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sporting_CP" title="Sporting CP">Sporting CP</a> and <a href="/wiki/FC_Porto" title="FC Porto">FC Porto</a> are the largest <a href="/wiki/Sports_clubs" class="mw-redirect" title="Sports clubs">sports clubs</a> by popularity and by number of trophies won, often known as "<i>os três grandes</i>" (<a href="/wiki/Big_Three_(Portugal)" title="Big Three (Portugal)">"the big three"</a>). They have won eight titles in the European <a href="/wiki/UEFA" title="UEFA">UEFA</a> club competitions, were present in 21 finals and have been regular contenders in the last stages almost every season. Other than football, many Portuguese sports clubs, including the "big three", compete in several other sports events with a varying level of success and popularity, these may include <a href="/wiki/Roller_hockey_(quad)" title="Roller hockey (quad)">roller hockey</a>, <a href="/wiki/Basketball" title="Basketball">basketball</a>, <a href="/wiki/Futsal" title="Futsal">futsal</a>, <a href="/wiki/Team_handball" class="mw-redirect" title="Team handball">handball</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Volleyball" title="Volleyball">volleyball</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_Football_Federation" title="Portuguese Football Federation">Portuguese Football Federation</a> (FPF) &nbsp;– <i>Federação Portuguesa de Futebol</i>&nbsp;– annually hosts the <a href="/wiki/Algarve_Cup" title="Algarve Cup">Algarve Cup</a>, a prestigious <a href="/wiki/Women%27s_association_football" title="Women's association football">women's football</a> tournament that has been celebrated in the Algarvian part of Portugal. </p>
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Portugal_national_rugby_union_team" title="Portugal national rugby union team">Portuguese national rugby union team</a> qualified for the <a href="/wiki/2007_Rugby_World_Cup" title="2007 Rugby World Cup">2007 Rugby World Cup</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Portugal_national_rugby_sevens_team" title="Portugal national rugby sevens team">Portuguese national rugby sevens team</a> has played in the <a href="/wiki/World_Rugby_Sevens_Series" title="World Rugby Sevens Series">World Rugby Sevens Series</a>. </p> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:152px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:N%C3%A9lson_%C3%89vora_2015.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/70/N%C3%A9lson_%C3%89vora_2015.jpg/150px-N%C3%A9lson_%C3%89vora_2015.jpg" decoding="async" width="150" height="235" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/70/N%C3%A9lson_%C3%89vora_2015.jpg/225px-N%C3%A9lson_%C3%89vora_2015.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/70/N%C3%A9lson_%C3%89vora_2015.jpg/300px-N%C3%A9lson_%C3%89vora_2015.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1360" data-file-height="2128"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:N%C3%A9lson_%C3%89vora_2015.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Nelson_%C3%89vora" title="Nelson Évora">Nelson Évora</a> won gold in <a href="/wiki/Athletics_at_the_2008_Summer_Olympics_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_triple_jump" title="Athletics at the 2008 Summer Olympics – Men's triple jump">triple jump</a> at the <a href="/wiki/2008_Summer_Olympics" title="2008 Summer Olympics">2008 Beijing Olympics</a>.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>In <a href="/wiki/Athletics_(sport)" class="mw-redirect" title="Athletics (sport)">athletics</a>, the Portuguese have won a number of gold, silver and bronze medals in the European, World and Olympic Games competitions. <a href="/wiki/Cycling" title="Cycling">Cycling</a>, with <a href="/wiki/Volta_a_Portugal" title="Volta a Portugal">Volta a Portugal</a> being the most important race, is also a popular sports event and includes professional cycling teams such as <a href="/wiki/Sporting_CP" title="Sporting CP">Sporting CP</a>, <a href="/wiki/Boavista_(cycling_team)" class="mw-redirect" title="Boavista (cycling team)">Boavista</a>, <a href="/wiki/Clube_de_Ciclismo_de_Tavira" class="mw-redirect" title="Clube de Ciclismo de Tavira">Clube de Ciclismo de Tavira</a> and <a href="/wiki/Uni%C3%A3o_Ciclista_da_Maia" title="União Ciclista da Maia">União Ciclista da Maia</a>. At international level, Portuguese cyclists have already achieved good results. <a href="/wiki/Joaquim_Agostinho" title="Joaquim Agostinho">Joaquim Agostinho</a> finished on the podium in 1978 and 1979 <a href="/wiki/Tour_de_France" title="Tour de France">Tour de France</a>, and 1974 <a href="/wiki/Vuelta_a_Espa%C3%B1a" title="Vuelta a España">Vuelta a España</a>. <a href="/wiki/Rui_Costa_(cyclist)" title="Rui Costa (cyclist)">Rui Costa</a> has won the <a href="/wiki/UCI_Road_World_Championships" title="UCI Road World Championships">world title</a> in the men's road race. </p>
      <p>The country has also achieved notable performances in sports like <a href="/wiki/Fencing" title="Fencing">fencing</a>, <a href="/wiki/Judo" title="Judo">judo</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kitesurf" class="mw-redirect" title="Kitesurf">kitesurf</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rowing_(sport)" title="Rowing (sport)">rowing</a>, sailing, <a href="/wiki/Surfing" title="Surfing">surfing</a>, shooting, <a href="/wiki/Taekwondo" title="Taekwondo">taekwondo</a>, <a href="/wiki/Triathlon" title="Triathlon">triathlon</a> and <a href="/wiki/Windsurf" class="mw-redirect" title="Windsurf">windsurf</a>, owning several European and world titles. The <a href="/wiki/Paralympic" class="mw-redirect" title="Paralympic">paralympic</a> athletes have also conquered many medals in sports like <a href="/wiki/Swimming_(sport)" title="Swimming (sport)">swimming</a>, <a href="/wiki/Boccia" title="Boccia">boccia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sport_of_athletics" title="Sport of athletics">athletics</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mixed_martial_arts" title="Mixed martial arts">mixed martial arts</a> and <a href="/wiki/Wrestling" title="Wrestling">wrestling</a>. </p>
      <p>In motorsport, Portugal is internationally noted for the <a href="/wiki/Rally_of_Portugal" class="mw-redirect" title="Rally of Portugal">Rally of Portugal</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Estoril_Circuit" class="mw-redirect" title="Estoril Circuit">Estoril</a>, <a href="/wiki/Algarve_Circuit" class="mw-redirect" title="Algarve Circuit">Algarve Circuits</a> and the revived <a href="/wiki/Porto_Street_Circuit" class="mw-redirect" title="Porto Street Circuit">Porto Street Circuit</a> which holds a stage of the WTCC every two years, as well as for a number of internationally noted pilots in varied <a href="/wiki/Motorsports" class="mw-redirect" title="Motorsports">motorsports</a>. </p>
      <p>In equestrian sports, Portugal won the only Horseball-Pato World Championship in 2006 achieved the third position in the First <a href="/wiki/Horseball" title="Horseball">Horseball</a> World Cup and has achieved several victories in the European <a href="/wiki/Working_Equitation" class="mw-redirect" title="Working Equitation">Working Equitation</a> Championship. </p>
      <p>In water sports, Portugal has three major sports: <a href="/wiki/Swimming_(sport)" title="Swimming (sport)">swimming</a>, <a href="/wiki/Water_polo" title="Water polo">water polo</a> and <a href="/wiki/Surfing" title="Surfing">surfing</a>. Most recently, Portugal had success in <a href="/wiki/Canoeing" title="Canoeing">canoeing</a> with several world and European champions, such as olympic medalists. Annually, the country also hosts one of the stages of the <a href="/wiki/World_Surf_League" title="World Surf League">World Surf League</a> men's and women's <i>Championship Tour</i>, the <a href="/wiki/MEO_Rip_Curl_Pro_Portugal" title="MEO Rip Curl Pro Portugal">MEO Rip Curl Pro Portugal</a> at the <a href="/wiki/Supertubos" title="Supertubos">Supertubos</a> in <a href="/wiki/Peniche,_Portugal" title="Peniche, Portugal">Peniche</a>. </p>
      <p>Northern Portugal has its own original <a href="/wiki/Martial_art" class="mw-redirect" title="Martial art">martial art</a>, <i><a href="/wiki/Jogo_do_Pau" class="mw-redirect" title="Jogo do Pau">Jogo do Pau</a></i>, in which the fighters use staffs to confront one or several opponents. Other popular sport-related recreational outdoor activities with thousands of enthusiasts nationwide include <a href="/wiki/Airsoft" title="Airsoft">airsoft</a>, fishing, <a href="/wiki/Golf" title="Golf">golf</a>, hiking, hunting and <a href="/wiki/Orienteering" title="Orienteering">orienteering</a>. </p>
      <p>Portugal is one of the world's best <a href="/wiki/Golf" title="Golf">golf</a> destinations.<sup id="cite_ref-253" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-253">[248]</a></sup> It has received several awards by the World Golf Awards.<sup id="cite_ref-254" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-254">[249]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="See_also">See also</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Portugal&amp;action=edit&amp;section=55" title="Edit section: See also">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2> 
      <style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r936637989">.mw-parser-output .portal{border:solid #aaa 1px;padding:0}.mw-parser-output .portal.tleft{margin:0.5em 1em 0.5em 0}.mw-parser-output .portal.tright{margin:0.5em 0 0.5em 1em}.mw-parser-output .portal>ul{display:table;box-sizing:border-box;padding:0.1em;max-width:175px;background:#f9f9f9;font-size:85%;line-height:110%;font-style:italic;font-weight:bold}.mw-parser-output .portal>ul>li{display:table-row}.mw-parser-output .portal>ul>li>span:first-child{display:table-cell;padding:0.2em;vertical-align:middle;text-align:center}.mw-parser-output .portal>ul>li>span:last-child{display:table-cell;padding:0.2em 0.2em 0.2em 0.3em;vertical-align:middle}</style>
      <div role="navigation" aria-label="Portals" class="noprint portal plainlist tright"> 
       <ul> 
        <li><span><img alt="flag" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5c/Flag_of_Portugal.svg/32px-Flag_of_Portugal.svg.png" decoding="async" width="32" height="21" class="noviewer thumbborder" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5c/Flag_of_Portugal.svg/48px-Flag_of_Portugal.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5c/Flag_of_Portugal.svg/64px-Flag_of_Portugal.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="600" data-file-height="400"></span><span><a href="/wiki/Portal:Portugal" title="Portal:Portugal">Portugal portal</a></span></li>
       </ul>
      </div> 
      <ul>
       <li><a href="/wiki/Index_of_Portugal-related_articles" title="Index of Portugal-related articles">Index of Portugal-related articles</a></li> 
       <li><a href="/wiki/Outline_of_Portugal" title="Outline of Portugal">Outline of Portugal</a>
        <div style="clear:both;"></div></li>
      </ul> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Notes">Notes</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Portugal&amp;action=edit&amp;section=56" title="Edit section: Notes">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2> 
      <div class="reflist" style="list-style-type: decimal;">

         <li id="cite_note-b-4"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-b_4-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">By country of citizenship</span> </li>

         <li id="cite_note-16"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-16">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">In recognized minority <a href="/wiki/Languages_of_Portugal" title="Languages of Portugal">languages of Portugal</a>:

       </div>
      </div> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="References">References</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Portugal&amp;action=edit&amp;section=57" title="Edit section: References">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2> 
      <div class="reflist" style="list-style-type: decimal;"> 
       <div class="mw-references-wrap mw-references-columns">
        <ol class="references"> 
         <li id="cite_note-auto-1"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-auto_1-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-auto_1-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r999302996">.mw-parser-output cite.citation{font-style:inherit}.mw-parser-output .citation q{quotes:"\"""\"""'""'"}.mw-parser-output            <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20190621135623/https://www.v-dem.net/en/news-publications/democracy-reports/">"Democracy Reports | V-Dem"</a>. <i>www.v-dem.net</i>.          <li id="cite_note-41"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-41">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFGarstk2012" class="citation journal cs1">Garstk, Kevin (28 August 2012). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://dc.uwm.edu/ekeltoi/vol9/iss1/9/">"Celtic from the West: Alternative Perspectives from Archaeology, Genetics, Language and Literature.            <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.historyireland.com/pre-history-archaeology/tartessian-europes-newest-and-oldest-celtic-language/">"Tartessian, Europe's newest and oldest Celtic language"</a>. 5 March 2013.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Tartessian%2C+Europe%27s+newest+and+oldest+Celtic+language&amp;rft.date=2013-03-05&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.historyireland.com%2Fpre-history-archaeology%2Ftartessian-europes-newest-and-oldest-celtic-language%2F&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APortugal" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-43"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-43">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFDevine" class="citation web cs1">Devine, Darren. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.walesonline.co.uk/news/wales-news/celtic-roots-lie-spain-portugal-2174486">"Our Celtic roots lie in Spain and Portugal"</a>. <i>Wales Online</i><span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">11 April</span> 2017</span>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=Wales+Online&amp;rft.atitle=Our+Celtic+roots+lie+in+Spain+and+Portugal&amp;rft.aulast=Devine&amp;rft.aufirst=Darren&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.walesonline.co.uk%2Fnews%2Fwales-news%2Fceltic-roots-lie-spain-portugal-2174486&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APortugal" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-44"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-44">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://ppg.revistas.uema.br/index.php/brathair/article/download/1785/1305">"Info"</a>. <i>ppg.revistas.uema.br</i><span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">11 July</span> 2020</span>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=ppg.revistas.uema.br&amp;rft.atitle=Info&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fppg.revistas.uema.br%2Findex.php%2Fbrathair%2Farticle%2Fdownload%2F1785%2F1305&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APortugal" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-45"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-45">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Estos se establecieron en el norte de Portugal y el área de la <a href="/wiki/Galicia_(Eastern_Europe)" title="Galicia (Eastern Europe)">Galicia</a> actual, introduciendo en esta región la cultura de las urnas, una variante de las Urnenfelder que evolucionaría después en la cultura de los castros o castreña</span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-46"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-46">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFRadical" class="citation web cs1">Radical, The. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://peopleinhistory.co.uk/celts-part-1">"Celts Part 1"</a>. <i>People In History</i>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=People+In+History&amp;rft.atitle=Celts+Part+1&amp;rft.aulast=Radical&amp;rft.aufirst=The&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fpeopleinhistory.co.uk%2Fcelts-part-1&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APortugal" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-47"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-47">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">

         <li id="cite_note-54"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-54">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">David Rohrbacher, "Orosius," in <i>The Historians of Late Antiquity</i> (Routledge, 2002), <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=TLvK-_fk8TkC&amp;pg=PA135&amp;dq=Orosius+life+OR+biography+OR+born+OR+birth&amp;lr=&amp;num=100&amp;as_brr=3&amp;sig=ACfU3U2atlXMBUN45DliVbnt_fLlckZInw">pp. 135–137.</a> Rohrbacher bases the date of birth on Augustine's description of Orosius as a "young priest" and a "son by age" in the period 414–418, which would place his age at 30 or younger.</span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-auto4-55"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-auto4_55-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-auto4_55-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text">

         <li id="cite_note-62"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-62">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFFerreiro1999" class="citation book cs1">Ferreiro, Alberto (1999). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=7QNl90qnOp8C&amp;q=visigothic+culture+portugal+academia&amp;pg=PR11"><i>The Visigoths: Studies in Culture and Society</i></a>. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/9004112065" title="Special:BookSources/9004112065"><bdi>9004112065</bdi></a>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=The+Visigoths%3A+Studies+in+Culture+and+Society&amp;rft.date=1999&amp;rft.isbn=9004112065&amp;rft.aulast=Ferreiro&amp;rft.aufirst=Alberto&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3D7QNl90qnOp8C%26q%3Dvisigothic%2Bculture%2Bportugal%2Bacademia%26pg%3DPR11&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APortugal" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li>

In Brown, George Williams (ed.). <i><a href="/wiki/Dictionary_of_Canadian_Biography" title="Dictionary of Canadian Biography">Dictionary of Canadian Biography</a></i>. I (1000–1700) (online&nbsp;ed.). University of Toronto Press<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">31 January</span> 2014</span>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=bookitem&amp;rft.atitle=Corte-Real%2C+Miguel&amp;rft.btitle=Dictionary+of+Canadian+Biography&amp;rft.edition=online&amp;rft.pub=University+of+Toronto+Press&amp;rft.date=1979&amp;rft.aulast=Vigneras&amp;rft.aufirst=L.-A.&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.biographi.ca%2Fen%2Fbio%2Fcorte_real_miguel_1E.html&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APortugal" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-83"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-83">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://pcsp.ca/?Content=Visiting/About_Our_Town/History">"Town of Portugal Cove – St.Philip's&nbsp;: History"</a>. <i>Pcsp.ca</i><span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">14 September</span> 2015</span>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=Pcsp.ca&amp;rft.atitle=Town+of+Portugal+Cove+%E2%80%93+St.Philip%27s+%3A+History&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fpcsp.ca%2F%3FContent%3DVisiting%2FAbout_Our_Town%2FHistory&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APortugal" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-84"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-84">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The standard view of historians is that Cabral was blown off course as he was navigating the currents of the South Atlantic, sighted the coast of South America, thereby accidentally discovering Brazil. However, for an alternative account of the discovery of Brazil, see <a href="/wiki/History_of_Brazil" title="History of Brazil">History of Brazil</a></span> </li>

         <li id="cite_note-117"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-117">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
